editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: Hi≈øtorical Remarques, AND OBSERVATIONS Of the Ancient and Pre≈øent State of LONDON and WESTMINSTER. Shewing

The Foundation, Walls, Gates, Towers, Bridges, Churches, Rivers, Wards, Palaces, Halls, Companies, Inns of Court and Chancery, Ho≈øpitals, Schools, Government, Charters, Courts and Priviledges thereof.
With an Account of the mo≈øt Remarkable Accidents, as to Wars, Fires, Plagues, and other Occurrences which have happened therein for above Nine Hundred Years pa≈øt, till the Year 1681.
Illu≈øtrated with Pictures of the mo≈øt con≈øiderable Matters curiou≈øly Ingraven on Copper Plates; With the Arms of the Sixty Six Companies of London, and the time of their Incorporating.
By RICHARD BURTON, Author of the Hi≈øtory of the Wars of England.
LONDON, Printed for Nath. Crouch at the Bell next to Kemps Coffee hou≈øe in Exchange Alley, over again≈øt the Royal Exchange in Cornhil. 1681.

div.head: TO THE READER.
div.p:
AN Ingenious Hi≈øtorian who was a great Traveller, writing concerning this famous City about Thirty years ≈øince, ventured to compare it as to Scituation, Government, Trade, Arti≈øts, and all other Accommodations to the greate≈øt Cities in Europe, yea all things con≈øidered, to the Greatest in the World, and if at that time it de≈øerved ≈øuch high Encomiums, then certainly ≈øince its Ri≈øe out of tho≈øe Ruines that unhappily befell a great part thereof by the dreadful fire in 1666, it doth even excel it ≈øelf; and the Beauty thereof is very much increa≈øed, e≈øpecially as to ∆≤niformity and Curio≈øity of Buildings, largene≈øs of Streets, and many other Excellencies which that fiery Purgation hath occa≈øioned; So that we may invert what was formerly ≈øaid of Solomon's Temple in Ezra's time, That the Glory of the former City is
not to be compared with the Glory of the latter.

There needs then no Apology for making this ≈øhort Collection concerning this great Subject, e≈øpecially ≈øince there are few Books now extant that Treat of the Antiquities thereof, and none that I know of, who have written of the particular Accidents that happened thereunto; It cannot therefore be unacceptable to have a ≈øhort Manunual of ≈øo many particulars, for ≈øo long time pa≈øt at ≈øo ≈ømall a price as this is, The ≈øerious peru≈øal whereof will very much confirm the Truth of what the wi≈øe Solomon writ ≈øo long ≈øince, Eccl. 1.9. The thing that hath been, it is that which ≈øhall be, and that which is done is that which ≈øhall be done, and there is no new thing under the Sun.

div.head: CHAP. I. The Original and Foundation of the Famous City of London.
div.p: THough it may ≈øeem difficult to di≈øcover the Original of ≈øome Nations and Cities, yet it is no hard matter to find out the Foundation of this Honourable and Famous City of London.

But as the Roman Writers to magnify the City of Rome, drew its Original from Gods, and Demy-Gods, by the race of the Trojans, ≈øo Jeffery of Monmouth our Wel≈øh Hi≈øtorian, for the greater Glory of this Renowned City, deduceth it from the ≈øame Original, relating that Bruce who de≈øcended from the Demy-God Aeneas, the Son of Venus, Daughter of Jupiter, about the year of the World 2855, and 1108 years before the Nativity of our ble≈ø≈øed Saviour built this City near the River now called Thames, and named it Troynovant, or Trenovant; but this Account has no great Authority.

The ≈øame Hi≈øtorian tells us, that K. Lud afterward repaired and increa≈øed this City with fair Buildings, Towers, and Walls, and called it after his own name Caire Lud or Luds Town, and the Gate which he built in the We≈øt part thereof, he likewi≈øe for his own Honour named Ludgate. He adds, That this Lud had two Sons, Androgeus and Theomantius, who being not of Age to Govern at the Death of their Father, their Uncle Ca≈ø≈øibelan took upon him the Crown; in the eight year of who≈øe Reign, Julius Cae≈øar arrived in England with a formidable Army to Conquer it, and obliged the Brittains to pay a yearly Tribute to Rome. Cae≈øar calls London the City of the Trinobantes, which ≈øounds ≈øomewhat like Troy Nova, though learned men think that Trinobantes ≈øignifies the State or Signiory of the Trinobantes.

But in tho≈øe dayes, the Cities of the Brittains were not artificially built with Stone or Timber, but were only thick, and Trouble≈øome Woods pla≈øhed together, and intrenched round, like to tho≈øe which the Iri≈øh at this day call Fa≈øtne≈ø≈øes; Some are of Opinion that whence London had her Fame, from thence ≈øhe had al≈øo a Name, that is from Ships, which the Brittains call Lough, and Dinan a Town, ≈øo that London is no other than Shipton, a Town of Ships; which Title no City hath more Right to a≈ø≈øume than this, being ≈øcituated upon the gentle A≈øcent of an Hill, near a gallant Navigable River, which ≈øwelling at certain times with the Ocean Tides, ≈øhe is able by her deep and ≈øafe Channel to entertain the greate≈øt Ships, which bring in all the riche≈øt Commodities the World can afford.

Some would have Llwndian the Wel≈øh name of London, to be derived from Llhwn which ≈øignifies a fenced Town, made of Trees ca≈øt down and barricadoed together, as aforementioned, for ≈øo the Poet ≈øings.

q.l: ‚Äî Their Hou≈øes were the Thicks,
And bu≈øhy queachy hollow Caves
And Hurdles made of Sticks.

div.p: And it is probable, that in the Place where St. Pauls Church now ≈øtands, there was a Wood or Grove, and a Temple dedicated to Diana, which was u≈øually ≈øet up in the Woods; and in a place about St. Pauls, there were the Heads and Bones of Oxen lately found, which is ≈øuppo≈øed were offered in Sacrifice to her.

Now though it be not certainly known, who was the Founder of London, yet whoever it was, he ≈øhewed much Prudence in the Choice of Scituation; for ≈øhe ≈øeems to have been built in an happy hour, having continued for ≈øo many Ages; Amianus Marcellinus who wrote near thirteen hundred years ago, calls her then, an Ancient City.

When the Romans had reduced the hither parts of Brittain into the form of a Province, and had ≈øown the ≈øeeds of Civility here, as well as over all Europe, this City began to be renowned and famous for Wealth, Riches, and Pro≈øperity, yea ≈øhe continued always the ≈øame under the Romans, Saxons, and Normans, being ≈øeldom or never afflicted with any great Calamities. In the Reign of Nero, when the Brittains had con≈øpired to recover their lo≈øt Liberty, under the Conduct of Boadicia, the Londoners could not with all their weeping and Lamentations, keep Suetonius Paulinus in the City, but after he had rai≈øed a Power of the Citizens, he would needs go from thence, leaving the City naked to the Enemy, who pre≈øently ≈øurprized it, and ≈ølew tho≈øe whom either weakne≈øs, feeblene≈øs, or ≈øweetne≈øs of the place, had detained there. Nor was London in le≈øs danger by the Gaules or French, if ≈øhe had not been wonderfully pre≈øerved, for when Caius Alectus, had Treacherou≈øly de≈øtroyed Carau≈øius, he kept to him≈øelf the Revenues of Brittain and Holland,
and called him≈øelf Augu≈øtus Emperour, as his Coins often found here do demon≈øtrate; But when Marcus A≈øclepiodotus had ≈ølain him in Battel, tho≈øe French who remained alive after the Fight, ha≈øtening to London, would have plundred the City, had not the River Thames, (who never fail'd to help the Londoners at need) very happily brought the Roman Legions to their A≈ø≈øi≈øtance, who put the Barbarians to the Sword all the City over. About which time it is Recorded, that Lucius Gallus was ≈ølain by a Brook≈øide which ran almo≈øt through the City, and of him was called by the Brittains, Wantgall, in Engli≈øh, Walbrook, which name remains to this day, under which there is a Sewer within the ground, to carry the Kennel water of the City into the Thames. This is not far from London-≈øtone, which is thought to be a Milemark, or Miliary, ≈øuch as were in the Market Places of Rome, from which were taken dimen≈øions of Journeys every way, which ≈øeems the more probable, becau≈øe this Stone is near the mid≈øt of the City as it lyeth in length.

After this Julius Agricola the Roman Lieutenant per≈øwaded the Brittains to build Hou≈øes for them≈øelves, and Temples for their Gods, to bring up their Children in Learning, and to Apparel them≈øelves like Romans; ≈øo that in a few years after our Saviours Nativity ≈øhe became famous, but e≈øpecially for the multitude of Merchants, Provi≈øion and Trade thereof, as Cornelius Tacitus notes, and was then called by ≈øome Authors Londinum, by others Augu≈øta, under which name her Fame is celebrated by an Ancient Author, which is thus Tran≈ølated by Philemon Holland;
This City was Augu≈øta call'd
To which (a truth to ≈øay)
Air, Land. Sea, and all Elements
Show favour every way.
The Weather no where milder is,
The Ground mo≈øt rich to ≈øee,
Which yields all ≈øorts of u≈øeful Fruit
That never ≈øpent will be.
The Ocean that with Thames her Streams
His flowing Tyde doth blend,
Conveys to it Commodities
All that the World can ≈øend.
The Noble Seat of Kings it is;
For State and Royalty
Of all the Realm, the Fence, the Heart,
The Life, the Light, the Eye.
The People Ancient, Valorous,
Expert in Chivalry,
Enriched with all ≈øorts of Goods,
Of Art, or Mi≈øtery.
Take a ≈øtrict view of every thing
And then ≈øay thus in brief,
This either is a World it ≈øelf
Or of the World the Chief.

div.head: CHAP. II. The Ancient, and pre≈øent Walls and Gates of the City.
div.p: HI≈øtorians report, That about the year after Chri≈øt 306, Con≈øtantine the Great, at the de≈øire of his Mother Helena, did fir≈øt build a Wall about this City, which may ≈øeem more probable, con≈øidering that the Brittains did under≈øtand how to build Walls with Stone, as may appear by the following Relation.

About the Year of Chri≈øt 399, when the Empire of Rome was invaded, and that City de≈øtroyed by the Goths, the Romans called away all their Forces from Brittain for the Defence of their own Countrey; After which the Brittains being not able to defend them≈øelves, were for many years oppre≈ø≈øed by two cruel Nations, that is, the Scots and Picts, whereupon they ≈øent Amba≈ø≈øadors, with Letters full of Lamentable Supplications and Complaints to Rome, to de≈øire their a≈ø≈øi≈øtance, promi≈øing con≈øtant Obedience to them. The Romans ≈øent them a Legion of Souldiers, who fought with their Enemies and drove them out of the Countrey; And leaving the Brittains at Liberty they advi≈øed them to make a Wall cro≈øs the Countrey from one Sea to the other, for their defence again≈øt their trouble≈øome Neighbours; and then the Romans returned home in Triumph.

The Brittains built this Wall in the North of England, but wanting Ma≈øons, they did not make it of Stone as the Romans directed, but of Turf, which was ≈øo weak, that it was little Security to them. For their Enemies perceiving the Romans were gone, they pre≈øently came in Boats, and invaded their Countrey, ruining and wa≈øting all before them. Upon which
Amba≈ø≈øadors were again ≈øent with fre≈øh Lamentations to Rome, be≈øeeching them not to ≈øuffer their mi≈øerable Countrey to be wholy de≈øtroyed; The Romans then ≈øent them another Legion, who coming ≈øuddenly, ≈øurprized their Enemies and made a great ≈ølaughter among them, cha≈øing them back again even to their own Countrey.

The Romans departing home again, told the Brittains plainly, that the Journey hither was long and trouble≈øome, and therefore they mu≈øt expect no further help from them; but mu≈øt learn to u≈øe Armour, and weapons them≈øelves, thereby to be able to re≈øi≈øt their Enemies, who were incouraged to invade them becau≈øe of their Cowardice and Faintheartedne≈øs; However for the incouragement of their Tributary Friends, whom they were now forced to for≈øake the Romans made them a Wall of hard Stone from the We≈øt Sea to the Ea≈øt Sea, and built two Cities at each end thereof, the Brittains labouring therein al≈øo. This Wall was built Eight Foot thick, and twelve Foot high, directly Ea≈øt and We≈øt, as appears by the ruins to be ≈øeen at this day. The work being fini≈øhed; the Romans gave them a ≈øtrict charge to look to them≈øelves, and to in≈øtruct their People in the u≈øe of Arms, and Millitary Di≈øcipline, and lea≈øt the Enemy ≈øhould come by Sea, Southward, they made divers Bulwarks at ≈øome di≈øtance from each other by the Sea≈øide; And then bid the Brittains farewel, as intending to return no more; This happened in the Reign of Theodo≈øius the younger; near 500 years after the fir≈øt Arrival of the Romans here, and about the year of our Lord 434.

The Brittains after this had ≈øeveral Skirmi≈øhes with the Picts and Scots, and made Choice of Vortiger to be their King and Leader, who is ≈øaid to have been neither Wi≈øe nor Valiant, being wholly given up to Lu≈øt and Debauchery; And the People likewi≈øe having ≈øome re≈øt from their Enemies, ran into Gluttony,
Drunkenne≈øs, Pride, Contention, Envy, and all manner of Vice, to the great ≈øcandal of their Chri≈øtian Profe≈ø≈øion. At which time a dreadful Pe≈øtilence fell upon them, which de≈øtroyed ≈øuch a multitude of them, that the quick were not ≈øufficient to bury the dead, and yet tho≈øe that remained alive continued ≈øo impenitent, that neither the death of their Friends, nor fear of their Enemies had any Effect upon them, whereupon Divine Ju≈øtice pur≈øued them even almo≈øt to the De≈øtruction of the whole ≈øinful Nation

For being now again in danger of utter ruin from their old Neighbours the Scots and Picts, they con≈øult with their King Vortiger what to do, and at la≈øt conclude to call in the Saxons, who ≈øoon after arrived in Brittain; where (≈øaith Bede) they were received as Friends, For having driven out the Picts and Scots, they likewi≈øe drove out the Brittains, forcing ≈øome of them to fly over the Seas, and others into the barren and wa≈øte Mountains of Wales and Cornwall.

The Saxons were likewi≈øe ignorant of building with Stone till the year 680. for it is affirmed that Bennet Abbot of Werral, and Ma≈øter to Reverend Bede, fir≈øt brought in Artificers for Stone hou≈øes, and Gla≈øs Windows, unknown before to the Saxons, who built only with Wood. And to this Polychronicon agrees; who ≈øpeaking of tho≈øe times, ≈øaith, Then had ye wooden Churches, nay wooden Chalices, but Golden Priests; but now you have Golden Chalices, and Wooden Prie≈øts. And to conclude this Argument, King Edgar in his Charter to the Abby of Malmsbury, dated the year of Chri≈øt 974, writes to this Effect; All the Mona≈øteries in my Realm to the outward ≈øight are nothing but wormeaten and rotten Timber, and Boards, and which is wor≈øe, within they are almost empty, and void of Divine Wor≈øhip.

Thus much as to Walls in General, now to return to London; This City was de≈øtroyed and burnt by the Danes, and other Pagan Enemies, about the year of our Lord 839, and was nobly rebuilt, and repaired in
the year 886 by Alfred King of the We≈øt Saxons, ≈øo that it lay wa≈øte, and uninhabited for almo≈øt fifty years; Alfred committed the cu≈øtody of this new built City to his Son in Law Etheldred Earl of Mercia, to whom he had before married his Daughter Ethelsted; And that this City was then ≈øtrongly Walled may appear by divers Accidents; William of Malmsbury writes, that about the year 994 the Londoners ≈øhut up their Gates and defended their King Etheldred within their Walls again≈øt the Danes. In the year 1016, Canutus the Dane made War again≈øt Edmond Iron≈øide, King of the West-Saxons, and brought his Navy to the We≈øt part of the Bridge, ca≈øting a Trench about the City of London, and attempted to have won it by a≈ø≈øault, but the Citizens repul≈øed him, and drove him from their Walls. Likewi≈øe in the year 1052, Earl Godwin with his Navy, Sailed up by the South end of the Bridge, and a≈ø≈øailed the Walls of this City.

William Fitz Stephen in the Reign of Henry 2. writes thus, The Wall of London is High and Great, well Towered on the North ≈øide, with due distance between the Towers. On the South ≈øide al≈øo the City was Walled and Towered, but the Fi≈øhful River of Thames by his ebbing and flowing hath long ≈øince ≈øubverted them. Where by the North≈øide he means from the River in the Ea≈øt to the River of Thames in the We≈øt, for ≈øo the Wall ≈øtretched in his time, and the City being far longer from Ea≈øt to We≈øt, than in breadth from South to North, and al≈øo narrower at both ends than in the mid≈øt, is therefore compa≈ø≈øed with the Wall on the Land≈øide in the form of a Bow, except where it is indented in betwixt Cripplegate and Alder≈øgate. But the Wall on the South≈øide along the River of Thames was ≈øtreight as the ≈øtring of a Bow and fortified with Towers or Bulwarks (as we now term them) in due di≈øtance from each other, as our Author ≈øays, and we our ≈øelves may ob≈øerve at this day, this demon≈øtrates that the Walls of this City are of great Antiquity.

Now for repairing and maintaining this Wall, we find, That in the year 1215 and the 6th of King John. The Barons entring the City by Aldgate, fir≈øt took A≈ø≈øurance of the City, and then broke into the Jews hou≈øes, and ≈øeizing their Money and Goods for their own u≈øes, they with great diligence repaired the Walls, and Gates of this City, with Stones taken from the Jews broken Hou≈øes. In the year 1257, Henry 3. ordered the Walls of this City which were much decayed and without Towers to be hand≈øomely repaired, and beautified at the common Charge of the City.

In the 17th of Edward 4. Ralph Joceline Mayor cau≈øed part of the Wall of the City of London to be repaired between Aldgate, and Alder≈øgate; He al≈øo cau≈øed Morefields to be ≈øearched for Clay to make brick for that purpo≈øe. The Skinners made that part of the Wall between Aldgate, and Buvies Marks, (commonly call'd Bevis Marks) toward Bi≈øhop≈øgate, as may appear by their Arms fixed in three places there; The Lord Mayor, and his Company of Drapers made all that part between Bi≈øhop≈øgate and Alhallows Church in the Wall, and from Alhallows toward the Po≈øtern called Moregate. A great part of the ≈øame Wall was repaired by the Executors of Sir John Crosby Alderman, his Arms being in 2 places; and other Companies repaired the re≈øt of the Wall to Cripplegate, the Gold≈ømiths repaired from Cripplegate to Alder≈øgate, and there the work cea≈øed.

The Circuit of the VVall of London on the Lands ≈øide, that is from the Tower of London in the Ea≈øt to Aldgate is 82 Perches; From Aldgate to Bi≈øhop≈øgate 86 Perchees; From Bi≈øhop≈øgate to Cripplegate 162 Perches; From Cripplegate to Alder≈øgate 75 Perches; From Alder≈øgate to Newgate 66 Perches; From Newgate to Ludgate 42 Perches; in all 513 Perches of A≈ø≈øize. From Ludgate to Fleet Ditch 60 Perches; From Fleetbridge to the River of Thames about 70 Perches. So that the total of the≈øe Perches amounteth
to 643; and every Perch being 5 Yards and an half, makes 3536 Yards and an half, containing 10608 Foot, which is two Engli≈øh Miles and 608 Foot more.

In former time there were but four Gates in the VVall of this City, that is Aldgate for the Ea≈øt; Alder≈øgate for the North; Ludgate for the VVe≈øt; and Bridgate over London Bridge for the South, but of late days for the Conveniency of Pa≈ø≈øengers, divers other Gates and Po≈øterns have been made.

Fitz Stephen ≈øaith, that in the Reign of Henry 2 there were ≈øeven Double Gates in the VVall of this City, but names them not, we may therefore ≈øuppo≈øe them to be, 1. The Gate next the Tower of London, called the Postern. 2. Aldgate. 3. Bi≈øhop≈øgate. 4. Alder≈øgate. 5. Newgate. 6. Ludgate. 7. Bridge-gate. Since which there hath been built Moregate, now a Famous Gate and ≈øeveral other ≈ømaller Po≈øterns, as one between Bi≈øhop≈øgate and Moregate, and two between Moregate and Cripplegate; be≈øides other in other Places.

As to the fir≈øt called the Po≈øtern near the Tower (which was de≈øtroyed by the dreadful Fire in 1666 of which you have a particular Account in this Treati≈øe and never ≈øince rebuilt or like to be) by that which remained of it before, it ≈øeemed to have been a fair ≈øtrong Arched Gate, built of hard Stone. In the year 1190, and the 2. of Richard 1. William Long≈øhamp, Bi≈øhop of Ely Chancellor, cau≈øed part of the City VVall from that Gate to the White Tower to be broken down, for inlarging the Tower, round which he made a VVall imbattelled, which is now the outermo≈øt VVall; He likewi≈øe made a broad deep Ditch without the VVall, to let in the Tyde from the Thames; But the South≈øide of this Gate was by undermining the Foundation much weakned, and about two Hundred years after, that is 1440, the 18 Hen. 6. it fell down, and was never ≈øince rebuilt.

The next in the Ea≈øt, is ALDGATE, or Oldgate of the Antiquity thereof, having been one of the four Principal Gates, and al≈øo one of the ≈øeven Double Gates aforementioned; It had two pair of Gates and Portculli≈øes, though now but one; yet the hooks of the other Gate, and the place of letting down the other Portcullice are yet to be ≈øeen. This Gate appeareth to be very Ancient, being named in a Charter in King Edgars time; and likewi≈øe in K. Edward 1. And in the Civil VVars between K. John, and his Barons 1215. the Londoners were on the Barons part, who then be≈øieged Northampton, and after came to Bedford Ca≈øtle, where they were well received by William Beauchamp Captain thereof; and having then ≈øecret Notice, that if they plea≈øed they might enter the City, they removed their Camp to Ware, and from thence coming to London in the Night, they entred by Aldgate, and placing Guards at the Gates, they di≈øpo≈øed of all things at their plea≈øure.

They ≈øpoiled the Fryers Hou≈øes, and ≈øearcht their Coffers; after which Robert Fitzwater, Jeffery Magnaville, the Earl of E≈ø≈øex, and the Earl of Gloce≈øter cheif Commander in the Army applied them≈øelves to repair the Gates and VValls of the City, with ≈øtones taken from the Jews Hou≈øes as afore≈øaid; and Aldgate being mo≈øt ruinous, and having given them an ea≈øie entrance, they repaired, or rather new built it, after the manner of the Normans, with ≈øtrong Arches, and Bulwarks of Stone, ≈ømall brick, and Flanders Tile.

In the 11 of Edw. 4. 1471, Thomas Ba≈øtard Fauconbridge, having A≈ø≈øembled a Riotous Company of Seamen and others in E≈ø≈øex, and Kent, came with a great Navy of Ships up to the Tower of London; whereupon the L. Mayor and Aldermen with con≈øent of the Common Council fortified the Thames ≈øides with Armed Men, Guns, and other warlike weapons, from Baynards Ca≈øtle to the Tower, to prevent their Landing; But the Rebels being denied pa≈ø≈øage that way,
they fell upon Aldgate, Bi≈øhop≈øgate, Cripplegate, Alder≈øgate, London Bridge, and along the Bank≈øide, ≈øhooting Arrows, and Guns into the City, and burning above three≈øcore hou≈øes in the Suburbs.

And upon Sunday May 11, 1471. Five thou≈øand of them a≈ø≈øaulting Aldgate, won the Bulwarks, and entred the City, but the Portcullice being let down, tho≈øe that were in were ≈ølain? And Robert Ba≈ø≈øet Alderman of that Ward, commanded them in the name of God to draw up the Portcullice, which being done, the Londoners i≈ø≈øued out of the Gate, and couragiou≈øly beat back their Enemies to St. Buttolphs Church, by which time, the Earl Rivers and the Lieutenant of the Tower coming with fre≈øh Forces, joined them, and then they ≈øoon routed the Rebels, and made them fly, Alderman Ba≈ø≈øet and other Citizens cha≈øing them to Miland, and from thence, pur≈øued ≈øome of them to Poplar, and others to Stratford, killing many, and taking divers Pri≈øoners. In the mean time, Fauconbridge their Commander, having in vain a≈ø≈øaulted other Places on the Water≈øide, fled to his Ships. Thus much of Aldgate as it was of old, we ≈øhall ≈øpeak of the rebuilding when we come to Aldgate Ward.

The third Gate toward the North, is BISHOPSGATE; ≈øuppo≈øed to be built by ≈øome Bi≈øhop of London, though now unknown; But the occa≈øion thereof was for the ea≈øe of Pa≈ø≈øengers, e≈øpecially to Norfolk, Suffolk, Cambridg≈øhire, &c. who before were forced to go much about; yet it is ≈øomewhat Ancient, for we read that in the year 1210, ≈øome Land was ≈øold to the Procurators or Wardens of London Bridge, ≈øituate in the Pari≈øh of St. Buttolph without Bi≈øhop≈øgate. And in a Charter dated 1235. It is writt, That Walter Brume and Ro≈øia his Wife, having founded the Priory, or New Ho≈øpital of our Ble≈ø≈øed Lady, (≈øince called St. Mary Spittle (without Bi≈øhop≈øgate, have confirmed the ≈øame to the Honour of God, and our Ble≈ø≈øed Lady for Canons Regular. Al≈øo in 1247, Simeon Fitz Mary, Sheriff of
London, the 29 Hen. 3. founded the Ho≈øpital of St. Mary called Bethlem without Bi≈øhop≈øgate:

And for repairing this Gate, Hen. 3. confirmed certain Liberties to the Merchants of the Haunce to keep it in repair, which they did for many years; But in the year 1551, having prepared Stone and a new Gate to be ≈øet up, at the Complaint of the Engli≈øh Merchants their Charter was taken from them, ≈øo that the Old Gate remained.

Next to this upon the North≈øide of the City, is MOREGATE; of which we read, that in the 3d of Hen. 5. 1415, Thomas Faulconer Mayor, cau≈øed the VVall of the City to be broken through near Coleman≈øtreet, and there builded a Po≈øtern, now called Moregate, of a Moory ground hard by, which is now drained, and made fair and firm, and turned into ≈øeveral Feilds and delightful VValks, with Trees ≈øet in curious Order for the Accommodation of the Citizens; This Gate ≈øince the dreadful Fire of London in 1666 has been new built and is made very Noble with a great Arch and two Po≈øterns, ≈øo that it now equals, if not excels any other Gate of the City.
Between this Gate and Cripplegate there have been lately made two Po≈øterns through the VVall, for the better ea≈øe of Pa≈ø≈øengers, and ≈øeveral new Hou≈øes built near them.

CRIPPLEGATE is next, which is of great Antiquity being ≈øo called before the Conque≈øt, for we read that in 1010, the Danes ≈øpoiling the Kingdom of the East-Angles, Alwyn Bi≈øhop of Helinham, cau≈øed the body of King Edmund the Martyr to be brought from Bredi≈øworth (now called St. Edmunds Bury) through the Kingdom of the East-Saxons, and ≈øo to London in at Cripplegate. Some ≈øay it was ≈øo named from Cripples begging there, and that when the body of St. Edmund pa≈ø≈øed through it, many Miracles were wrought thereby, as that ≈øome of the Lame were cured, prai≈øing God, &c. This Body continued three years in St. Gregories
Church near St. Pauls. And further, William the Conquerour in his Charter for Confirming the Foundation of the Colledge in London, called St. Martins le Grand, ≈øaith thus, I do give and grant to the ≈øame Church, and Canons ≈øerving God therein, all the Lands, and the Moor without the Po≈øtern which is called Cripplegate, on either part of the Po≈øtern. VVe read likewi≈øe, That Alfune builded the Pari≈øh Church of St. Giles nigh a Gate of the City called Porta Contractorum or Cripple≈øgate, about the year 1090.

This Gate was formerly a Pri≈øon for Citizens for Debt or otherwi≈øe, like one of the Counters; It was new built in 1244 by the Brewers of London; and Edmund Shaw Gold≈ømith in 1483. gave by his VVill 400 Marks, and the ≈øtuff of the the old Gate called Cripplegate, to build the ≈øame again, which was accordingly done in 1491.

ALDERSGATE or Aelder≈øgate is next, not ≈øo called from Aldwich, or of Elders, or Ancient men building the ≈øame, nor of Elder Trees growing more plentifully there than in other places, as ≈øome have fancied; but only from the Antiquity thereof, it being one of the four fir≈øt Gates of this City, ≈øerving for the Northern, as Aldgate doth for the Ea≈øtern Parts, and being both Old Gates, for di≈øtinction, one is called Alder≈øgate, and the other Aldgate; This Gate hath had ≈øeveral Additional buildings to it, as on the South≈øide, where ≈øeveral large Rooms and Lodgings of Timber have been made; And on the Ea≈øt≈øide a Great Timber building with one large Room paved with Stone or Tile) there is likewi≈øe a well curbed with Stone, and of a great depth, which ri≈øes into that Room though two Stories high from the Ground, which is very remarkable; John Day a famous Printer, dwelt in this Gate, and built many Hou≈øes upon the City wall toward St. Anns Church. You may read more of the new building this Gate in Alder≈øgate Ward.

In the ≈øixth year of Edw. 6. Three was a Po≈øtern Gate made through the City VVall on the North≈øide of the late di≈ø≈øolved Cloi≈øter of Friars Minors, commonly called Gray Friars; Now Chri≈øt Church, and Ho≈øpital; this was done to make a Pa≈ø≈øage from Chri≈øt Church Ho≈øpital, to St. Bartholomews Ho≈øpital in Smithfield, and Licen≈øe was given to Sir Richard Dobbs, Lord Mayor to do it, by Virtue of an Act of Common Council, Aug. 1. in the 6 of Edw. 6.

The next Gate is on the Northwe≈øt, and is called NEWGATE, and is the fifth Principal Gate, though built later than the re≈øt, being erected about the Reign of Hen. 1. or K. Stephen upon this occa≈øion. The Cathedral of St. Pauls being burnt down in the Reign of William the Conquerour 1086. Mauritius then Bi≈øhop of London, did not repair the Old Church as ≈øome have thought, but laid the Foundation of a new one, which it was judged would hardly ever have been fini≈øhed, it was ≈øo wonderful for length, bredth, and height; and likewi≈øe becau≈øe it was rai≈øed upon Vaults or Arches, after the Norman fa≈øhion, and never known in England before.

After Mauritius, Richard Beumore did very much advance the building of this Church purcha≈øing the large Streets and Lanes round about, which ground he incompa≈ø≈øed with a ≈øtrong Stone VVall and Gates: By rea≈øon of this inclo≈øure for ≈øo large a Church-yard, the High-≈øtreet from Aldgate in the Ea≈øt, to Ludgate in the We≈øt, was made ≈øo ≈øtreight and narrow, that the Carriage through the City was by Paterno≈øter-Row, down Ave-Mary Lane, and ≈øo through Bouger Row (now called Ludgate≈øtreet) to Ludgate; or el≈øe by Cheap≈øide through Watlingstreet, and ≈øo through Carter-lane, and up Creedlane to Ludgate, which Pa≈ø≈øage by rea≈øon of the often turning was very Inconvenient.

VVhereupon a New Gate was made to pa≈øs through Cheap≈øide (North of St. Pauls) St. Nicholas Shambles, and Newgate-≈øtreet to Newgate, and from thence we≈øtward
to Holbourn Bridge; or Turning without the Gate, to Smithfield, and I≈ølington, (or I≈øeldon) or to any place North, or VVe≈øt. This Gate hath for many years been a Pri≈øon for Felons, Murderers, Highwaymen and other Tre≈øpa≈ø≈øers, as appeareth by the Records of King John and others; and among the re≈øt in the 3. of Hen. 3. 1218. That King writ to the Sheriffs of London, commanding them to repair the Goal of Newgate, for the ≈øafe keeping of his Pri≈øoners, promi≈øing that the Charges thereof ≈øhould be allowed them upon their Account in the Exchequer.

In the year 1241. The Jews of Norwich were hanged being accu≈øed for Circumci≈øing a Chri≈øtian Child; their Hou≈øe (called the Thor) was pulled down and de≈øtroyed; Aaron the Son of Abraham a Jew, and other Jews in London, were con≈øtrained to pay twenty thou≈øand Marks, at two Terms in the year, or el≈øe to be kept perpetual Pri≈øoners in Newgate at London, and in other Pri≈øons.

In 1255, King Henry 3. lodged in the Tower, and upon ≈øome di≈øplea≈øure again≈øt the City of London, for the e≈øcape of John Offrem a Clerk Convict, Pri≈øoner in Newgate, for killing a Prior who was Cou≈øin to the Queen, He ≈øent for the Lord Mayor, who laid the fault on the Sheriffs to who≈øe Cu≈øtody the Pri≈øoners are committed; the Mayor was di≈øcharged, but the Sheriffs were impri≈øoned above a month, though they alledged the fault was in the Bi≈øhops Officers, who though he was impri≈øoned in Newgate, yet they were to ≈øee that he was kept ≈øafe. But however the King required three thou≈øand Marks of the City for a Fine.

In the third year of Edw. 3. 1326. Robert Baldock the Kings Chancellor was put into Newgate. In 1237, Sir John Pouitney gave four Marks a year for releif of the Pri≈øoners in Newgate. In 1358, William Walworth gave likewi≈øe toward their relief, and ≈øo have many others ≈øince. In 1414, the Jaylors in Ludgate and Newgate died, and 64 Pri≈øoners. In 1418, the Par≈øon
of Wertham in Kent was Impri≈øoned in Newgate. In the fir≈øt of Henry 6, 1412. The Executors of Richard Whittington repaired Newgate. And Thomas Knowles Grocer, ≈øometimes L. Mayor, brought the wa≈øt water from the Ce≈øtern near St. Nicholas Chappel, by St. Bartholomews Ho≈øpital to Newgate and Ludgate for the Accommodation of the Pri≈øoners. In 1431, all the Pri≈øoners in Ludgate were conveyed to Newgate, by the Sheriffs of London; And ≈øoon after they fetcht from thence 18 Per≈øons, Freemen of the City, who were led pinioned to the Counters like Felons, by the fal≈øe ≈øugge≈øtion of the Jaylor of Newgate; But Ludgate was a while after again appointed for Freemen who were Debtors; and they were all carried back again thither.

In 1427. There was a great Skirmi≈øh in the North Countrey between Sir Thomas Percie, Lord Egremond, and the Earl of Salisburies Sons, whereby many were wounded and ≈ølain, but the Lord Egremond being taken was found to give the occa≈øion, and was thereupon condemned by the Kings Council, to pay a con≈øiderable Sum of Money to the Earl of Salisbury, and in the mean time was committed to Newgate; and a while after both he, and his Brother Sir Richard Percie brake out by night, and went to the King. The other Pri≈øoners got upon the Leads over the Gate, and defended it again≈øt the Sheriffs, and all their Officers a great while, till they were forced to call more Citizens to their Aid, who at la≈øt ≈øubdued them, and laid them in Irons; Thus much of Newgate.

LUDGATE is the next in the VVe≈øt, and the Sixth Principal Gate of this City, and Hi≈øtorians ≈øay, was built by King Lud, near 66 years before our Saviours Nativity; which ≈øhews its great Antiquity; This being built for the VVe≈øt, as Aldgate for the Ea≈øt.

In the year 1215. aforementioned, being the 17th. of King John, when the Barons who were in Arms again≈øt the King, entred this City, and pull'd down
the Jews Hou≈øes, repairing the VValls and Gates of the City with the Stones thereof; It appeareth that they then repaired or rather new built this Gate; For in 1586 when this Gate was pulled down in order to its being repaired, there was a ≈øtone found within the wall, which ≈øeems to have been taken from one of the Jews Hou≈øes, there being ≈øeveral Hebrew Characters ingraven thereon, which being interpreted are thus in Engli≈øh; This is the Station or Ward of Rabbi Mo≈øes, the Son of the Honourable Rabbi I≈øaac. This it is thought had been fixed upon one of the Jews Hou≈øes, as a ≈øign he lived there.

In 1260, Ludgate was repaired, and beautified with the Images of Lud and other Kings, but in the Reign of Edw. 6. the≈øe Images of the Kings had their Heads ≈ømitten off, and were defaced, by ≈øuch as judged every Image to be an Idol; In the Reign of Q. Mary they were repaired and new heads ≈øet upon their old Bodies, which remained ≈øo, till the 28 of Q. Elizabeth 1586. VVhen this Gate was quite taken down and nobly Rebuilt, with the Images of K. Lud and others on the Ea≈øt-≈øide, and Q. Elizabeth on the VVe≈øt, which was done at the City Charge being above 1500 pounds.

In 1463. Stephen Foster Fi≈øhmonger, and Dame Agnes his VVife, added ≈øeveral large Rooms to Ludgate, and gave other releif to the Pri≈øoners, who are only ≈øuch Citizens as are Debtors; All Per≈øons for Trea≈øons, Felonies, and other Criminal Offences being committed to Newgate. In one of the≈øe rooms, there was a Copper Plate hanging with the following Rhimes ingraven thereon.

q.l: Devout Souls that pa≈øs this way,
For Stephen For≈øter late Mayor, heartily pray;
And Dame Agnes his Spou≈øe, to God Con≈øecrate,
That of pity this Hou≈øe made of London in Ludgate
So that for lodging and water, Pri≈øoners here nought pay
As their keepers ≈øhall all an≈øwer at dreadful Doom≈øday.

div.p: This Gate (as well as Newgate) in the late di≈ømal Fire in 1666, was burnt down, but ≈øince they are both repaired and very curiou≈øly Beautified having a new. Po≈øtern for Foot Pa≈ø≈øengers added thereto; with ≈øeveral other Conveniencies. Thus much for Ludgate.

Next to this before the late Fire, there was only a breach in the VVall of the City and a Bridge of Timber over Fleet Ditch; directly again≈øt Bridewell Ho≈øpital; but ≈øince, it is all laid open, and a hand≈øome Bridge of Stone built in that Place, the Ditch being very much enlarged, and a VVharf made of Stone, and cleared from all Hou≈øes on each ≈øide up to Holborn Bridge. The Bridge likewi≈øe at the lower end of Ludgate Hill being nobly rebuilt, or rather new built and made much broader, and another Gallant Bridge is built upon the ≈øame Ditch almo≈øt over again≈øt the Fleet Pri≈øon. All this has been done ≈øince the di≈ømal Fire, to the very great Charge of the City. And ≈øo much for the Gates in the Wall.

Now for the VVatergates on the Banks of the River Thames, which formerly have been many, though mo≈øt, or all of them have been ruined by the late Fire, however take a breif Account of what they were. Black Fryers Stairs is a free landing place now gallantly rebuilt with a u≈øeful Bridge by Sir Tho. Fitch, who has built a very curious hou≈øe upon the VVharf, and cleared it, ≈øo that now the Lord Mayor when he comes from Westminster to be ≈øworn Lands there, in≈øtead of Pauls Wharf, as being much more convenient. Then there is Puddle Wharf, Pauls Wharf, Broken Wharf, be≈øides divers others all along the River which are made by the Citizens for their Private u≈øe. Next is Ripa Regina, the Queens Bank, or Queen Hyth, which was accounted the Cheif and Principal VVatergate of this City, far exceeding Billings-Gate, as it appears in Queen-hithe VVard.

figure.head: Wat Tyler kild by ye Lord Mayor.

div.p: The next was called Wolfes Gate in the Ropary, afterward called Wolfes lane, but now out of u≈øe. The next was called Ebgate of old time, as appeareth by Ancient Records, and ≈øtood near St. Lawrence Pountneys Church, it is now a narrow Lane, and called Ebgate lane, but u≈øually the Old Swan. There was another Gate at the Bridgfoot called Oy≈øter Gate, of Oy≈øters that were there ≈øold, that being the Market-place for them, and other ≈ømall Fi≈øh; But now there ≈øtandeth an Engine to carry up the water into the City in the place thereof.

Then there is the BRIDG-GATE, ≈øo called of London Bridge whereon it ≈øtandeth; This long before the Conque≈øt was one of the four fir≈øt, or Principal Gates of the City, where there was only a Bridge of Timber, and is the ≈øeventh and la≈øt Principal Gate mentioned by Fitz Stephen; when the Bridge was new built of Stone, this Gate was rebuilt again; In the year 1436, this Gate with the Tower upon it fell down, and two of the furthe≈øt Arches of the Bridg, Southward fell therewith, yet none were killed, or hurt thereby; to the repairing whereof ≈øeveral Citizens gave very Liberally. When the Ba≈øtard Fauconbridg aforenamed came with the Kenti≈øh Mariners into this City, they burnt this Gate, and thirteen Hou≈øes be≈øides on the Bridge, and likewi≈øe the Brewhou≈øes at St. Katherines and many others in the Suburbs.

Next hereunto was a Gate, commonly called Buttolphs Gate, of the Pari≈øh Church adjoyning, This was given; or confirmed by William the Conquerour to the Monks of We≈øtmin≈øter. Then there is Billing≈øgate, which is much u≈øed by ≈ømall Ships & Barges, ≈øo that Queen Hyth is almo≈øt for≈øaken. It is ≈øomewhat uncertain why this Gate was ≈øo named, only Jeffry of Monmouth writes, that Belin a King of the Brittains about 400 years before Chri≈øts Nativity, built this Gate, and called it after his own name, & that when he was dead his Body was burned, and the A≈øhes were put into a ve≈ø≈øel of Bra≈øs, and ≈øet over that Gate upon an High Pinacle of Stone; yet it doth not ≈øeem to be ≈øo Ancient, but rather to have taken the name from ≈øome late Owner, called (it may be) Beling, or Billing, as Somers Key, Smarts Key, Fre≈øh Warf and others have done; Then there was a Watergate on the South-end of Water-lane by the Cu≈øtom-hou≈øe Key, but of all the≈øe more hereafter. One other Watergate there was more by the Bulwark of the Tower, and this is the la≈øt, and farthe≈øt Gate Ea≈øtward on the River of Thames as far as the City of London extends within the Walls.

Be≈øides the≈øe Common Water Gates, there were formerly divers private Wharfs, and Keys all along from the Ea≈øt to the We≈øt of this City, on the Thames ≈øide, where Merchants of all Nations landed their Goods, and had Warehou≈øes, Cellars, and Stowage form them. And in the 42 of Hen. 3. 1258. it was appointed that the Ports of England ≈øhould be ≈øtrongly Guarded and the Gates of London ≈øhould be newly repaired and diligently kept in the night for fear of French deceits.

div.head: CHAP. III. Of the Tower of London, (and other Ancient Towers and Ca≈øtles of this City) with ≈øeveral Remarkable Accidents happening therein.
div.p: THe City of London (≈øaith Fitz Stephen) hath in the Ea≈øt a very Great, and mo≈øt Strong Palatine Tower, who≈øe Turrets and Walls do ri≈øe from a deep Foundation, the Mortar thereof being tempered with the Bloud of Bea≈øts.

It is the Common Opinion that Julius Cae≈øar the fir≈øt Conquerour, or indeed Di≈øcoverer of Brittain was the Original Founder thereof and of many other Towers Ca≈øtles and Great Hou≈øes. But there is little Rea≈øon for it, in regard of his ≈øhort ≈øtay here, having other things to think on, de≈øigning only to di≈øpatch his Conque≈øt over this Barbarous Countrey, and then to perform greater Enterprizes; Neither do the Roman Hi≈øtorians mention any ≈øuch Buildings erected by him here.

The more probable Opinion therefore is, That William the Conquerour built the Great white and ≈øquare Tower there about the year of our Lord 1078, as appears by Ancient Records, and that made Gundulph Bi≈øhop of Roche≈øter Principal Surveyor of the work. The Wall of the City of London (as it is aforementioned) was furni≈øhed formerly with Towers, and Bulwarks in due di≈øtance from each other; and the River of Thames with its Ebbing and Flowing had overthrown the Walls and Towers on the Banks thereof, whereupon William the Conquerour for the defence of the City which lay open to the Enemy, having taken down
the ≈øecond Bulwark in the Ea≈øt part of the Wall toward the Thames, built the Great White Tower, which hath been ≈øince enlarged at ≈øeveral times with buildings adjoining thereto; This Tower in the 4th. of William Rufus, 1092. was much ≈øhaken and defaced by a great Tempe≈øt of Wind; but was again repaired by William Rufus, and Henry the fir≈øt, who likewi≈øe built a Ca≈øtle on the South-≈øide thereof toward the Thames, intrenching the ≈øame round about. Hi≈øtorians ≈øay of this William Rufus, That he challenged the Inve≈øtiture of Prelates, He pilled, and ≈øhared the People with Tribute, e≈øpecially to ≈øpend about the Tower of London, and the Great Hall at We≈øtmin≈øter.

The four fir≈øt Con≈øtables or Keepers of the Tower were Othowerus, Acolinillus, Otto, and Jeffry Magnaville Earl of E≈ø≈øex, who was al≈øo Sheriff of London, Middle≈øex, E≈ø≈øex and Hertford≈øhire; He fortified the Tower of London again≈øt K. Stephen, but the King ≈øeizing him at his Court at St. Albans would not di≈øcharge him, till he had delivered it up, together with the Ca≈øtles of Walden, and Pla≈øhey in E≈ø≈øex. In 1153, the Tower of London, and Ca≈øtle of Wind≈øor were delivered by the King to Richard de Lucie, to be ≈øafely kept. In 1155, Thomas Becket, Chancellor to Hen. 2. cau≈øed the Flemings to be bani≈øhed out of England, their Ca≈øtles lately built to be demoli≈øhed, and the Tower of London to be repaired.

In the 2. of Rich. fir≈øt, 1190. William Long≈øhamp Bi≈øhop of Ely, Lord Chancellor (by rea≈øon of ≈øome difference between him, and Earl John the Kings Brother, who was in Rebellion) inclo≈øed the Tower and Ca≈øtle of London with an outward Wall of Stone embatailed; and likewi≈øe cau≈øed a deep ditch to be made about the ≈øame, de≈øigning (as is aforementioned) to have invironed it with the River of Thames. This inclo≈øure and Ditch took away ≈øome ground from Trinity Church in London, which King Edward recompenced. And a great quantity of Ground likewi≈øe
was taken from the City upon this Account, yet the Citizens had no recompence, nor were offended thereat, ≈øince it was done with their liking, as being for the defence of the City.

But another Hi≈øtorian ≈øaith, that in 1239, Hen. 3. Fortified the Tower of London to another Purpo≈øe, and the Citizens fearing it was intended to their detriment, complained to the King; who an≈øwered, That he had not done it to their hurt, but (≈øaith he) I will do from henceforth as my Brother doth, (in building and fortifying Castles) who beareth the name of being wi≈øer than I. But the next year, all the≈øe Noble Buildings of the Stone Gate and Bulwark, were ≈øhaken as with an Earthquake, and fell down; which the King commanded to be again built better than before. And in the year 1241. Though the King had be≈øtowed above 12000 Marks in the work, yet the Wall and Bulwarks irrecoverably fell down; at which the Citizens were very well plea≈øed; for they were threatned, that when this Wall and Bulwarks were built, if any of them ≈øhould contend for the Liberties of the City they ≈øhould be Impri≈øoned therein.

Yet were they again rebuilt and fini≈øhed by Edward the 1. and the Bulwark at the We≈øt-gate, now called the Lyon Tower, added; the Original of which name, and of Lyons in England, we read was thus. Henry the 1. built the Mannor of Woodflock, and walled the Park about with ≈øtone, ≈øeven Miles in compa≈øs, de≈øtroying to that purpo≈øe divers Villages, Churches and Chappels, and this was the fir≈øt Park in England, and as the Record ≈øaith; He appointed therein (be≈øides great ≈øtore of Deer) divers ≈øtrange bea≈øts to be kept and nouri≈øhed, ≈øuch as were brought to him from far Countreys, as Lyons, Leopards, Linxes, Porpentines, and ≈øuch other, for ≈øuch was his Estimation among Outlandi≈øh Princes, that few would willingly offend him.

In the year 1235, we read, that Frederick the Emperour, ≈øent Henry 3. three Leopards in token of his Regal ≈øheild of Arms, wherein they were pictured; ≈øince which time, the Lyons, and other Creatures have been kept in a part of this Bulwark now called the Lyons Tower. In the 16 of Edward 3. One Lyon, One Lyonefs, One Leopard and two Cattes Lyons were committed to the cu≈øtody of Robert Boure. Edw. 4. Fortified the Tower of London, and inclo≈øed a peice of Ground (We≈øt from the Lyon Tower) upon Towerbill with brick, now called the Bulwark. And in the 6th. year of his Reign, he ordered a Scaffold and Gallows to be ≈øet upon the Hill for the Execution of Offenders upon which the L. Mayor and Aldermen complained to the King, but were an≈øwered, That it was not done in Derogation of the Cities Liberties, and cau≈øed Proclamation to be made thereof accordingly.

Richard the 3. and Henry the 8. repaired this Tower; but in the 2. of Edward 6, 1548. Nov. 22. A Frenchman lodging in the round Bulwark, between the We≈øtgate, and the Po≈øtern, by ≈øetting fire to a Barrel of Gunpowder in the night, blew up that Bulwark, yet burnt none but him≈øelf; this Bulwark was ≈øoon rebuilt again. This we≈øt Gate of the Tower is the Principal Gate, for receiving, and delivering all manner of Carriages, and without it, there are divers Bulwarks and Gates turning to the North; within this Gate to the South is a ≈øtrong Po≈øtern for Pa≈ø≈øengers, by the VVard-hou≈øe, over a Drawbridge, which is let down, and pull'd up at plea≈øure.

Next to this on the South ≈øide Ea≈øt-ward, is a large VVater-gate (commonly called Traytors Gate, becau≈øe ≈øome have been carried in that way) this Gate is partly under a ≈øtrong Stone Bridge from the River of Thames. Beyond which was a ≈ømall Po≈øtern with a Drawbridge ≈øeldom let down but for receiving in ≈øome Great Per≈øons Pri≈øoners; Further to the Ea≈øt was a
Great and ≈øtrong Gate called the Iron Gate, but not u≈øually opened. And ≈øo much for the Foundation, building and repairing of the Tower, with the Gates and Po≈øterns. There are many Fair Hou≈øes within the walls of the Tower, wherein the Officers belonging thereto, and other Inhabitants live, there is al≈øo a Chappel.

In the year 1196, William Fitz Ozbet a Citizen, ≈øeditiou≈øly moving the People to ≈øtand up for their Liberties, and not to be ≈øubject to the Rich and Mighty, was taken, and brought before the Archbi≈øhop of Canterbury in the Tower where he was condemned by the Judges, and being drawn thence by the Heels to the Elms in East-Smithfield, he was there hanged. In 1214. King John writ to Jeffery Magnaville to deliver the Tower of London with the Pri≈øoners, Armour, and all other things found therein belonging to the King, to William Archdeacon of Huntington. In the fir≈øt of Henry 3. 1216. the Tower was delivered to Lewes of Franse, and the Barons of England. In 1206 Pleas of the Crown were pleaded in the Tower, and divers times afterward. In 1222, the Citizens having made a Tumult again≈øt the Abbot of We≈øtminster, Hubbert of Burg, Cheif Ju≈øtice of England, ≈øent for the Lord Mayor and Aldermen to the Tower of London to enquire who were Principal Authors thereof. Among≈øt whom, one named Con≈øtantine Fitz Aelufe boldly avowed, That he was the man, and had done much le≈øs than he thought to have done; whereupon the Cheif Ju≈øtice ≈øent him, with two others to Falks de Brent, who with armed men brought them to the Gallows, and hanged them.

In 1244, Griffith Prince of Wales, being a Pri≈øoner in the Tower, attempted an e≈øcape, and having in the night tyed the Sheets, and hangings together he endeavoured thereby to ≈ølide from the top of the High Tower, but being a Fat man the weight of his Body brake the Rope, and he fell; The next morning
he was found dead, his head and neck being driven into his Brea≈øt between the Shoulders. In 1253, K. Hen. 3. impri≈øoned the Sheriffs of London in the Tower above a Month, about the e≈øcape of a Pri≈øoner out of Newgate, as is aforementioned. In 1260, this King with his Queen (for fear of the Barons) lodged in the Tower; And the next year he ≈øent for his Lords, and held his Parliament there.

In 1263, As the Queen was going by water from the Tower toward Wind≈øor, ≈øeveral Citizens got together upon London Bridge, under which ≈øhe was to pa≈øs, who not only u≈øed reproachful words again≈øt her, but threw ≈øtones and dirt at her, forcing her to go back again, but in 1265. they were forced to ≈øubmit them≈øelves to the King for it, and the Lord Mayor, Aldermen, and Sheriffs were ≈øent to ≈øeveral Pri≈øons; Othon, Con≈øtable of the Tower, being made Cu≈øtos, or keeper of the City.

About this time, Leoline Prince of Wales came down from the Mountain of Snowdon to Montgomery, and was taken at Bluith Ca≈øtle, where u≈øing reproachful words again≈øt the Engli≈øh, Roger le Strange fell upon him, and with his own ≈øword cut off his head, leaving his dead body on the Ground; Sir Roger Mortimer cau≈øed this Head to be ≈øet upon the Tower of London, crowned with a wreath of Ivy; And this was the end of Leoline, who was betrayed by the Men of Bluith, and was the la≈øt Prince of the Britti≈øh bloud who Ruled in Wales.

In 1290, Several Judges as well of the Kings Bench as the A≈ø≈øize, were ≈øent Pri≈øoners to the Tower, and with great Sums of Money obtained their Liberty; Sir Thomas Weyland had all his E≈øtate confi≈øcated, and him≈øelf bani≈øhed; Sir Ralph Hengham Lord Chief Ju≈øtice of the Kings Bench; paid 7000 Marks; Sir John Lovet Cheif Ju≈øtice of the Lower Bench 3000 Marks. Sir William Brompton 6000 Marks; Yea their Clerks were fined al≈øo, as being confederate with their Ma≈øters
in Bribery and Inju≈øtice; Robert Littlebury Clerk paid 1000 Marks; and Roger Leice≈øter as much. But a certain Clerk of the Courts, called Adam de Straton paid thirty two thou≈øand Marks of Old and new Money, be≈øides Jewels without number, and precious ve≈ø≈øels of Silver, which were found in his Hou≈øe, together with a Kings Crown, whi ‚Ä¢ h ≈øome ≈øaid was King Johns. After this the King con≈øtrained the Judges to ≈øwear; That for the future they ≈øhould take no Pen≈øion, Fee, or Gift of any man, except a breakfa≈øt, or ≈øome ≈øuch ≈ømall kindne≈øs.

In the 14 of Edw. 2. The King allowed to the Pri≈øoners in the Tower, two pence a day to a Knight; and a peny a day to an E≈øquire for their Diet. In 1320. The Kings Ju≈øtices ≈øate in the Tower, for Trial of divers matters, at which time John Gi≈ø≈øors, late Lord Mayor of London, and ≈øeveral others fled to the City, for fear of being charged with things they had pre≈øumptuou≈øly done. The next year the Mortimers yeilding them≈øelves to King Edw. 2. he ≈øent them Pri≈øoners to the Tower, where they were condemned to be drawn, and hanged. But Roger Mortimer of Wigmore, by giving his Keepers ≈øleepy drink; made his e≈øcape, but his Uncle Mortimer died there, above 5 years afterward.

In 1326. The Citizens of London took po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the Tower, and taking away the keys from the Con≈øtable, they di≈øcharged all the Pri≈øoners, and kept both the City and Tower for the u≈øe of Queen I≈øabel and her ≈øon Edward, (who was afterward Edw. the III.)

In 1330, Roger Mortimer Earl of March, was taken, and committed to the Tower, from whence he was drawn to the Elmes, and their hanged on the Common Gallows, where he hung two days and two nights by the Kings Command, and was then buried in the Gray Friers Church; This Earl was condemned by his Peers, and yet was never brought to make his Defence before them. He him≈øelf having procured a Law to that purpo≈øe, by which the Earls of Lanca≈øter,
Winche≈øter, Gloce≈øter, and Kent were put to death, and now he him≈øelf ≈øuffered by the ≈øame Law.

In the 3. of Edw. 3. 1344. The King commanded Florences of Gold to be coyned in the Tower; Perceval de Port, of Lake, being then Ma≈øter of the Mint, and this is the fir≈øt coining we read of there; we read likewi≈øe that the ≈øame year the King appointed his Exchange of Money to be kept in Sernes Tower, being part of the Kings Hou≈øe in Buckles (or Bucklers) Bury. And we find that in former times all great Sums were paid by weight, that is, ≈øo many pounds or Marks of Gold or Silver cut into blank peices without any ≈øtamp upon them, and ≈ømaller Sums were paid in Starlings which were pence ≈øo called, for they had no other Moneys; This Starling, or Ea≈øterling money, took its name, as it is judged, from the Ea≈øterlings which fir≈øt made it in England in the Reign of Hen. 2. though others imagine it ≈øo called from a Star ≈øtamped in the Ring or Edge of the Peny; or of a Bird called a Starling ≈øtamped on it; others yet more unlikely, of being coyned at Striveling or Sterling, a Town in Scotland, but the fir≈øt Opinion ≈øeems the mo≈øt probable:

In 1360. A Peace being concluded between England and France, Edward the 3d. came back into England, and went to the Tower to vi≈øit the French King, who was Pri≈øoner there, ≈øetting his Ran≈øome at three Millions of Florences, which being paid, he was di≈øcharged from his Impri≈øonment and the King conducted him with Honour to the Sea≈øide.

In the 4th. of Rich. 2. 1381. A grievous Tax was laid upon the Subjects, which cau≈øed much Trouble. For the Courtiers, greedy to inrich them≈øelves, informed the King that the Tax was not ≈øo carefully gathered as it ought; And therefore they would pay a great Sum of Money to Farm it, which they would rai≈øe above what it was before, by being more ≈øevere in gathering it. This Propo≈øition was ≈øoon accepted, ≈øo that having the Kings Authority, and Letters, the≈øe
Farmers or Commi≈ø≈øioners, met in ≈øeveral Places in Kent and E≈ø≈øex, where they levied this Tax of Groats, or Polemoney, with all manner of ≈øeverity, which ≈øo di≈øcontented the People, that they combined together, and re≈øi≈øted the Collectors, killing ≈øome, wounding others, and making the re≈øt fly.

The Tumult began fir≈øt in Kent, upon this occa≈øion, (as it is related in the Chronicles of St. Albans) One of the≈øe Exactors coming to the Hou≈øe of John (others ≈øay) Wat Tyler, living at Dartford in Kent, demanded of Tylers Wife, a Groat a piece for her Husband, her ≈øelf, and Servants, and likewi≈øe for a young Maiden her Daughter; The woman paid for all but her daughter, alleaging ≈øhe was a Child, and underage to pay; That will I ≈øoon know, (quoth the Collector) and ≈øhamefully turned the young Maids Coats up, to ≈øee whether ≈øhe were come to ripene≈øs of Age; (the≈øe Villains having in divers other Places made the like ba≈øe; and uncivil Trials.) Hereupon the Mother crying out, divers of the Neighbours came in, and her Husband being at work in the Town, tyling a hou≈øe hearing of it, taking his Lathing-≈øtaff in his hand, ran home, and finding the Collector, asked him, who made him ≈øo bold? the Collector returned ill Language and ≈øtruck at Tyler, who avoiding the blow, gave the Collector ≈øuch a home-blow with his Lathing-≈øtaff, that his Brains flew out of his head; which made a great uproar in the Streets, and the People being glad at what had happened, they prepared to defend and ≈øtand by Tyler.

And thereupon a great number of them being got together, they went from thence to Maid≈øtone, and then to Black-Heath, per≈øwading, and Exhorting all the People as they marched along to join with them in this common Cau≈øe, and ≈øetting Guards upon all the ways to Canterbury, they ≈øtopped all Pa≈ø≈øengers, compelling them to ≈øwear; That they would keep Allegiance to King Richard, and to the Commons; That they would
accept of no King who≈øe name was John, (becau≈øe of the hatred they had to John Duke of Lanca≈øter, who called him≈øelf King of Ca≈øtile) And that they ≈øhould be ready when they were called, and ≈øhould agree to no Tax to be levied from thenceforth in the Kingdom, nor con≈øent to any, except it were a Fifteenth.

There joyned with them one John Ball a factious Clergyman, who took occa≈øion to rip up the grounds of the Mi≈ø-government, telling the People, That this difference of Mens E≈øtates, where ≈øome were Potentates, and others Bondmen, was again≈øt Christian Liberty, taking for his Text this old Rhyme,
When Adam Delv'd and Eve Span,
Who was then a Gentleman.

This ≈øo incen≈øed the Commons that their Number daily increa≈øed, ≈øo that when they were come as far as Blackheath, they were e≈øteemed to be an Hundred Thou≈øand, ≈øo that fearing no re≈øi≈øtance, they began to commit all manner of Violence, ≈øparing none whom they thought to be learned e≈øpecially if they found a pen or Inkhorn about him, for then they pull'd off his Hood, and with one Voice cryed out, Hale him out, and cut off his head. The King ≈øent ≈øome Knights to them to know the cau≈øe of their A≈ø≈øembling, To whom they an≈øwered, That for certain Cau≈øes they were come together, and de≈øired to talk with the King, and therefore willed the Knights to tell him, That he must needs come to them, that he might understand the de≈øire of their Hearts. The King was advi≈øed by ≈øome to go pre≈øently to them, but Simon Sudbury Archbi≈øhop of Canterbury, Lord Chancellor, and Robert Hales of St. Johns, Trea≈øurer, affirmed, That it was not fit for the King to go to ≈øuch a rude Company, but rather to take Order to ≈øuppre≈øs them.

This the Commons hearing, were ≈øo enraged, that they ≈øwore, They would go ≈øeek the Kings Traytors, and
cut off their beads; And thereupon they marched into Southwark, and ruined the Archbi≈øhops Palace at Lambeth, out of ≈øpight to him. The Lord Mayor and Aldermen fearing they would do the like to the City, ordered the Gates to be ≈øhut, but the Commoners of the City, e≈øpecially the Poorer ≈øort, favouring the Commoners of the Countrey, threatned death to all that ≈øhould attempt it; So that the Rebels had free Egre≈øs, and Regre≈øs in and out of London, and dayly incouraged the Citizens to favour their Cau≈øe, declaring, Their Purpo≈øe was only to bring the Traytors of the Land to Ju≈øtice, and then they would lay down their Arms; And hereby they won them to ≈øtand by them.

The fir≈øt thing they did when they came to London was to ≈øend for one Richard Lyon a Grave Citizen, who had been Tylers Ma≈øter, and having ≈øtruck off his head, they carried it upon a Pole in Triumph before them. The next day they came to the Savoy, the Duke of Lancasters Hou≈øe, which they ≈øet on fire, burning all his rich Furniture, breaking in peices all his Plate and Jewels, and throwing them into the Thames, ≈øaying, They were men of Ju≈øtice, and would not like Robbers inrich them≈øelves with any mans Goods, for they only were for destroying Traytors; And when one of their Fellows was e≈øpied to thru≈øt a fair piece of Silver into his bo≈øom, they took him, and ca≈øt both him and it into the Fire; neither took they any thing from any man but at the ju≈øt price. Two and thirty of them were got into the Dukes Wine-cellar, where they ≈øtayed drinking ≈øo long, till the Rafters of the Hou≈øe, which was on Fire, fell upon them, and ≈øo covered them, that not able to get out, they were heard cry ≈øeven days after, and then peri≈øhed.

From the Savoy they went to the Temple where they burnt the Lawyers Chambers, with their Books, and Writings, and all they could lay hands on. Al≈øo the Noble Hou≈øe of St. Johns, by Smithfield they ≈øet on
Fire, which burnt for ≈øeven days together, not ≈øuffering any to quench it, And likewi≈øe the Mannor of Highbury, and other Places belonging to St. Johns. After this they came to the Tower, where King Richard lodged, and ≈øent to command him, To come to them, without delay, unarmed, and without any Guard, which if he refu≈øed, they would pull down the Tower, and be ≈øhould not e≈øcape alive. The King finding no other Remedy though he had 600 Armed Men, and as many Archers about him, yet dur≈øt not but ≈øuffer them to enter, ≈øo that in great fear the King went toward them on Hor≈øeback, his own Guards ≈øtanding as men amazed. Being come into the Tower, the≈øe Ru≈øticks pre≈øumed to enter into the King, and his Mothers Chambers with their Weapons, and laid them≈øelves on the Kings bed, ≈øporting and playing thereon, yea they abu≈øed the Kings Mother, offering to ki≈øs her in ≈øuch a rude manner that ≈øhe fell into a Swound.

They then proceeded with Rage and Fury to ≈øearch for the Arch-bi≈øhop of Canterbury, and finding one of his Servants, charged him to bring them to the Traytor his Ma≈øter; the Servant being afraid brought them to the Chappel where his Ma≈øter was at Prayers, who being aware of their coming had continued there all night; and when he heard they were come, he ≈øaid with great con≈øtancy to his Servants, Let us now go, ≈øurely it is be≈øt to dye, when it is no plea≈øure to live; Upon which the Rabble cryed, Where is the Traytor? who an≈øwered, I am the Archbi≈øhop whom you ≈øeek, not a Traytor. Whereupon they dragged him out of the Chappel to Tower-hill, where being incompa≈ø≈øed with many Thou≈øands, and ≈øeeing many drawn ≈øwords about his head he ≈øaid,

What is it (dear Brethren) you purpo≈øe to do? what is mine offence committed against you, for which you will kill me? you were best take heed, that if I be killed, who am your Pastor, there come not on you the Indignation of the just Revenger, or at least for ≈øuch a fact all England be not put under Interdiction, or the Popes Cur≈øe. But
they cried out with a great noi≈øe, That they did not fear the Interdiction, neither did allow the Pope to be above them. The Archbi≈øhop ≈øeeing death at hand, ≈øpoke them fairly, and granting forgivene≈øs to the Executioner, he kneeled down and offered his Head to be cut off; The Hangman ≈øtruck him on the neck but not deadly, he putting up his hand, ≈øaid, Aha, it is the hand of God; and being ≈øtruck again before he removed his hand, his fingers ends were cut off, and part of the Arteries; with which he fell down, but died not, till they had mangled him with eight ≈øeveral ≈øtrokes in the Neck and Head. His body lay two days unburied, none daring to do it; His Head they cut off, and nailing his hood thereon, fixt it upon a Pole on London Bridge. This Simon Sudbury was eighteen years Bi≈øhop of London, and being tran≈ølated to Canterbury, he in 1375. repaired the Walls of London from the West-gate, (which he built) to the North-gate, which had been de≈øtroyed by the Danes, before the Conque≈øt of William the Ba≈øtard. He was at la≈øt buried in the Cathedral at Canterbury.

Sir Robert Hales Lord Trea≈øurer of England, ≈øuffered with him at the ≈øame time, a mo≈øt Valiant Knight, and Lord of St. Johns; together with John Leg, one of the Serjeants at Arms, and William Apledore a Franci≈øcan Friar who was the Kings Confe≈ø≈øor; Many more were beheaded daily, for no cau≈øe but the plea≈øure of the Commons, for it was pa≈øtime to them, to take any who were not ≈øworn of their Party, and pulling off their Hoods, behead them; They took 13 Flemings out of the Augustine Friers, 17 out of another Church, and 32 in the Vintry, and beheaded them all; And to make a di≈øtinction of Flemings, they put them to pronounce, Bread, and Chee≈øe; and if they ≈øpake it like, Brot, and Caw≈øe, off went their Heads, as a ≈øure ≈øign that they were Flemings.

The King coming according as he was required, to Mile-end, was much a≈øtoni≈øhed at the madne≈øs of the
People, who with frowning Countenances made the following demands which they pre≈øented in writing, ‚Ä¢ nd would have them confirmed by the Kings Letters Patents.

list.item: 1. That all men ≈øhould be free from Servitude or Bondage, ≈øo that from thenceforth there ≈øhould be no Bondmen.

2. That he ≈øhould Pardon all men of what Estate ≈øoever all manner of Actions, and In≈øurrections committed, and all Trea≈øons, Felonies, Tran≈øgre≈ø≈øions, and Extortions by any of them done, and to grant them Peace.
3. That all men henceforth might be infranchi≈øed, or made free, to buy and ≈øell in every County, City, Burrough, Town, Fair, Market and other Places within the Realm of England.
4. That no Acre of Land holden in Bondage or Service, ≈øhould be holden but for four pence, and if it had been held for le≈øs in former time, it ≈øhould not now be inhanced.

div.p: The≈øe and many other things they required telling the King, That he had been ill Governed to that day, but for the time forward, he must be otherwi≈øe governed. The King finding him≈øelf in danger, yeilded hereunto, and ≈øo de≈øiring a Truce, the E≈ø≈øex men returned home. Next day the King went to Westminster, to vi≈øit St. Edwards Shrine, and coming back by West≈ømithfield, he found the place full of Kenti≈øhmen, to whom he ≈øent word, That their Fellows the E≈ø≈øex men were gone home, and that if they de≈øired it he would grant them the ≈øame Conditions of Peace; But their Chief Captain named John, or as others ≈øay, Walter Hilliard, alias Tyler, being a cunning Fellow, an≈øwered, He de≈øired Peace, but upon his own Conditions; intending by fair words to have delayed the bu≈øine≈øs till the next day; for he de≈øigned that Night to have killed the King and the Nobility about him, and then to have p ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ndred the City, and burnt it.

But he was wonderfully di≈øappointed in his Pride, having refu≈øed Conditions of Peace which were ≈øent him in three ≈øeveral Charters three times. Upon which the King at la≈øt ≈øent Sir John Newton, not to Command, but to Intreat him to come and di≈øcour≈øe with him concerning what he demanded; among which one particular was, That Wat Tyler de≈øired a Commi≈ø≈øion to behead all Lawyers, E≈øcheators, and others what≈øoever that were learned in the Law, conceiving that afterward all would be managed according to the Humour of the Common People; And it is reported that the day before, putting his hand to his Lips he had ≈øaid, That before four days came to an end, all the Laws of England ≈øhould proceed from his mouth.

When Sir John Newton de≈øired Tyler to di≈øpatch him, he ≈øcornfully an≈øwered; If thou art ≈øo ha≈øty thou mayst go to thy Ma≈øter, for I will come when I plea≈øe. However Sir John Newton followed him ≈ølowly on Hor≈øeback, and by the way a Doublet-maker brought three≈øcore Doublets to the Commons, and demanded thirty Marks for them, but could have no Money; Upon which Wat Tyler told him, Friend be quiet, thou ≈øhalt be well paid before this day be ended, keep nigh me and I will be thy Creditor.

Wat Tyler then ≈øet Spurs to his Hor≈øe and rid up toward the King, coming ≈øo near that his Hor≈øe touched the Crouper of the Kings, to whom he ≈øaid, Sir King, ≈øee≈øt thou all yonder People? Yes truly (≈øaid the King), but why do≈øt thou ask? Becau≈øe (≈øaid Ty ‚Ä¢ er) they are all at my Command, and have ≈øworn their Truth and Faith to me, to do whatever I bid them. In good time (replyed the King) I believe it well. Then ≈øaid Tyler, Believe≈øt thou King, that the≈øe People, and as many more that are in London will depart from thee thus without having thy Letters? No (≈øaid the King) you ≈øhall have them, they are ready and ≈øhall be delivered to them all.

Wat Tyler ob≈øerving Sir John Newton to be near him bearing the Kings Sword, was offended, ≈øaying, Th ‚Ä¢ it became him better to be afoot in his pre≈øence; Th ‚Ä¢ Knight an≈øwered ≈øtoutly, That ≈øurely there was no ha ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ in it, ≈øince he him≈øelf was on Hor≈øeback. This ≈øo i ‚Ä¢ raged Wat, that he drew his Dagger, and offered „Äà‚óä„Äâ ≈øtrike the Knight, calling him Traytor, Sir John to ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ him he lied, and drew his Dagger likewi≈øe; Wat Tyl ‚Ä¢

But being per≈øwaded to u≈øe more Moderation, he in Revenge, fir≈øt cau≈øed the Lord Maior, Sheriffs, and many of the Principal Citizens to be committed to ≈øeveral Pri≈øons, the Lord Mayor to Wind≈øor Ca≈øtle, and others to other Places; and then ≈øeized the Liberties of the City into his hands declaring, that no Lord Mayor ≈øhould for the future be Elected any more, but that the King ≈øhould at his Plea≈øure appoint a Warden, or Governour over the City. Richard the II. was the only Son of a Renowned Father, Edward Sirnamed the Black Prince, who died before his Father, Edward III. and thereupon Richard, was by his Grandfather in his Life-time, declared to be his Heir and lawful Succe≈ø≈øor, and accordingly after his Death was Crowned King of England at We≈øtmin≈øter, July 16. 1377. While the King was in his Minority matters were carried indifferent well, but in the year 1387, King Richard begins to enter, as we may ≈øay, upon the Confines of his De≈øtiny; His Gracing of unde≈øerving Men, and Di≈øgracing of Men de≈øerving, if they were not the Cau≈øes, were at lea≈øt the occa≈øions of his own Di≈øgracing; He was now come to be of full Age to do all him≈øelf, which was indeed to be of full Age to undo him≈øelf, for the Errors of his younger years might be excu≈øed by inexperience, but the faults of the Age he was now of, admit of no Apology, nor defence; And to ha≈øten his de≈øtiny the ≈øooner, the Evil Coun≈øel which was formerly but whi≈øpered in his Ear, they now had the Confidence to give him aloud; For it was told him, That he was under Tuition no longer, and therefore not to be controlled as formerly he had been; That to be cro≈øt of his will by his Subjects, was to be their Subject; That he is no Soveraign, if he be not Ab≈øolute.

By the in≈øtigation of ≈øuch Coun≈øellors as the≈øe, the King in a Parliament then A≈ø≈øembled fell to expo≈øtulate with the Lords, asking them, What years they thought him to be of; who an≈øwering, That he was ≈øomewhat more than one and Twenty; Well then, (≈øaid he) I am out of your Ward≈øhip, and expect to enjoy my Kingdom as freely as you your ≈øelves at the like years enjoy your Patrimonies.
