that all his Goods were Confi≈øcate, and him≈øelf adjudged to dye if the King plea≈øed. Though others write, his Sentence was only to pay twenty Thou≈øand Marks as a Fine, and a Thou≈øand pound be≈øides yearly.

This Chancellor was Michael de la Pool a Merchants Son, who was lately made Earl of Suffolk and Lord Chancellor of England, who with Robert Vere Earl of Oxford and Marque≈øs of Dublin, and ≈øome others, were King Richards bo≈øom Favourites; And upon this Provocation given them, they pre≈øently ≈øtudy Revenge; And thereupon contrive, that the Duke of Glocester (the Kings Uncle) as Principal, and other Lords who cro≈ø≈øed the Kings Cour≈øes, ≈øhould be invited to a ≈øupper in London, and be there Murdered; In the Execution of which Plot, the late Lord Mayor, Sir Nicholas Brember, was deeply concerned, but the pre≈øent Lord Mayor, Richard Exton, though moved thereto by the King him≈øelf, utterly refu≈øed to do it, and thereupon this De≈øign mi≈øcarried.

But notwith≈øtanding the≈øe heats, and many more, which pa≈ø≈øed in this Parliament, yet a Sub≈øidy was at la≈øt granted to the King of half a Tenth, and half a Fifteenth, but with this expre≈øs Condition, that it ≈øhould not be paid out, but by order from the Lords, and the Earl of Arundel was to receive it; But before this time, it was ab≈øolutely agreed between both Hou≈øes of Parliament, That unle≈øs the Chancellor were removed they would proceed no further;

The King having notice hereof, ≈øent a Me≈ø≈øage to the Hou≈øe of Commons that they ≈øhould ≈øend to Eltham, where he then lay, Forty of their Hou≈øe, to declare their Minds to him; But upon a Conference between both Hou≈øes, it was agreed, That the Duke of Glocester, and Thomas Arundel Bi≈øhop of Ely ≈øhould in the name of the Parliament go to him; who coming to the King, declared. That by an old Statute the King once a year might lawfully ≈øummon his Court of Parliament for Reformation of all Enormities and Corruptions within
the Realm; and further declared, That by an Old Ordinance it was likewi≈øe Enacted, That if the King ≈øhould ab≈øent him≈øelf Forty days not being ≈øick, the Hou≈øes might lawfully break up, and return home; At which it is reported the King ≈øhould ≈øay, Well, we perceive our People go about to ri≈øe against us, and therefore we think we cannot do better, then to ask aid of our Cou≈øen the King of France, and rather ≈øubmit our ≈øelves to him, than to our own Subjects.

To which the Lords an≈øwered, They wondred at his Maje≈øties Opinion, ≈øince the French King was the Ancient Enemy of the Kingdom, and he might remember what mi≈øchiefs were brought upon the Realm in King Johns time by ≈øuch Cour≈øes. By the≈øe and the like per≈øwa≈øions the King was induced to come to his Parliament, wherein John Fordham, Bi≈øhop of Durham is di≈øcharged of his Office of Trea≈øurer, and Michael de la Pool of being Chancellor, and others by con≈øent of Parliament put in their places; Likewi≈øe by Order of Parliament, thirteen Lords were appointed under the King to have over≈øight of the whole Government of the Realm, that is the Bi≈øhop of Ely Lord Chancellor; Bi≈øhop of Hereford Lord Trea≈øurer, the Abbot of Waltham Lord Privy Seal, the Archbi≈øhops of Canterbury and York, the Dukes of York, and Glocester, with others; but this divi≈øion of the Government was ≈øoon found inconvenient; This Parliament al≈øo granted to Robert de Vere (lately created Duke of Ireland) thirty Thou≈øand Marks (which the Frenchmen were to give to the heirs of Charles de Bloys) upon Condition that before Ea≈øter following he ≈øhould go over into Ireland; So de≈øirous were the Lords, and Commons to have him removed from the Kings pre≈øence.

But though the King gave way to this Torrent of the Parliament at pre≈øent, yet as ≈øoon as they were Di≈ø≈øolved, he di≈ø≈øolved likewi≈øe all they had done again≈øt his Favourites, and received them into more Favour than before. A while after the Duke of Ireland
puts away his lawful Wife who was neer a Kin to the Duke of Gloce≈øter, and married one of the Queens Maids a Vintners Daughter, at which the Duke of Glocester was very much offended; which the Duke of Ireland under≈øtanding ≈øtudied how by any means he might di≈øpatch the Duke of Glocester; and Ea≈øter being now pa≈øt which was the time appointed for the Duke to go into Ireland, the King pretending to go with him to the Sea≈øide, went with him unto Wales, being attended likewi≈øe with Michael de la Pool, Robert Tre≈øillian a prime Favourite, who was Lord Chief Ju≈øtice, and divers others, where they con≈øulted how to di≈øpatch the Duke of Gloce≈øter, the Earls of Arundel, Warwick, Darby, Nottingham, with divers others of that Party.

The King having remained ≈øome time in tho≈øe Parts had quite forgotten the Voyage of the Duke of Ireland, and ≈øo brought him back with him again to Nottingham Ca≈øtle. About the ≈øame time Robert Tre≈øillian Lord Chief Ju≈øtice came to Coventry, and there Indicted two Thou≈øand Per≈øons; The King then called all the High Sheriffs of the Counties before him, and demanded what ≈øtrength they could make for him again≈øt the Lords, if there ≈øhould be occa≈øion; To which they returned an≈øwer, That the Common People did ≈øo favour the Lords, as believing them to be Loyal and true to the King, that it was not in their power to rai≈øe any great force against them; They were then commanded to take care, That no Knights nor Burge≈ø≈øes ≈øhould afterward he cho≈øen to any Parliament, but tho≈øe whom the King and his Council ≈øhould name; They replyed, It was a hard matter in tho≈øe times of Jealou≈øy and ≈øu≈øpition, to deprive the People of their Ancient Liberties in choo≈øing their Repre≈øentatives; after which they were di≈ømi≈ø≈øed.

And ≈øome of the Judges of the Realm being called, that is Robert Tre≈øillian Lord Chief Ju≈øtice of the Kings Ben ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ , Robert Belknap, Chief Ju≈øtice of the Commonpleas,
John Holt, Roger Fulthorpe, and William Borough Knights, and Judges, men learned chiefly in one point, that is, without con≈øidering Truth or Fal≈øhood to plea≈øe tho≈øe in high Place; The≈øe were charged upon their Allegiance to give True and full An≈øwers to the following Que≈øtions.

list.item: I. Whether the Statute and Commi≈ø≈øion in the last Parliament, (that is again≈øt Michael de la Pool) were against the Kings Prerogative or not. To which they all an≈øwered, It was.

II. How they were to be puni≈øhed who procured that Statute, &c. or who moved, or compelled the King to con≈øent thereunto. They Unanimou≈øly an≈øwered, They ought to be put to death as Traytors unle≈øs the King would plea≈øe to pardon them.

III. When a Parliament is A≈ø≈øembled, and the Cau≈øe of their Meeting declared, and common Articles limited by the King upon which the Lords, and Commons in that Parliament ≈øhould proceed, if the Lords and Commons will go upon other Articles, and not the≈øe appointed by the King, till the King hath first an≈øwered their de≈øires, though injoyned by the King to the contrary, whether the King in this Ca≈øe ought not to command the Parliament, and oblige them to do his plea≈øure before they proceed further; They an≈øwered, That in this Ca≈øe, the King ≈øhould over-rule, and if any pre≈øumed to do contrary, he was to be puni≈øhed as a Traytor.

IV. Whether the King may at his plea≈øure di≈ø≈øolve the Parliament, and Command the Lords, and Commons to depart? They an≈øwered, That the King at his Plea≈øure may di≈ø≈øolve the Parliament, and whoever ≈øhall after proceed against the Kings Mind as in a Parliament, he is worthy to be puni≈øhed as a Traytor.

V. Since the King may at his plea≈øure remove any of his Officers and Justices, and puni≈øh them for their Offences,
whether may the Lords, and Commons without the Kings Will, accu≈øe them in Parliament, They replied, They cannot, and who≈øoever doth the contrary de≈øerveth to be puni≈øhed as a Traytor.

VI. What puni≈øhment they de≈øerve who moved in Parliament that the Statute whereby. K. Edward of Carnarvan was depo≈øed in Parliament ≈øhould be produced, whereby a new Statute ≈øhould be made, It was an≈øwered, That as well he that moved it as he that brought the Statute into the Hou≈øe were to be puni≈øhed as Traytors.

La≈øtly, Whether the Judgment given in Parliament against Michael de la Pool were erroneous and revocable, They an≈øwered, It was Erroneous and Revocable, and that if the Judgment were now to be given the Justices would not give the ≈øame.

div.p:
At this time the Londoners incurred much obloquy, for having before been pardoned by the King of ≈øome Crimes lay'd to their Charge, they were now ready to comply with his de≈øires, and a Jury of them being Impanneled, they indicted ≈øome Lords of many crimes laid to their Charge; And now the King, and the Duke of Ireland ≈øent into all parts of the Realm to rai≈øe men in this Quarrel again≈øt the Lords; And required the Mayor of London to give an Account how many able men he could rai≈øe in the City, who an≈øwered, That he thought they could make fifty Thou≈øand men at an hours warning; Well, ≈øaid the King, go and try what may be done, But when the Mayor went about it, the Citizens an≈øwered, That they would never fight against the Kings Friends, and the Defenders of the Realm; About this time the King intended to have apprehended the Duke of Glocester, but he made his e≈øcape, and with other Lords had got together a great power of men at Harringey Park; Upon which the King commanded that no Citizen of London ≈øhould ≈øell to the D. of Glocester, the E. of Arundel, or any of the Lords any
Armour or Furniture of War under a great penalty.

After this the King is per≈øwaded to ≈øend to the Lords to come to him to We≈øtmin≈øter, upon Oath given by the Arch-bi≈øhop of Canterbury and the Chancellor that no fraud nor evil practice ≈øhould be u≈øed again≈øt them, which the Lords were content to do, but when they were ready to come, they under≈øtood there was an Ambu≈øh laid to intrap them of a Thou≈øand men in the Mews; which the King ab≈øolutely denied he had any knowledge of; yet the Lords after this receiving a ≈øafe Conduct from the King, came to We≈øtmin≈øter, of who≈øe coming when the King heard, he apparelled him≈øelf in his Royal Robes, and with his Scepter in his hand came into the Great Hall, before whom the Lords upon their Knees pre≈øented them≈øelves, the King bidding them welcome, and taking each of them by the hand.

Then the Lord Chancellor made a Speech wherein he blamed them for rai≈øing Arms, de≈øiring to know the Cau≈øe; who an≈øwered, They had done it for the good of the Kingdom, and to remove the Traytors about the King; Upon which the King him≈øelf ≈øpoke and asked them whether they thought to compel him by ≈øtrong hand? Have not I (≈øaith he) ≈øufficient power to beat you down? truly in this behalf, I make no more account of you than of the ba≈øe≈øt Skullion in my Kitchen. Yet after the≈øe great words, he lift up the Duke of Gloce≈øter who all this while was kneeling, and commanded the re≈øt al≈øo to ri≈øe, and then led them Courteou≈øly to his Chamber, where they ≈øate and drank together, and at la≈øt it was concluded they ≈øhould all meet again, as well the≈øe Lords, as tho≈øe they accu≈øed at the next Parliament, which the King promi≈øed he would ≈øpeedily call, and each party to receive there according to Ju≈øtice, and in the mean while all Parties ≈øhould be under the Kings Protection.

But when the Favourite Lords heard this, they told the King plainly they neither dur≈øt nor would put
them≈øelves to the hazard of ≈øuch a Meeting, and therefore the Duke of Ireland, and the re≈øt of that Faction left the Court to be out of the way; but the King not enduring their ab≈øence appointed Thomas Molineux, Con≈øtable of the Ca≈øtle of Che≈øter to rai≈øe an Army, and to ≈øafe conduct the Duke of Ireland to his pre≈øence; But they being come as far as Radcoat Bridge, were encountred by the Earl of Derby, and the Duke of Ireland not daring to joyn battel with him fled, and being to pa≈øs a River, ca≈øt away his Gauntlets and ≈øword to be more nimble, and ≈øpurring his Hor≈øe lept into the River and ≈øo e≈øcaped; though it was reported he was drowned, till news came he was got into Holland, where being no welcome Gue≈øt he wandred up and down two or three years, like a Fugitive, and at Lorain in Brabant ended his life.

By this time the Lords had got matter enough again≈øt the King, at lea≈øt to ju≈øtifie their Arms, and thereupon with an Army of Forty thou≈øand men they came to London, where after ≈øome debate, they were received, and ≈øome of them went to the Tower to the King, to whom after humble Salutations, they ≈øhewed the Letter which he had written to the Duke of Ireland to levy an Army for their de≈øtruction; likewi≈øe the Letters which the French King had written to him, containing a ≈øafe Conduct for him to come into France, there to do Acts to his own di≈øhonour, and the Kingdoms.

After which upon the Kings Promi≈øe that he would come the next day to We≈øtmin≈øter to treat further of the≈øe matters, the Lords departed, only at the Kings de≈øire the Earls of Nottingham and Derby ≈øtayed all Night, but before the King went to bed, his Mind was quite altered as to keeping promi≈øe with the Lords, which they under≈øtanding, ≈øent peremptorily to him, That if be came not according to his Word, they would chu≈øe another King who ≈øhould hearken to the faithful Coun≈øel of his Lords. This touched the King to the quick,
≈øo that the next morning he went & met them, & they declared to him how much it concerned the good of the Kingdom that tho≈øe Traitors ≈øo often ≈øpoken of, ≈øhould be removed from the Court; To which the King, though much again≈øt his Will, at la≈øt conde≈øcended, and thereupon the Archbi≈øhop of York, and the Bi≈øhop of Chiche≈øter fled no man knew whether; the Bi≈øhop of Durham Lord Trea≈øurer, Lord Zouch, Lord Burrel, Lord Beumont and others were expelled the Court, and con≈øtrained to put in Bail to appear the next Parliament; Al≈øo cer ‚Ä¢ ain Ladies were expelled the Court, as the Lady Poynings, the Lady Mouling and others; Several other Knights with three of the Kings Chaplains, and the Dean of his Chappel, were likewi≈øe committed to Pri≈øon.

Shortly after the Parliament began, called afterward the Parliament that wrought wonders; On the fir≈øt day whereof, all the Judges but one, were arre≈øted as they ≈øate upon the Bench, and ≈øent to the Tower, and ≈øeveral Lords and Bi≈øhops were impeached; But the Lord Chief Ju≈øtice Tre≈øillian having made his e≈øcape, was afterward taken and hanged at Tyburn; Sir Nicholas Brember was Beheaded with an Axe which he had prepared for the beheading of others, after this divers Lords and Knights, and among the re≈øt the Steward of the Kings Hou≈øehold, were Beheaded on Tower-hill. Al≈øo all the Judges were condemned to dye, but by the Queens Interce≈ø≈øion, they were only bani≈øhed the Realm, and all their Lands and E≈øtates Confi≈øcated, only a ≈ømall Sallery was allowed them for their ≈øupport. Finally, in this Parliament an Oath was required, and obtained of the King, that he would perform ≈øuch things as the Lords ≈øhould Order, and this Oath was likewi≈øe required of all the People of the Kingdom.

After this the Duke of Gloce≈øter and ≈øome other Lords upon di≈øcontent, con≈øpire to ≈øeize upon the King, the Dukes of Lanca≈øter
„Äà‚óä„Äâ
York, and commit
them to Pri≈øon, and all the other Lords of the Kings Council they determined ≈øhould be drawn, and hanged, but the King having notice thereof, by a Wile he ≈øeizeth upon the Duke of Glocester, and ≈øends him pre≈øently to Callice, where he ≈øoon after lo≈øt his life, being ≈ømothered with Pillows as ≈øome write, and divers other Lords are committed to the Tower, and ≈øoon after the Earl of Arundel is beheaded on Towerhill; and a Parliament being called, the King brought it ≈øo about, that he obtained the whole Power of the Parliament to be conferred upon certain Per≈øons, or to any ≈øeven or eight of them, and the≈øe by virtue of this Grant proceeded to conclude upon many things which concerned the whole Parliament to the great prejudice of the State, and a dangerous Example in time to come. A General Pardon was al≈øo granted for all the Kings Subjects but only to Fifty; who≈øe names he would not Expre≈øs, but re≈øerved them to him≈øelf, that when any of the Nobility offended him, he might at his Plea≈øure name him to be one of the number excepted, and ≈øo keep them ≈øtill within his danger. Al≈øo in this Parliament the Judges gave their Opinious, That when Articles are propounded by the King to be handled in Parliament, if other Articles be handled before tho≈øe be first determined, that it is Trea≈øon in them that do it. And for the more ≈øtrengthning the Acts of this Parliament the King purcha≈øed the Popes Bulls, containing grievous Cen≈øures, and Cur≈øes to tho≈øe that ≈øhould break them.

And now the Heads of the Oppo≈øite Faction having lo≈øt their Heads, and all things as well ≈øetled as could be de≈øired, the King was ≈øecure as thinking him≈øelf ≈øafe, and he had been indeed ≈øafe, if Time and Fortune were not Actors in Revenge as well as men, or rather if a Superiour Power did not interpo≈øe, who≈øe ways are as ≈øecret as him≈øelf is invincible. About this time it happened that Thomas Mowbray Duke of Norfolk and Henry Duke of Hereford, accu≈øed each other for
≈øpeaking words ≈øounding highly to the Kings di≈øhonour, whereupon a Combate is agreed upon between them, which being ready to be begun, the King interpo≈øeth, and bani≈øheth the Duke of Norfolk for ever, and the D of Hereford for ≈øix years; But ≈øoon after ≈øeveral di≈øcontented Lords ≈øollicite the D. of Hereford to return into England, & take the Government upon him, & they would be ready to a≈ø≈øi≈øt him; who thereupon without much deliberation prepares to come over, and landing at Raven≈øpur in York≈øhire, where many Lords, Gentlemen, and Common people repaired to him, to whom he ≈øolemnly prote≈øts, That though ≈øome of them had invited him to come to take the Government, yet he came only to take po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the Inheritance de≈øcended to him from his Father, which King Richard unju≈øtly and contrary to his promi≈øe had ≈øeized into his hands.

Hereupon many more Lords join with him, and all the Kings Ca≈øtles are ≈øurrendred to him, and the Lord Scroop Trea≈øurer of England, Sir Henry Bu≈øhy and Sir Henry Green being ≈øeized, were condemned, and beheaded, for Mi≈øgoverning the King, and the Realm. King Richard was at that time in Ireland bu≈øie in ≈øuppre≈ø≈øing the Rebels, and had no notice of the Dukes Arrival in England till ≈øix weeks after; but hearing of it, he ≈øends the Earl of Salisbury before to rai≈øe an Army, and promi≈øeth to come him≈øelf within ≈øix days; the Earl provides an Army of Forty Thou≈øand men, but when the King came not at his time, they all di≈øbanded and went away; The King coming over, and finding how it was, fell into de≈øpair, and ≈øecretly the next night gets into Conway Ca≈øtle.

The Duke of Hereford, (now Duke of Lanca≈øter by his Fathers Death) ≈øends the Earl of Northumberland to the King, that if his Grace would undertake there ≈øhould be a Parliament called, wherein Ju≈øtice might be done, and him≈øelf pardoned all Offences, he would be ready to come to him on his knees, and as an humble Subject to obey him; Yet upon this Conference
with the Earl ≈øome ≈øay, the King required only, that him≈øelf and eight more whom he would name, might have honourable allowance, with a≈ø≈øurance of a private quiet Life, and that then he would re≈øign his Crown, and that upon the Earls Oath that this ≈øhould be performed the King agreed to go with the Earl to meet the Duke, but after four miles riding coming to the place where they had laid an Ambu≈øh, the King was ≈øeized, and carried Pri≈øoner to Flint Ca≈øtle, where the Duke of Lanca≈øter came to him, and bowing the knee thrice came toward him, whom the King took by the hand, and lifted up, ≈øaying, Dear Cou≈øin you are welcome, the Duke humbly thanking him ≈øaid, My Soveraign Lord, and King, the Cau≈øe of my coming at this pre≈øent is (your honour ≈øaved) to have re≈øtitution of my Per≈øon, my Lands and Heritage; whereto the King an≈øwered, Dear Cou≈øin, I am ready to accompli≈øh your Will, ≈øo that you enjoy all that is yours without exception.

After this coming out of the Ca≈øtle, the King called for Wine and then mounted on Hor≈øeback, and by ea≈øie Journeys came to London, and the next day he was committed to the Tower. As the King was carried toward London, divers Citizens con≈øpired to lye in wait by the way, and ≈øuddenly ≈ølay him, partly for private Grievances, and partly for the Severity, he had u≈øed toward the whole City; But the Maior having notice thereof, prevented it, and rid forth with a Con≈øiderable Company to conduct him ≈øafely to the Tower, and ≈øoon after a Parliament was called by the Duke of Lanca≈øter, but in the name of King Richard, where many heinous points of Mi≈øgovernment were laid to his Charge, and were drawn up into three and thirty Articles, the Cheif whereof were.

Th ‚Ä¢ t be had wa≈øtefully ≈øpent the Trea≈øure of the Realm upon unworthy Per≈øons, whereby great Taxes were laid upon the People; That he had borrowed great ≈øums of Money, and given his Letters Patents to repay the ≈øame, and yet not one peny ever paid. That he had taxed men at the
plea≈øure of him≈øelf and his unhappy Council, and had ≈øpent the money in folly and not in paying poor men for their victual and viand. That he ≈øaid the Laws of the Realm were in his Head, and Breast, by rea≈øon of which phanta≈øtical Opinion he de≈øtroyed Noblemen and Impoveri≈øhed the Commons; That he mo≈øt Tyranou≈øly, and unprincely ≈øaid, that the Lives and Goods of all his Subjects were in his hands and at his di≈øpo≈øition; That when divers Lords as well ≈øpiritual, as Temporal were appointed by Parliament to Treat of matters concerning the good of the Kingdom, while they are bu≈øie therein, he and others of his Party, went about to impeach them of Trea≈øon; and that the King cau≈øed all the Rolls and Records to be kept from them contrary to his promi≈øe made in Parliament, and to his open di≈øhonour. That he had private Spies in every place, and if any di≈øcour≈øed of his La≈øcivious living, or his Illegal Actings, he pre≈øently apprehended them, and grievou≈øly fined them. That he changed Knights and Burge≈ø≈øes of Parliament at his Plea≈øure, putting out divers Per≈øons, and placing others in their Room to ≈øerve his Will and Appetite. That when divers Lords and Justices were ≈øworn to ≈øpeak the truth in many things which concerned the honour and profit of the Realm; the King ≈øo threatned them that they durst not ≈øpeak what was right. That by force and threats he compelled the Judges of the Realm to conde≈øcend to him, for de≈øtruction of divers of the Lords. That he cau≈øed his Fathers own Brother, the Duke of Gloce≈øter without Law to be Attached, and ≈øent to Callice, and there without Cau≈øe to be ≈øecretly Murdered. That contrary to the Great Charter of England he cau≈øed ≈øeveral lusty young men to Challenge divers old men, upon matters determinable at Common Law in the Court Martial where Tryal is only by battel, which old men fearing ≈øubmitted them≈øelves to his mercy, whom he fined unrea≈øonably at his plea≈øure. That in all his Leagues with Forreign Princes, his way of Writing was ≈øo ≈øubtill and dark that no other Prince, nor his own Subjects could beleive or trust him; That he craftily
devi≈øed certain private Oaths contrary to Law, cau≈øing ≈øeveral to ≈øwear the ≈øame to the utter undoing of many honest men. That he a≈ø≈øembled certain Lanca≈øhire and Che≈øhire-men to make War upon the Lords, and ≈øuffered them to rob and ≈øpoil without prohibition; That notwithstanding his pardon granted them, he inforced divers of tho≈øe who joined with the Lords to be again Intollerably fined to their utter undoing.

Upon the≈øe and ≈øome other Articles which were read it was demanded of the Nobility and the Commons, what they judged both of the Truth and de≈øert of the≈øe Articles, who all agreed that the Crimes were Notorious, and King Richard was worthy for the ≈øame to be depo≈øed from all Princely Honour and Kingly Government. The Duke of York who a little before had been Governour of the Realm for the King, and directed him much, thought it be≈øt, that King Richard ≈øhould both Voluntarily Re≈øign, and al≈øo be Solemnly depo≈øed by con≈øent of all the States of the Realm, for Re≈øignation only would be imputed to fear, and deprivation to force; and therefore this being concluded on, there came Thomas Archbi≈øhop of Canterbury, the Archbi≈øhop of York, the Bi≈øhop of Hereford, the Duke of Lancaster, and ≈øeveral other Lords and Abbots to King Richard in the Tower of London.

When all were ≈øet in their places, King Richard was brought forth apparelled in his Royal Robes, the Crown on his head and the Scepter in his hand, and was placed among them in a Chair of State; Never was Prince ≈øo Gorgeous with le≈øs Glory, and greater Grief, to whom it was not di≈øgrace ≈øufficient to lo≈øe both the honour and Ornaments of a King, but he mu≈øt openly do even in great ≈øcorn renounce the one, and deliver up the other. After a little Pau≈øe and expectation, the King ro≈øe from his Seat, and ≈øpake to the A≈ø≈øembly the≈øe words, or to this effect;

I a≈ø≈øure my ≈øelf that ≈øome at this pre≈øent, and many hereafter will account my Ca≈øe lamentable, either that I have de≈øerved this Dejection if it be ju≈øt, or if it be wrongful, that I could not avoid it; Indeed I do confe≈øs, that many times I have ≈øhewed my ≈øelf both le≈øs Provident, and le≈øs painful for the benefit of the Commonwealth than I ≈øhould, or might, or intended to do hereafter; and have in my Actions more re≈øpected the ≈øatisfying of my own particular humour than either Ju≈øtice to ≈øome private per≈øons, or the Common Good of all, yet I did not at any time omit duty, or Commit Grievance upon natural dulne≈øs, or ≈øet malice, but partly by abu≈øe of Corrupt Councellors, partly by Error of my Youthful Judgment, and now the remembrance of the≈øe over≈øights is not more unplea≈øant to any man than my ≈øelf, and the rather, becau≈øe I have no means left either to recompence the injuries which I have done, or to te≈øtifie to the World my reformed Affections, which experience, and stayedne≈øs of years had already corrected, and would daily have framed to more perfection.

But whether all the Imputations wherewith I am charged be True, either in Sub≈øtance, or in ≈øuch Quality as they are laid, or whether being True, they are ≈øo heinous as to force the≈øe Extremities, or whether any other Prince, e≈øpecially in the heat of Youth, and in the ≈øpace of twenty two years, the time of my unfortunate Reign, doth not ≈øometimes either for advantage, or upon di≈øplea≈øure in as deep manner grieve ≈øome particular Subject, I will not now examine; It helpeth not to u≈øe any Defence, neither is it to any purpo≈øe to complain, there is left no room for the one, nor pity for the other, and therefore I refer it to the Judgment of God, and your le≈øs di≈øtempered Con≈øiderations.

I accu≈øe no man, I blame no Fortune, I complain of nothing, I have no plea≈øure in ≈øuch vain, and needle≈øs comforts, if I had minded to have ≈øtood upon Terms, I know I have Great Favourers abroad, and I hope ≈øome Friends at home, who would have been ready, yea very forward on my behalf to have begun a bloody and doubtful War, but I e≈øteem not my Dignity at ≈øo high a Rate, or Value, as to
venture the lo≈øs of ≈øo much Engli≈øh Bloud, and the wa≈øting and de≈øolation of ≈øuch a flouri≈øhing Kingdom as this might have occa≈øioned; Therefore that the Common-wealth may rather ri≈øe by my fall, than I stand by the ruin thereof, I willingly yeild to your de≈øires, and am here come to di≈øpo≈ø≈øe≈øs my ≈øelf of all publick Authority and Title, and to make it free, and lawful for you to create for your King Henry Duke of Lanca≈øter my Co≈øen German, whom I know to be as worthy to take that Place, as I ≈øee you willing to give it to him.

Then he read openly the form of his Re≈øignation, which di≈øcharged his Subjects from all Oathes and Fealty, &c. to which the King ≈øub≈øcribed, and was ≈øworn; After which he delivered with his own hands the Crown, the Scepter, and the Robe to the Duke of Lanca≈øter, wi≈øhing him more happine≈øs therewith than ever he enjoyed, de≈øiring him and the re≈øt to permit him to live ≈øafely in a private and ob≈øcure life, and not altogether forget he had been their King.

Upon October 13. following the Duke of Lancaster was Crowned King by the Name of Henry the Fourth, and King Richard was removed to Pomfret Ca≈øtle, but ≈øome of the Lords being di≈øcontented with Henry u≈øed many endeavours to re≈øtore Richard again, which cau≈øed great Wars, and Rebellions, and occa≈øioned ≈øuch Melancholy in King Henry, that ≈øitting one time at his Table, he ≈øighing ≈øaid, Have I no faithful Friend who will deliver me from him that will be my Death. This Speech was e≈øpecially noted by one Sir Piers of Exton who pre≈øently with eight Per≈øons in his Company, came to Pomfret, commanding the E≈øquire who was Ta≈øter to King Richard to be ≈øo no more, whereat the King marvelling, asked him the Rea≈øon; Sir, ≈øaid he, I am otherwi≈øe commanded by Sir Piers of Exton, who is newly come from King Henry, when King Richard heard that word he took the Carving-knife in his hand, and ≈øtrook the E≈øquire lightly on the head ≈øaying; The Devil take Henry of Lanca≈øter, and thee
together; and with that word Sir Piers entred the Chamber with eight armed men, every one having a Bill in his hand; King Richard perceiving this, put the Table from him, and ≈øtepping to the foremo≈øt man, wre≈øted the Bill out of his hands and ≈ølew four of tho≈øe that thus came to a≈ø≈øault him; Sir Piers lept to the Chair where King Richard u≈øed to ≈øit, whil≈øt the re≈øt cha≈øed him about the Chamber, at la≈øt being forced to the place where Sir Piers was, he with a ≈øtroak of his Pole-Ax upon his head felled him down, and ≈øo ended his mi≈øerable life. It is ≈øaid, that at the point of his death the King gathered ≈øome Spirit and with a faint and feeble voice groaned forth the≈øe words.

My Great Grandfnther King Edward the II. was in this manner depo≈øed, impri≈øoned and Murdered, by which means my Granfather King Edward the III. obtained the Crown, and now is the puni≈øhment of that injnry poured upon his next Succe≈ø≈øor; well, this may be ju≈øt for me to ≈øuffer, but not Right for you to do. Your King for a time may rejoyce at my Death, and enjoy his de≈øire, but let him qualifie his plea≈øures with Expectation of the ≈øame Ju≈øtice, for God who mea≈øureth all our Actions by the malice of our Minds will not ≈øuffer this to go unpuni≈øhed.

Sir Piers having thus ≈ølain the King, wept bitterly, and a great part of this prophetical Speech came to pa≈øs in a ≈øhort time after; King Richard thus dead his Body was imbalmed and covered with Lead all ≈øave his Face, and then brought to London where it lay in St. Pauls Church three days unburied, that all might ≈øee he was dead. And this was the end of this unfortunate Prince, in which there was a wonderful Concurrence of Fortune in behalf of King Henry, and again≈øt Richard, but when all is done, there is no re≈øi≈øting the Decree of Heaven, but ≈øince that is unknown to us, and perhaps but Conditional, we ≈øhall be manife≈øt Traytors to our ≈øelves if we u≈øe not our uttermo≈øt endeavours to divert
it; ≈øo that it may be truly ≈øaid Richard lo≈øt his Crown more by his own fault, than the Trea≈øon of any other. After this long diver≈øion let us now return to the Tower of London.

In 1458 there were Ju≈øts and Turnaments in the Tower; In 1478. The Duke of Clarence was drowned in a Butt of Malm≈øey within the Tower; Elizabeth Wife to King Henry 7. Dyed in the Tower in Childbed 1502. In the year 1512, the Chappel in the High White Tower was burnt; Queen Ann Bullein was beheaded in the Tower 1541, and a little after Katherine Howard both Wives to Henry the Eight. In the year 1546 a ≈øtrange accident happened in the Tower, for one Foxly who was Potmaker for the Mint, falling a ≈øleep could not be awakened by pinching, beating or burning, for fourteen days; at which time he awaked as fre≈øh as the fir≈øt day he began to ≈øleep.

In King Henry the Eights time, the Tower was often full of Pri≈øoners, and among others Sir Thomas More Lord Chancellor of England, who was kept clo≈øe Pri≈øoner, and at la≈øt they took from him all his Books, whereupon he ≈øhut up his Pri≈øon Windows, and lived in Darkne≈øs; and being asked the rea≈øon, he an≈øwered, it is time to ≈øhut up Shop when the Wares are all gone; At his fir≈øt entrance into the Tower, the Gentleman Porter demanded his Fee, which is the upper Garment, whereupon Sr. Thomas pulled off his Cap to give it him, but that not ≈øufficing, he pulled out an handfull of Angels, and gave him a good many, a Knight that was in his Company telling him, that he was glad to ≈øee him have ≈øo many Angels, Yes (an≈øwered he,) I love to carry my Friends always about me. Not long after the Lady Jane was beheaded there, and upon the Scaffold, ≈øhe made a mo≈øt ingenious Speech full of Pity, That ≈øhe came thither to ≈øerve for an Example to Po≈øterity, that Innocence cannot be any Protection against Greatne≈øs; and
that ≈øhe was come thither not for a≈øpiring to a Crown, but for refu≈øing one when it was offered her.

In King James his time, there was no Blood ≈øpilt in the Tower, or upon Towerhill, only Sir Gerva≈øe Elways was hanged there when he was Lieutenant about the Murder of Sir Thomas Overbury, and one remarkable pa≈ø≈øage there was in his Speech upon the Ladder, That being in the Low-Countreys, and much addicted to Gaming, he made a ≈øerious wi≈øh that if ever he played more above ≈øuch a ≈øum, he might be hanged, but he Violated the Oath, and ≈øo the just Judgment of Heaven fell upon him according to his words. The Earl of Castle haven in the year 1631, was brought from the Tower to be Executed for Horrid Crimes; and divers others ≈øince, have been Executed there, as the Earl of Strafford, Arch-Bi≈øhop Laud, and many more.

This ≈øtately Tower ≈øerves not only for a Goal to detain Pri≈øoners, but for many other u≈øes, it is a ≈øtrong Fort, or Citadel, which ≈øecures both City and River. It is the Trea≈øury of the Jewels and Ornaments of the Crown; It con≈øerves all the Old Records of the Courts of Ju≈øtice at We≈øtminster, it is the place for the Royal Mint, and the Coynage of Gold and Silver, it is the chief Magazine and Armory of the whole Land for Martial Engines and Provi≈øion, and there only is the Brahe or Rack, u≈øually called the Duke of Exeters Daughter, becau≈øe he was the fir≈øt Inventor of it, and La≈øtly it is a great Ornament, by the ≈øituation of it, both to the River and City.

This City hath had divers other Towns be≈øides; one at the North End of London-Bridge, which is now utterly demoli≈øhed, and the other at the South End, which hath ≈øuffered many Accidents of Fireing, and otherwi≈øe, and was ≈øtill repaired at the charge of the City. Upon this Gate the Heads of Traytors are commonly placed, and ≈øome there are thereon at this day. Hi≈øtorians mention two Ca≈øtles that were
built in the We≈øt part of the City, one called the Ca≈øtle of Montfiquet, built by a Lord of that name, which is now demoli≈øhed, and the Black Fryers ro≈øe up in≈øtead of it, the other called Baynards Ca≈øtle from one Baynard, who≈øe Family long enjoyed it, and after that Robert Fitz-Walter who was called Banner Bearer of the City of London, and had great Priviledges. This Ca≈øtle fell afterwards to the Earl of March, who was Crowned there by the Title of Edward the Fourth, to whom this City always ≈øtuck very clo≈øe, but in the Seventh Year of his Reign many of the greate≈øt men in London were accu≈øed of High Trea≈øon, and divers Aldermen, whereof they were acquitted, yet did they forfeit their Goods to the value of Forty Thou≈øand Marks, and among them Sr. Thomas Cook formerly Lord Mayor, without Hawkins were committed to the Tower, neither could be di≈øcharged without paying Eight Thou≈øand Marks to the King. Henry the Seventh repaired Baynards Ca≈øtle, and rid through the City in State with all the Knights of the Garter, from the Tower to St. Paul's Church, where they heard Ma≈øs, and Lodged that Night at Baynards Castle, Queen Mary was likewi≈øe proclaimed at Baynards Castle, though the Lady Jane had been proclaimed a little before.

There was al≈øo another Tower or Ca≈øtle near Baynards Ca≈øtle, but there is now no ≈øign of it remaining; And another in the place where Bridewell now ≈øtands, which being demoli≈øhed, yet there was a Royal Palace left where the Kings of England kept their Courts, and King John ≈øummoned a Parliament there; and afterwards Henry the Eight repaired it, and made it much more ≈øtately for the entertainment of his Nephew Charles the Fift Emperour, and King of Spain, who in the year 1522 was Magnificently Treated there.

There was another Tower called the Tower Royal, where King Stephen kept his Court; Barbican was
likewi≈øe another Tower; There was another called Sernes Tower in Bucklersbury, where we read Edward the III. kept his Court, and gave it afterward to his free Chappel of St. Stephens in We≈øtmin≈øter, now called Henry the ≈øevenths Chappel, who ≈øpent fourteen thou≈øand pound in building of it, and about the ≈øame time he built a Great Ship which co≈øt ju≈øt ≈øo much. Thus much for the Towers and Ca≈øtles of London.

div.head: CHAP. IV. The Rivers, Wells, Conduits, Ditches and Bridges, &c. in and about this City.
div.p: IN former times before William the Conquerour, and long after, the City was watered (be≈øides the famous River of Thames in the South) with the River of Wells, as it was then called; and in the We≈øt with a water called Walbrook, running through the mid≈øt of the City into the River of Thames; There was al≈øo another Water which ran within the City through Langbourn Ward, watering that part in the Ea≈øt; There were three Principal Fountains or Wells in the other Suburbs, that is Holywell, Clements Well, and Clarkes Well; and near to the la≈øt were divers other Wells; as Skinners Well, Fogs Well, Todewell, and Radwell, all which flowing into the River afore-mentioned, much increa≈øed the ≈øtream, and gave it the name of Wells.

It is recorded that in We≈øt-Smithfield there was a
Pool called Hor≈øe-pool, and another in the Pari≈øh of St. Giles; Be≈øides which they had in divers ≈øtreets and Lanes of the City fair Wells, and fre≈øh Springs, by which the City was ≈øerved with ≈øweet Water; and many Conduits were built in divers Streets, which continued till the dreadful Fire in 1666. Since which time for the Conveniency and enlargement of the Streets, and likewi≈øe by rea≈øon of the new River Water, contrived by Sir Hugh Middleton, mo≈øt of the≈øe Conduits are taken down, and removed.

For Queen Elizabeth having before granted to the Citizens of London by Act of Parliament Liberty for cutting and conveying a River from any part of Middle≈øex or Hertford≈øhire to the City of London with a limitation of Ten years time, her life ended before any would undertake it; whereupon the like Act was pa≈ø≈øed by King James, but without Date of time, and when all others refu≈øed it, Sir Hugh Middleton undertook to bring a River from Chadwell and Amwell, to the North≈øide of London near I≈ølington, where he built a large Ci≈øtern to receive it. This work was begun Feb. 20. 1608 and in the five years ≈øpace was fully accompli≈øhed, though with great difficulty by rea≈øon of the difference and unevenne≈øs of the Ground, the depth of the River in ≈øome places being Thirty Foot, and in other places the water is carryed through a Wooden Trough, and advanced above the Valley near Three and Twenty Foot.

When the Water was brought to the Ci≈øtern, but not as yet let in, upon Michaelmas Day 1613. in the afternoon, Sir Thomas Middleton brother to Sir Hugh, being that day Elected Lord Mayor for the year en≈øu≈øuing, he together with the pre≈øent Lord Mayor, Sir John Swinerton, Sir Thomas and Sir Henry Montague, the Recorder, with divers other Aldermen and Citizens rid to ≈øee the Ci≈øtern, and the Water fir≈øt i≈ø≈øuing therein; at which time a Troop of about. Three ≈øcore Labourers, well apparel'd, and wearing gree ‚Ä¢
Monmouth Caps all alike, Armed with Spades, Shovels, pick-axes, and ≈øuch In≈øtruments of Labour, marched twice or thrice round the Ci≈øtern, the Drums beating before them, and then pre≈øented them≈øelves before the Mount, where the Lord Mayor and Aldermen ≈øtood to behold them, and after one of them had made a hand≈øome Speech upon the occa≈øion, the Flood Gates flew open, and the ≈øtream ran chearfully into the Ci≈øtern, Drums and Trumpets ≈øounding all the while in a Triumphant manner, and a brave peal of Muskets concluded the entertainment.

But above all the City owns its Glory and Riches, and many other Ble≈ø≈øings to the excellent River of Thames, who≈øe head or fir≈øt ≈øtream i≈ø≈øueth out of the ≈øide of a Hill upon Cot≈øwold Downs, about a Mile from Tethury, near to Fo≈øs a High Road ≈øo called in former times, and was ≈øometimes named I≈øis or the Ou≈øe, from hence it runs to the Ea≈øt, as all good Rivers ≈øhould, though not without ≈øome turnings, and meets with the Cirne or Chiurn, a brook whereof Cirence≈øter which is near it, is ≈øuppo≈øed to take the name. From hence it ha≈øteth to Creeklade, Lechlade, Radcotbridge, Newbridge, and Eve≈øham, receiving by the way abundance of ≈ømall Streams, Brooks, and Rivulets; And on this ≈øide the Town devideth it ≈øelf into two Streams, the one goes directly to Hinckly and Botly, and the other to God≈øtow; this latter ≈øpreadeth it ≈øelf for a while into divers ≈ømall ≈øtreams, which run not far before they meet again; and then encompa≈ø≈øing divers Fruitful Meadows, it pa≈ø≈øeth at length by Oxford, which ≈øome imagine ≈øhould rather be called Ou≈øeford of this River, and there it meeteth with the River Charnel, a little from whence the Original Branches Join again, and keep Company to Abington, though no part of it did formerly come ≈øo near the Town as now it doth, till a branch thereof was led thither by the main ≈øtream, through the Indu≈øtry of the Monks, as al≈øo by the decay of Caerdoure,
now called Dorchester, ≈øometimes the high Road from from Wales and the We≈øt Countrey to London.

From thence it goeth to Dorchester, and ≈øo into Thame, where joining to a River of that name, it is called no more Ou≈øe but Thames; from thence it goeth to Wallingford and ≈øo to Reading, which was formerly called Pontium, becau≈øe of the number of Bridges. There it joins with the River Kenet, which comes from the Hills We≈øt of Marleborough, and ≈øoon after with the Thetis commonly called the Tyde which comes from Thetisford; It goes from thence to Sudlington, or Maidenhead, and ≈øo to Windle≈øtore or Wind≈øor, Eaton, Chert≈øey, Stanes, and there receiving another Stream by the way called Cole, where Colebrook ≈øtands, it proceeds to King≈øton, Richmond, Sheen, Sion, and Brentford, where it meets with another ≈øtream called the Brene coming from Edgworth; It runs then by Moreclack, Putney, Falham, Batter≈øey, Chel≈øey, Lambeth, We≈øtmin≈øter, and ≈øo to London.

And pa≈ø≈øing through the Bridge the fir≈øt water that fall into it is Brome, We≈øt of Greenwich, who≈øe ≈øpring comes from Bromley in Kent. The next is River on E≈ø≈øex ≈øide over again≈øt Woolwich which is called Lee, and falls into it; and a while after the River Derwent on Kent ≈øide falls therein, having its ri≈øe from Tunbridg; The next water that falls into the Thames is a Rivulet of no great note, We≈øt of the Wain I≈øles; La≈øt of all the River of Thames mingleth with the River Medway, which comes out of Kent by Rochester, Chatham, and divers other Places, and waters all the South parts of Kent.

This Noble River for its bredth, depth, gentle ≈øtreight even Cour≈øe, extraordinary whol≈øom Waters and Tides, is more commodious for Navigation than perhaps any other River in the World; The Sea flows gently up this River four≈øcore Miles, that is almo≈øt to King≈øton, twelve miles above London by Land, and twenty by Water, bringing the greater Ve≈ø≈øels to London,
and the ≈ømaller beyond, and then Boats are drawn to Oxford again≈øt the Stream, and many miles higher.

As oft as the Moon comes to the Northea≈øt, and Southwe≈øt Points of Heaven, it is high Water at the City, the one Point in our Hemi≈øphere, and the other in the other. The Highe≈øt Tides are upon a Landfloud, the Wind Northwe≈øt at the Equinoctial, and the Moon at full, when the≈øe four Cau≈øes concur, which is very rare, than the Thames overflows its Banks in ≈øome places, and Westmin≈øter is ≈øomewhat endamaged in their Cellars, but not in their upper Rooms; This River opening Ea≈øtward toward France and Germany is much more advantagious for Traffick then any other River in England; wherein there is contained variety of Excellent Fi≈øh, and on both ≈øides thereof lyes a Fruitful Fat Soyl, plea≈øant rich Meadows, and innumerable Stately Palaces. So that the Thames ≈øeems to be the radical Moi≈øture of the City and in ≈øome ≈øence the Natural heat too, for almo≈øt all the Fuel for Firing is brought up this River from Newca≈øtle, Scotland, Kent, E≈ø≈øex and other parts; From this River the City by water Engines is in many Places ≈øupplyed with excellent whol≈øome water, and al≈øo from almo≈øt twenty Conduits which are yet remaining of pure ≈øpring Water, as well as by the New River aforementioned of which River we ≈øhall add, That it comes from Amwell and Chadwell two Springs near Ware in Hertford≈øhire from whence in a turning and winding Cour≈øe it runs three≈øcore Miles, before it reaches I≈ølington; Over this River are made 800 Bridges, ≈øome of Stone, ≈øome of brick and ≈øome of Wood, 600 men were at once imployed in this Great work It is carried in Pipes of wood under gronnd into mo≈øt Streets of this City, and from thence with Pipes of Lead into Hou≈øes, it ≈øerves the highe≈øt parts of London in their lower Rooms, and the lower parts in their highe≈øt room. This City likewi≈øe is ≈øo Scituated,
that in all parts, though in the highe≈øt ground it is abundantly ≈øerved with Pump Water, and the≈øe Pumps in many places not ≈øix foot deep in the ground.

The va≈øt Traffick and Commerce whereby this City doth flouri≈øh may be gue≈ø≈øed at chiefly by the cu ‚Ä¢ io ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ s which are paid for all Merchandize Imported or Exported, which in the Port of London only, amounts to above Three Hundred Thou≈øand Pounds a Year; and by the va≈øt number of Ships, which by their Ma≈øts re≈øemble a Forre≈øt, as they lye along the ≈øtream, be≈øides many that are ≈øent forth every year to carry and fetch Commodities to, and from all parts of the known world, now for the pre≈øervation of the River Thames, there is a Court of con≈øervacy kept by the Lord Mayor and Aldermen of London, (under whom is a VVater Bayliff and other Officers,) they commonly fi≈øh eight times every year in the four Counties of Middle≈øx, Surrey, Kent and E≈ø≈øex, where they have power to Impanel Juries, and to make Inqui≈øition into, and puni≈øh all Offences committed upon the River within their Juri≈ødiction and Extent; which begins at a place called Colny Ditch, a little above Stanes-bridge We≈øtward; and from thence all along through London Bridge to a place called Yendal, alias Yenleet, and the waters of Medway near Chatham in Kent Ea≈øtward.

This River as we have ≈øay'd, is full of all ≈øorts of Excellent Fi≈øh, as ≈øweet Salmons after the time of the Smelt is pa≈øt, wherein no River in Europe exceeds it; It hath likewi≈øe ≈øtore of Barbels, Trouts, Chevins, Pearches, Smelts, Breams, Roches, Daces, Gudgeons, Flounders, Shrimps, Eels, &c. only it ≈øeems not to be ≈øo ≈øtored with Carps, except that by Land-Flonds, they are ≈øometimes brought out of Gentlemens Ponds; There are great numbers of Swans dayly ≈øeen upon this River, and above Two Thou≈øand Wherries and ≈ømall Boats, whereby Three
Thou≈øand poor Watermen are maintained, by carrying Goods and Pa≈ø≈øengers thereon, be≈øides tho≈øe large Tilt-boats, Tyde-boats and Barges, which either carry People, or bring Provi≈øion from all parts of the Counties of Oxford, Berks, Buchingham, Bedford, Hertford, Middle≈øex, E≈ø≈øex, Surry and Kent to the City of London,

To conclude this famous River of Thames, taking all her advantages together, ≈øurpa≈ø≈øeth all others that pay Tribute to the Ocean, if we con≈øider the ≈øtreightne≈øs of its cour≈øe, the ≈øtilne≈øs of its ≈øtreams, con≈øidering its bredth, as al≈øo its length, running above Nine≈øcore Miles before it comes into the Sea, and the conveniency of its ≈øituation being toward the middle of England; It hath likewi≈øe one peculiar property more, that the entrance into this River is ≈øafe, and ea≈øy to Engli≈øhmen, and Natives, but difficult and hazardous to Strangers, either to go in and out without a Pilot; in≈øomuch that in the whole, the Thames may be ≈øaid to be Londons be≈øt Friend, as may appear by a pa≈ø≈øage in the Reign of King James, who being di≈øplea≈øed with the City, becau≈øe they would not lend him a ≈øum of money which he required, and the Lord Mayor and Aldermen attending him one day, being ≈øomewhat tran≈øported with Anger, the King ≈øaid, He would remove his own Court, with all the Records of the Tower, and the Courts of We≈øtmin≈øter Hall to another place, with further expre≈ø≈øions of his Indignation. The Lord Mayor calmly heard all, and at la≈øt An≈øwered, Your Majesty hath power to do what you plea≈øe, and your City of London will obey accordingly, but ≈øhe humbly de≈øires that when your Majesty ≈øhall remove your Courts, you would plea≈øe to leave the River of Thames behind you, having been thus long upon the Water, 'tis now time to Land and take a view of the great and ≈øtupendious Bridge, which if the ≈øcituation and ≈øtructure thereof be well con≈øidered, may be ≈øaid to be one of the Wonders of the World; of
which an Ingenious Gentleman decea≈øed made this Poem;

q.l: When Neptune from his Billows London ≈øpy'd,
Brought proud'y thither by a High Spring Tyde;
As through a floating Wood he ≈øteer'd along,
When he beheld a mighty Bridge give Law,
Unto his Surges, and their Fury awe,
When ≈øuch a Shelf of Cataracts did roar,
As if the Thames with Nyle had chang'd her Shore;
When he ≈øuch Ma≈ø≈øy Walls, ≈øuch Towers did eye,
Such Po≈øts, ≈øuch Irons. on his back to lye;
When ≈øuch vast Arches he ob≈øerv'd that might,
Nineteen Rialto's make for depth and height,
When the Cerulean God the≈øe things ≈øurveyed,
He ≈øhook his Trident, and a≈øtoni≈øht ≈øaid;
Let the whole world now all her wonders count,
This Bridge of wonders is the Paramount.

div.p: At fir≈øt there was only a Ferry kept where the Bridge now is, and the Ferry-man and his Wife dying, left it to their only Daughter a Maiden named Mary, who with the profits thereof, and money left her by her Parents, built a Hou≈øe for Nuns in the place where the Ea≈øt part of St. Mary Overies Church now ≈øtands, above the Quire where ≈øhe was buried; and unto tho≈øe Nuns ≈øhe bequeathed the benefit, and over≈øight of the Ferry, but that being afterwards turned to a Hou≈øe of Prie≈øts, they built a Bridge of Timber, which they kept in good repair, till at length con≈øidering the va≈øt charge thereof by the contribution of the Citizens and others, a Bridge was built of Stone.

Several Accidents have happened concerning this Bridge, of which we ≈øhall mention ≈øome hereafter in the Reign of the ≈øeveral Kings. In the fir≈øt year of King Stephen a Fire began near London-≈øtone, and burnt
≈øtands in the Quire wher of ≈øhe was buried; to tho≈øe Nuns ≈øhe bequeathed the benefit, and over≈øight of the Ferry, but that being afterwards turned to a Hou≈øe of Prie≈øts, they built a bridge of Timber, which they kept in good repair, till at length con≈øidering the va≈øt charge thereof by the contribution of the Citizens and others, a Bridge was built of Stone.

Several Accidents have happened to this Bridge. In the fir≈øt year of King Stephen a Fire began near London Stone, and burnt Ea≈øt to Algate, and We≈øt to St. Paul's Church; the Bridge of Timber upon the Thames was al≈øo burnt, but afterward repaired. In 1163 it was rebuilt all of new Timber, by Peter of Cole-Church a Prie≈øt, which ≈øhews, that there was a Timber Bridge 215 years before the Bridge of Stone was erected, which was maintained partly by Gifts, and partly by Taxes in every Shire. In 1176 the Foundation of the Stone-Bridge was laid by the afore≈øaid Peter near the place of the Timber-Bridge, but ≈øomewhat more to the We≈øt; for we read that Buttolph's Wharf was at the end of London-Bridge; the King a≈ø≈øi≈øted in the work; to perform which, the cour≈øe of the River Thames was turned another way about, by a Trench ca≈øt up for that purpo≈øe, beginning in the Ea≈øt about Rotherhith, and ending in the We≈øt at Batter≈øea.

This Bridge with the Arches Chappel, &c. was 33 years in building, and fini≈øhed in 1209 by the worthy Citizens, W. Serle Mercer W. Alman, & Senedict Botecorite, who were Over≈øeers of it, for Peter of Cole-Church died four years before, and as he principal Benefactor being buried in the Chappel on London-Bridge, a Ma≈øon who was Ma≈øter-workman of the Bridge, built this large Chappel from the Foundation, at his own Charge, was which endowed for two Prie≈øts, and four Clerks; after the fini≈øhing the Chapel, which was the fir≈øt building on tho≈øe Arches,
divers Man≈øion Hou≈øes were erected, and many Lands, Tenements, and ≈øums of Money were given toward the maintenance of the Bridge, all which were ‚Ä¢ ormerly regi≈øtred in a Table for Po≈øterity, and bung up in the Chappel, till it was turned into a dwelling Hou≈øe, and was then removed to the Bridge-hou≈øe; and it's recorded that all the Revenues belonging to to London-Bridge in King Henry VII time, amounted to 8 15 l. 17 s. 2d. a year, by which we may partly gue≈øs at the Incomes of this Bridge, and what va≈øt increa≈øe is made of it by this time.

But this noble Bridge like other earthly things hath ≈øuffered many di≈øa≈øters ≈øince, for ≈øome years after the fini≈øhing thereof, that is, 1212. on the 10th. of July at Night the Burrough of Southwark and St. Mary Overies Church being on fire, and a multitude of People pa≈ø≈øing the Bridge, either to quench or gaze upon it, on a ≈øudden the North part of it, by the blowing of the South wind, was ≈øet on fire, and when the People would have returned, they were ≈øtopped by the Fire, and as they ≈øtayed in a con≈øternation the South end of the Bridge ≈øell on fire, ≈øo that the People thronging between two raging Fires expected pre≈øent death, whereupon there came many Boats and Ve≈ø≈øels to ≈øave them, into which the multitude ru≈øhed ≈øo unadvi≈øedly, that the boats being thereby ≈øunk, they were all drowned; above Three thou≈øand Per≈øons being de≈øtroyed by the Fire and Water, part of who≈øe Bodies were found half burned, be≈øides tho≈øe burnt to A≈øhes, which could not be found.

In 1282. after a great Fro≈øt and deep Snow, five Arches of London-Bridge were carried away. In 1289. the Bridge was ≈øo much decayed that People were afraid to go over it, but by a ≈øub≈øidy granted it was repaired. In 1595. on St. George's Day there was a great Ju≈øting on London-Bridge, between David Earl of Crawford of Scotland. and the Lord Wells of
England, which ≈øhews that the Bridge was then only coaped in, but not built with Hou≈øes as it is now. The next year Novem. 30. the young Queen I≈øabel Wife to Richard II. commonly called the little Queen, for ≈øhe was but 8 years old, was brought from Kenington over the Bridge to the Tower of London, & ≈øuch a mu ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ itude of People went upon the Bridge to ≈øee her, that nine Per≈øons were crouded to death, among the re≈øt the P ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ or of Tiptree in E≈ø≈øex, and an ancient Matron in Cornhill. In 1633 there happened a great Fire on London Bridge, but was again repaired. In the dreadful Fire 1666 a great part of the North Buildings of the Bridge were burnt down, but are wholly rebuilt with much Advantage.

To conclude, this Bridge for admirable Workman≈øhip, va≈øtne≈øs of Foundation, and Dimen≈øions, and for ≈øtately Hou≈øes, and rich Shops built thereon, ≈øurpa≈ø≈øeth all others in Europe; it hath nineteen Arches founded in a deep River, made of ≈øquare Stone, ≈øixty Foot in height, and Thirty in breadth, di≈øtant 20 foot one from another, joined together with Vaults and Cellars, and built as ≈øome ≈øay upon Ozy ≈øoft ground, being Eight hundred Foot in length and 30 foot broad, and a Draw-bridge almo≈øt in the middle, Be≈øides this noble Bridge there are others belong to the City, as three ≈øtately Bridges of Stone built ≈øince 1666 over Fleet Ditch, and al≈øo Holborn Bridge, the Ditch being enlarged, clean≈øed, and fenced of each ≈øide with Stone and Rails, and Store-Hou≈øes for Coals on each ≈øide; it is likewi≈øe freed from Hou≈øes for twenty Foot on each ≈øide, and made exceeding hand≈øome, to the great charge of this City, there were likewi≈øe ≈øome ≈ømall Bridges over the Town Ditch, but now it is arched over with Brick, and doth no where appear, being paved even with the Street.

div.head: CHAP. V. The Government of the City of London.
div.p: THE Civil Government of this City is not as it is in Rome, Paris, Madrid, Vienna, and other Cities, by a chief Magi≈øtrate, or ≈øome noble Man ≈øet over it, as it was here in the time of the Romans, when the chief Magi≈øtrate was called the Prefect of London, or in the time of the Saxons, when he was called the Portrieve, Cu≈øtos or Guardian, and ≈øometimes Provo≈øt of London, but after the coming in of the Normans the cheif Magi≈øtrate was called Bailive from the French, or Commi≈ø≈øarie, one that hath a Commi≈ø≈øion to govern, and there were ≈øometimes two Bailiffs of London, till Rich. I. 1189. changed the name of Bailiff into Mayor, which hath held ever ≈øince.

The Mayor is a Citizen cho≈øen every year by the Citizens, evcept when their Priviledges and Franchi≈øes have been taken from them, as in the time of Henry III. Edward I. and King Charles II. The Mayor, tho' always a Citizen or Trade≈øman, hath been of ≈øuch high repute, that in writing and ≈øpeaking to him the Title of Lord is prefixt, as to Noble Men, Bi≈øhops or Judges, and of late to the Mayor of York, or ≈øome of the highe≈øt Officers of the Realm; he is likewi≈øe u≈øually Knighted; his Table, (and al≈øo the two Sheriffs is open to all that are of any Quality, but ≈øo well furni≈øhed that it is always fit to receive the greate≈øt Subject in England; nay it is recorded that a Lord Mayor of London fea≈øted four Kings at once at his Table.

His Officers are eight of them E≈øquires by their places, that is, the Sword-bearer, the Common Hunt, (who keeps a Kennel of Hounds for the Lord Mayor's Recreation) the Common Cryer, and four Water-Bailiffs; there is al≈øo the Coroner, three Sergeants
Carvers, three Serjeants of the Chamber, a Serjeant of the Channel, four Yeomen of the Water-≈øide, one Under Bailiff, two Yeomen of the Chamber, three Meal Weighers, two Yeomen of the Wood Wharfs, mo≈øt of which have their Servants allowed them, and Liveries for them≈øelves.

The State of the Lord Mayor appears when he goes abroad, which is u≈øually on Hor≈øeback, with rich Capari≈øons, him≈øelf always in long Robes either of Scarlet richly ≈øurred. People or Puke with a Chain of Gold about his Neck, many Officers walking before, and on all ≈øides of him; but e≈øp ‚Ä¢ cially on the 29th of October, when he goes „Äà‚óä„Äâ
We≈øtmin≈øter in his Barge, with the Aldermen, attended by all his Officers, and the Liverymen of the ≈øeveral Companies, in their ≈øtately Barges with their Arms, Colours and Streamers; and having in the Exchequer Chamber before the Judges, taken his Oath to be true to the King and Government, he returns in like manner to Guildhall, that is, the Great Hall of Guilds, o ‚Ä¢ Incorporated Confraternities, where is prepared a ≈øumptuous Dinner, & the Kings, Queens, Noblemen, and Per≈øons of Honour have of late years been plea≈øed to dine there with him; with the Forreign Amba≈ø≈øadors and all the Judges.

This great Magi≈øtrate upon the Death of the King is ≈øaid to be the Prime Per≈øon in England, and therefore when King James was invited to come and take the Crown of England, Robert Loe then Lord Mayor of London, ≈øub≈øcribed in the fir≈øt place, before the great Officers of the Crown and the Nobility; he is u≈øually cho≈øen on Michaelmas day out of 26 Aldermen, all Wealthy Men. His Authority reaches over all this great City, part of the Suburbs, and likewi≈øe to the River of Thames, with power to puni≈øh all that annoy the Stream, Banks or Fi≈øh; only the ≈øafety of the River again≈øt an Inva≈øion, and ≈øecuring Merchandizing, and Navigation by Block-Hou≈øes, Forts or „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ

There are divers Courts of Judicature belonging to the Lord Mayor and City of London; the highe≈øt and mo≈øt ancient Court is called the Hu≈øtings, which pre≈øerves the Laws, Rights, Franchi≈øes and Cu≈øtoms of the City. There is a Court of Reque≈øts or Con≈øcience; the Court of the Lord Mayor and Aldermen, where al≈øo the Recorder and Sheriffs ≈øit; two Courts of the Sheriffs, one for each Counter; the Court of the City Orphans, whereof the Lord Mayor and Aldermen have the Care. The Court of Common-Council con≈øi≈øting (as the Parliament of England) of two Hou≈øes one of the Lord Mayor and Aldermen, and the other of Commoners, but they fit all together. In which Court are made all B.-Laws, which bind all the Citizens of London, for every man either by him≈øelf or by his Repre≈øentative gives his a≈ø≈øent thereto, wherein con≈øi≈øts the happine≈øs of the Engli≈øh above all other Sub ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ cts in the world, that neither in Laws, By Laws, Taxes nor Impo≈øts, no man is obliged to pay any thing but by his own con≈øent. There is another Court of the Chamberlain of the City, to whom belong the Receipts of the Rents, and Revenues thereof, and likewi≈øe the Inrolling and making Free Apprentices, over whom he hath great Authority. Al≈øo the Courts of Coroner, and E≈øcheator, and another Court for the con≈øervation of the River of Thames; la≈øtly, the Court of Goal Delivery at Newgate, held u≈øually, eight times a ‚Ä¢ ear at the Old Baily both for the City and Middle≈øex, for the Trial of Criminals, whereof the Lord May or is cheif Judge. There are other Courts called Wardmote or the meeting of Wards, whereof there are 26 in the whole City, every Alderman having a ≈øeveral Ward. In this Court Inquiry is made into all things that conduce to the Regulating and well Governing of the City. Al≈øo the Court of Hallmote or A≈ø≈øembly of every Guild and Fraternity, for Regulating what belongs to every company in particular. There are
two Sheriff belonging to this City, which like the Lord Mayor are only for a year and are elected generally upon Mid≈øummerday. The name is thought to be Saxon from Shire, or Country, and Rive Governour. His Office is to ≈øerve the King's Writs of Attachment, to return indifferent Juries, to ≈øee that the publick Peace be kept and that condemned Per≈øons be executed, &c. Newgate, Ludgate, and the two Counters are put into the Cu≈øtody of the Sheriffs.

For the Eccle≈øia≈øtical Government, there is a Bi≈øhop, and the pre≈øent is Dr. Henry Compton; and to the Cathedral of St, Paul's, belongs a Dean, a Chapter, a Trea≈øurer and „Äà‚óä„Äâ Prehends. A Rector or Vicar is placed in every Pari≈øh for the Cure of S ‚Ä¢ uls, and there is in mo≈øt Pari≈øhes a Par≈øonage or Vicarage-Hou≈øe for the Mini≈øter, and a Competent Allowance of Tithes.
