div.head: CHAP. VII. The Wards and Precincts of the City of London.
div.p: THE General Divi≈øion of the Wards of this City ≈øince their purcha≈øing the Liberties of Southwark in the County of Surrey, con≈øi≈øts of twenty ≈øix parts, which have twenty ≈øix Aldermen to govern them; the names of which are as follow.

1. Tower≈øtreet Ward, ≈øo called from the Tower of London; it contains Sydon, or Seething lane, part of Mark-lane, Mincing lane, and Beer lane, in which is Bakers-Hal; two Lanes called Church-lanes, and next to them Fowl lane, the Church of St. Dun≈øtans in the Ea≈øt, & the Cu≈øtom-hou≈øe where are paid all the Impo≈øitions laid on Merchand ≈øes, imported or exported; which is ≈øo con≈øiderable, that all the Cu≈øtoms of England, being divided into three parts, the Port of London pays two Thirds, that is, above 330000 Pound yearly. This Hou≈øe being de≈øtroyed by the Fire, 1666, is now rebuilt in a more magnificen: Uniform and commodius Manner, by the King, and co≈øt 10000 l. the building. In this Ward are, the Tower of London, two Halls of Companies, the Clothworkers, and the Bakers. It hath an Alderman, a Deputy. 11 Common Council Men, and 3 Pari≈øh Churches, Alhallows Barking, St. Olave Hart≈øtreet, and St. Dun≈øtans in the Ea≈øt; the la≈øt of which, with great part of the Ward was burnt down by the Fire, but is lately rebuilt, and an Organ placed therein; It hath 13 Con≈øtables, 12 Scavengers, 13 of the Wardmote Inque≈øt, and a Beadle.

2. Port≈øoaken Ward, contains the Ea≈øt part of the Tower, the Ho≈øpital of St. Katharines, Ea≈øt-Smithfield and Tower-hill, where there is a Store-hou≈øe for Provi≈øions for the Navy Royal, called the Slaughter Hou≈øe; the Merchant Taylors have in this Ward Alms-hou≈øes for 14 Women; next is the Minories,
then Hog-lane near Goodmans Fields, and ends at Petticoat-lane. This Ward hath an Aldermen and his Deputy, ≈øix Common Council Men, two Pari≈øh Churches, Trinity Minories and St. Buttolphs Aldgate; 4 Con≈øtables; 4 Scavengers; 18 of the Wardmote Inque≈øt, and a Beadle.

3. Aldgate Ward, ≈øo named from the Gate; the chief Street begins between the Gate and Lime≈øtreet, and goes again to Billeter-Lane, and Fenchurch-Street, to Culver Alley, from thence to Crutched Friers, Woodroof-Lane, Hart-Street, and the North end of Mark-Lane where the Ward endeth. Wherein there are 3 Pari≈øh Churches, St. Katharine-Cree-Church, St. Andrew ∆≤nder≈øhaft, and St. Katharine Coleman; and there were 3 Halls of Companies, that is, Bricklayers, Fletchers, and Ironmongers Hall. It hath an Alderman, Deputy, and ≈øix Common Council Men, 6 Con≈øtables 9 Scavengers, Wardmote Inque≈øt 18, and a Beadle.

4. Lime-Street Ward, bath no Pari≈øh Church in it, nor any one whole Pari≈øh, but ≈ømall Portions only of two Par≈øhes; it hath an Alderman, his Deputy, and four Common Council Men, 4 Con≈øtables, 2 Scavengers, Wardmote Inque≈øt Men 16, and a Berdle.

5. Bi≈øhop≈øgate Ward, part of which is without the Gate from St. Mary Spittle to Bi≈øhop≈øgate, and almo≈øt half Houn≈øditch, & Old Bethlem Ea≈øt of the New Po≈øtern to Morefields; in this Ward is Fi≈øhers Folly (now called Devon≈øhire Hou≈øe, and lately made into a ≈øquare with ≈øtately Buildings) the Old Artillery Ground, Spittle Fields, now built into Streets; and the Church of St. Buttolphs Pi≈øhopsgate-gate: within the Gate it contains Bi≈øhopsgate Street, to the Ea≈øt end of St. Martins Outwich Church, and then winding by Leadenhall down Leaden Hall Street, Great St. Hellens, and Little St. Hellens. In this Ward there was Bethlem now removed to Morefields, St. Mauy Spittle, where Sermons were formerly
preached Monday, Tue≈øday and Wedne≈øday in Ea≈øter week yearly. Al≈øo the Church of St. Buttelphs B≈øhop≈øgate, the ≈ømall Church of St. Ethelborough, and the fair Church of St. Helen; near this Church a Child was found buried in the Sea-coal A≈øhes by his unnatural Mother, with his Face upward, yet found alive, without any ragg about it, but all bloody becau≈øe the Navel ≈øtring was untied, and the body cru≈øted over with Sea-coal Dur≈øt, yet being made clean, it was found to be a hand≈øome Manchild, without any harm, but only by ≈øucking in the A≈øhes; he was Chri≈øtned and named Job Cinere Extractus, Job taken out of the A≈øhes; he lived three days, and lies buried in that Church-yard. This Ward hath an Alderman and two Deputies, one within, and another without the Gate, eight Common Council Men within, and three without the Gate, ≈øeven Con≈øtables, ≈øeven Scavengers, 13 Wardmote Inque≈øt Men and a Beadle

6. Broad≈øtreet Ward, ≈øo called from the Street, wherein is Throgmorton-Street, Threadneedle-Street, half Finch-Lane and an Alley; and to the Ea≈øt end of St. Margaret Lothbury, and to a Pump formerly again≈øt St. Bennet Fink's Church. In this Ward is part of Gre≈øham Colledge, and eight Alms-hou≈øes; the Church of St. Peters Poor in Broad≈øtreet, Augu≈øtine Friers, now the Dutch Church, the Church of St. Martins Outwich, St. Bennet Fink, St. Bartholomew, Exchange, and St. Chri≈øtophers Pari≈øh; al≈øo Carpenters Hall, Drapers Hall, and Merchant Taylors Hall. Then there was St. Anthonies Colledge or Ho≈øpital, which is now a Church for French Calvini≈øts; Scalding Ally is the farthe≈øt part of this Ward; wherin there is an Alderman, his Deputy and nine Common Council Men, ten Con≈øtables, eight Scavengers; of the Ward note Inque≈øt thirteen, and a Beadle.

7. Cornhil Ward, ≈øo called from a Corn-Market, anciently kept there; It's chief Ornament is the
Royal Exchange formerly called the Bur≈øe, which was erected in 1566 and burnt down 100 years after, in 1666. It was built by Sir Thomas Gre≈øham a noble Merchant, and by Command of Q. Eliz. proclaimed and named the Royal-Exchange. The Merchants before met in Lumbarddreet; after the Fire, it was rebuilt mo≈øt part with Stone, with ≈øuch curious Architecture, e≈øpecially the Front, Turret, and Archwork, that it ≈øurpa≈ø≈øeth all other Bur≈øes. It is Quadrangular, with a large Court, wherein the Merchants may a≈ø≈øemble, and the greate≈øt part in ca≈øe of Rain, or Sun≈øhine, may be ≈øheltred in ≈øide Porti co's; the whole Fabrick co≈øt above 50000 Pound, one half paid by the Chamber of London, and the other by the Company of Mercers. There are 160 Shops above, let at 20 l. Rent each, and 30 l. Fine, and ≈øeveral Shops below on every ≈øide, and large Vaults underneath which yield con≈øiderable Rents, ≈øo that it is the riche≈øt piece of ground perhaps in the World, the ground whereon this goodly Fabrick is erected, being but 171 foot from North to South, and 203 foot from Ea≈øt to We≈øt, very little more than three quatters of an Acre, and products 4000 Pound yearly Rent. Cornhill Ward begins at the We≈øt end of Leadenhall, and ≈øo down to Finch-lane on one ≈øide, and Birchin lane on the other; half of which are in this Ward, and ≈øo to the Stocks-Market. In this Ward is the Church of St. Peters Cornhill, counted the olde≈øt in London, and the Church of St. Michael; both which with the greate≈øt part of this Ward, were burnt down, but are ≈øince nobly rebuilt, as well as the re≈øt of the Streets; St. Michael's Church had ten Bells formerly, and John Stow writes thus, I have heard my Father ≈øay, ≈øaith he, that upon St. James's night, certain Men ringing the Bells in the Loft, a Tempe≈øt of Thunder and Lightning did ari≈øe, and a thing of an ugly Shape was ≈øeen to come in at the South Window, which lighted on
the North, for fear whereof all the Ringers ≈øell down as dead for a time, letting the Bells cea≈øe of their own accord; when they came to them≈øelves, they found certain Stones of the North Window razed and ≈øcratcht as if they had been ≈øo much Butter printed with a Lions Claw; the ≈øame Stones were fa≈øtened there again when it was repaired, and remain ≈øo to this day; He adds, That one VVilliam Rus or Rous, gave a Bell to this Church to be rung nightly at 8 a Clock, and for Knels, and Peals, which was rung by one Man for 160 years together, In this Ward there is an Alderman, his Deputy and five Common Council Men; four Con≈øtables, four Scavengers; Wardmote Inque≈øt ≈øixteen, and a Beadle.

8. Langbourn VVard, ≈øo called, of a long Bourn of Water running out of Fenchurch-≈øtreet, down to the end of St. Mary VVoolnoth Church in Lumbard ≈øtreet, & then dividing into ≈ømall Streams, it left the name of Sherebourn-lane. In this Ward is Fenchurch ≈øtreet, Lumbard-≈øtreet, half Lime-≈øtreet, half Birchin-lane, St. Clements-Lane down to St. Clements-Church, St. Nicholas-Lane beyond St. Nicholas-Church, Abchurch-Lane, and part of Bearbinder-Lane. Formerly St. Gabriel's Church ≈øtood in the middle of Fenchurch-≈øtreet, but was taken away ≈øince the Fire; likewi≈øe St. Dionis Backchurch, Alhallows Lumbard-≈øtreet, St. Edmund Lumbard-≈øtreet, St. Nicholas Acons, and St. Mary VVoolnoth Church. In it are ≈øix Pari≈øh Churches, and Pewterers Hall in Lime-≈øtreet; there is an Alderman, his Deputy and nine Commoa Council Men; 15 Con≈øtables, 9 Scavengers, Wardmote Inque≈øt 17, and a Beadle in this Ward. The Po≈øt-Office is kept in Sir Robert Vyners Hou≈øe in this Ward; mo≈øt of which was burnt down and all the Churches, but ≈øince rebuilt.

9. Billing≈øgate VVard, contains part of Thame≈øtreet, Rood land, Puding lane, Love lane, Buttolph lane,
St. Margaret Fattons lane, Billing≈øgate, Somers Key, Smarts Key, Bo≈øs Alley, St. Mary Hill-lane; likewife five Charches, St. Buttolph Billing≈øgate, St. Mary Hill, St. Margaret Pattons, St. Andrew Hubbert, and Saint George Buttolphs Lane. This Ward was all burnt in 1666, but now rebuilt, with mo≈øt of the Churches; There is an Alderman, his Deputy, and nine Common Council Men; 11 Con≈øtables, 6 Scavengers, Wardmote Inque≈øt 14 and a Beadle.

10. Bridge-Ward within (≈øo called from London Bridge) begins at the South end, and comes over the Bridge up Fi≈øh-≈øtreet hill to the North corner of Grace-Church. In which were 4 Churches, St. Magnus at the Bridge-Foot, St. Margaret new Fi≈øh-≈øtreet, St. Leonard Ea≈øtcheap, and St. Bennet Grace Church; all the≈øe Churches, and all the Ward except part of London-Bridge was burnt down; two of which are rebuilt, but upon the place where St. Margaret's Church ≈øtood, there is erected by Act of Parliament, a Pillar in perpetual Memory of the dreadful Fire in 1666, which fir≈øt began in Pudding-Lane behind that Church. This Monument is built after the Dorick Order, 170 foot high, all of ≈øolid Portland Stone with a Stairca≈øe in the middle of Stone, coped with Iron, with an Iron Balcony on the Top, not unlike tho≈øe two ancient white Pillars at Rome, erected in honour of tho≈øe two Excellent Emperors, Trajan and Antoninus, which though they were built above 1500 years ago, are ≈øtill ≈øtanding entire; the Pede≈øtal of this Pillar is 43 foot ≈øquare. In the Bridge VVard are an Alderman, his Deputy, and 14 Common Council Men, 15 Con≈øtables, 6 Scavengers, Wardmote Inque≈øt 16, and a Beadle.

11. Candlewick VVard, begins at the Ea≈øt end of Great Ea≈øtcheap, & pa≈ø≈øeth We≈øt thro little Ea≈øtcheap, into Cannon-≈øtreet, & ≈øo to the North end thereof, & thence to the We≈øt end of St. Laurence Pountneys Church-yard; part of St. Clements-Lane, mo≈øt part
of St. Nicholas-Lane, almo≈øt all Abchurch-Lane, and mo≈øt part of St. Martins-Lane are in this Ward. It was wholly burnt down in 1666, but hand≈øomely rebuilt. There were in this Ward 5 Churches, that is, St. Clements-Ea≈øtcheap, St. Mary Abchurch, St. Michael Crooked-Lane (where was the Monument of Sir VVilliam VValworth Lord Mayor, who killed VVat Tyler) St. Martins Orgars and St. Laurence Poultney, which were all burnt down, the three ≈øir≈øt are rebuilt, and St. Martins is now a French Church. This Ward hath an Alderman, his Deputy, and 7 Common Council Men, 8 Con≈øtables, 5 Scavengers, Wardmote Inque≈øt 12 and a Beadle.

12, VValbrook VVard, begins at the We≈øt end of Canon-≈øtreet by Budge-row, where is St. Swithins lane, VValbrook, the Stocks-Market, four or five Hou≈øes in Lumbard-≈øtreet, Bearbinder lane, and part of Bucklersbury. This Ward was wholly de≈øtroyed by the Fire, and ≈øix Churches, that is, St. Swithins in Canon-≈øtreet, St. Mary VVoolchurch, St. Stephens VVallbrook, St. John Evangeli≈øt, and St. Mary Bothaw; St. Swithins, and St. Stephens VValbrook are hand≈øomely rebuilt, but St. Mary VVoolchurch, the Church-yard, and Stocks-Market are pulled down, and made a hand≈øome Market place; in the Front whereof toward the Street is a Conduit, and a Statue of King Charles II, on Hor≈øeback, with a Turk or Enemy under his Feet; erected by Sir Robert Vyner, This Ward hath an Alderman, his Deputy, and 7 Common Council Men, 9. Con≈øtables ≈øix Scavengers, Wardmote Inque≈øt 15 and a Beadle. In this Ward is Salters Hall.

13. Dowgate VVard begins at the South end of VValbrook VVard, over again≈øt the Ea≈øt corner of St. John Bapti≈øt's Church, and goes on both ≈øides the way to Dowgate, wherein there were Elbow-lane, Chequer-Alley, Fryer-lane, Grantham-lane, the Stilyard, Church-lane, Alhollows-lane, Cole-Harbour, Ebgate-lane, Bu≈øh-lane; and Suffolk-lane. This Ward was wholly
con≈øumed by the Fire, and three Churches. Alhallows the Great, Alhollows the Le≈øs, and St. Laurence-Poultney, the fir≈øt of which is again rebuilt. In this Ward were five Halls, Skinners, Dyers, Tallow-Chandlers, Innholders, and Joyners, and likewi≈øe Merchanr-Taylors School. It hath an Alderman, his Deputy, and 5 Common Council Men, 8 Con≈øtables, 5 Scavengers, Wardmote Inque≈øt 14, and a Beadle,

14. Vintrey VVard, ≈øtretcheth from the Vintrey North to Tower. Royal, in which were Stodies-lane, Cranes lane, Church-lane, and divers others. This Ward was con≈øumed by the Fire, and four Churches, St. Michael-Royal, St. Thomas-Apo≈øtles, St. Martins Vintrey, and St. James Garlick-Hithe; the fir≈øt only is rebuilt. This Ward hath an Alderman, his Deputy, and 6 Common-Council Men, 9 Con≈øtables 4 Scavengers, Wardmote Inque≈øt 14, and a Beadle. In which were 5 Halls, Vintners, Cutlers, Fruiterers, Plummers, and Pari≈øh-Clerks.

15. Cordwayners VVard, wherein there were Budge-Row, Turnba≈øe-lane, part of VVingmen-lane, Cordwayner-≈øtreet, Bow-lane, Ba≈øing-lane, and St. Syths lane, the South end of Needlers-lane, the South end of Soperlane, part of Bow-lane, and VVatling-≈øtreet. This Ward was burnt down, and three Churches, St. Antholines, Aldermary Church, and St Mary le Bow, all rebuilt with magnificent Steeples, This Ward hath an Alderman, his Deputy 8 Common Council Men, 8 Con≈øtables, 8 Scavengers, Wardmote Inque≈øt 14, and a Beadle.

16. Cheap≈øide VVard, wherein is the Poultrey, and the Counter, Cony-hoop lane, part of the Old-Jury, Bucklers-bury, Neelders-lane, part of Soper-lane, now called Queen≈øtreet, Ironmonger-lane, and Cateaten-≈øtreet. This Ward was con≈øumed by the Fire, and 7 Churches, St. Mildred-Poultrey, St. Mary Cole-Church, St. Bennet-Sherehog, St. Pancras Soper-lane, St. Martins Ironmongers-lane, St. Laurence-Jury, and Guildhall-Chappel,
≈øome are ≈øince finely rebuilt, as well as the Hall and the re≈øt of the Ward. It hath an Alderman, Deputy, and 11 Common Cou ‚Ä¢ cil Men, 11 Con≈øtables, 9 Scavengers, Wardmote Inque≈øt 12, a Beadle, and Grocers and Mercers Hall.

17. Coleman-≈øtreet VVard, wherein is part of the Old-Jury, Lothbury, Coleman-≈øtreet. and the Alleys thereabout; it was in part con≈øumed by the Fire, with three Churches, St. Margaret's Lothbury St. Stephens Coleman-≈øtreet, and St. Olaves Jury, all rebuilt, with the re≈øt of the Ward; It hath two Halls, Armourers and Founders, an Alderman, his Deputy, 5 Common Council Men, 4 Con≈øtables, 4 Scavengers, VVardmote Inque≈øt 13, and a Beadle.

18. Ba≈ø≈øi≈øhaw, or Ba≈øing-hall VVard, wherein are Ba≈øing hall ≈øtreet, part of London VVall and ≈øeveral other Alleys; mo≈øt of it was burnt down 1666, and therein Ba≈øing-hall, and St. Michael Ba≈ø≈øi≈øhaw Church, with Coopers, Ma≈øons, VVeavers, and Girdlers Hall. There are an Alderman, his Deputy, and 4 Common Council Men, 2 Con≈øtables, 2 Scavengers, Wardmote Inque≈øt 17 and a Beadle.

19 Cripplegate VVard, hath the≈øe Streets, Aldermanbary, Milk-≈øtreet, Gay≈øpur lane, part of VVe≈øtcheap, Love-lane,, Lad-lane, VVood-≈øtreet, Addle-street, Philip-lane, Huggen-lane, Maiden-lane, the Ea≈øt end of Guthorn-lane, Staining lane, Silver-≈øtreet, the North end of Mugwel-≈øtreet, all within the walls; without are More-lane, with all the Alleys, little Morefields, more than half Grub-≈øtreet, VVhite Cro≈øs ≈øtreet, to
‚Ä¢ eech-lane, Red Cro≈øs-≈øtreet, part of Golden-lane, and Barbican, more than half toward Alder≈øgate, Sim Colledge, in which is a ≈øtately Library, and Alms-Hou≈øes for 24 People founded by Dr. Thomas VVhite. Part of this Ward was con≈øumed by the Fire, and among the re≈øt Aldermanbury Church, St. Maudlin Milk-≈øtreet, St. Albans VVood-≈øtreet, St. Michael VVood-≈øtreet, but St. Alphage, and Cripplegate e≈øcaped; In this VVard were Bowyers and Scriveners Hall. It is of
‚Ä¢ great extent, divided into Cripplegate within and without; within it hath an Alderman, his Deputy, and 8 Common Council Men, 9 Con≈øtables, 12 Scavengers, VVardmote Inque≈øt 15, and a Beadle; without the Gate a Deputy, and three Common Council Men, 4 Con≈øtables, 4 Scavengers, VVardmote Inque≈øt 17, and a Beadle.

20. Alder≈øgate VVard, contains Lillipot-lane, the we≈øt ≈øide of Guthorns-lane, Cary-lane, St. Martins, Alder≈øgate-≈øtreet without the Gate, and Little-Brittain; ≈øome part of this VVard was burnt, and the Churches of St. John Zachary, St. Olave Silver ≈øtreet, St. Ann Alder≈øgate, and St. Mary Staining; but St. Buttolphs without the Gate e≈øcaped. There are in this VVard, Peter-hou≈øe, no ‚Ä¢ the Seat of the Lord Bi≈øhop of London, Thanet-Hou≈øe, and Gold≈ømiths Hall. It hath an Alderman, his Deputy, 4 Common Council Men, without the Gate, and 4 within, 8. Con≈øtables, 9 Scavengers, VVardmote Inque≈øt 14, and a Beadle.

21. Farringdon VVard, within contains Fo≈øter-lane, Mugwelwell-≈øtreet, Pentecost-lane, Butcherhall-lane, the we≈øt ≈øide of Fryday-≈øtreet, the Old-Change, the north Church-yard of St. Paul's, St. Paul's-School, Pater-No≈øter-Row, the we≈øt ≈øide of Avemary-lane, Greed-lane, Black-Fryers, Pannier-Alley, Ivy lane, Blow Bladder≈øtreet, Newgate Market, and Newgate-≈øtreet. mo≈øt of it was burnt in 1666. and the Churches of St. Peters Cheap at VVood-≈øtreet Corner, St. Fo≈øters in Fo≈øterlane, Chri≈øt Church and Ho≈øpital, St. Mathews Friday-≈øtreet, St. Au≈øtins in VVatling-≈øtreet, St. Martins Ludgate, St. Ann Black-Fryers, St. Faiths under St. Pauls, and St. Pauls Church it ≈øelf. St. Pauls is the only Cathedral of that Name in Chri≈øtendom, ≈øeated on the-highe≈øt part of all the City, and was more per≈øpicuous perhaps than any Cathedral in the VVorld It was a ≈øtructure for length, height, and antiquity, ≈øurpa≈ø≈øing all other Churches, the length thereof was 670 Foot, (therein exceeding by 20 Foot, St. Peters
Church in Rome, which for Beauty, Proportion, and divers other things excells all other Temples.) It was in height 102 Foot, and in breadth 130. This Church was built (as other Cathedrals) in a perfect Cro≈øs, and in the mid≈øt of the Cro≈øs upon mighty high Arches, was a Tower, or Steeple of Stone, 360 foot high, and on that a Spire of Timber, covered with Lead in height 260 foot more; in all from the ground 520 foot, above which was a Bole of Copper gilt of 9 foot in compa≈øs, whereon ≈øtood the Cro≈øs 15 foot and an half high, and almo≈øt 6 foot a-cro≈øs, made of Oak, covered with Lead, and another cover of Copper over the Lead; above all ≈øtood the Eagle or Cock of Copper gilt, 4 foot long, and the breadth over the wings 3 foot and an half. In 1561, part of this magnificent Pile was much wa≈øted, and the re≈øt endangered by Fire in that ≈øtately Spire, by the Negligence of a Plummer, who left his Pan of Fire there while he went to Dinner, as he confe≈øt on his Death-bed; This was repaired in 5 years; Arch-Bi≈øhop Laud much repaired it with Portland Stone, in 1640. It was again ruined by the dreadful Fire, 1666, but the Quire is now rebuit, with great part of the re≈øt of the Cathedral in a noble and ≈øumptuous manner. In this Ward of Farringdon, were the Halls of ≈øeveral Companies, as Embroiderers, Sadlers, Barber Chirurgeons, Butchers, Stationers, and likewi≈øe the Colledge of Phy≈øicians in Warwick-lane. It hath an Alderman, his Deputy, and 14 Common Council Men, 17 Con≈øtables, 18 Scavengers, Wardmote Inque≈øt 18, and a Beadle.

22. Bread≈øtreet Ward, wherein are Bread≈øtreet, the Ea≈øt part of Frieday≈øtreet, Watling≈øtreet, part of Knight Rider≈øtreet, and Di≈øtafflane; This Ward was wholly laid wa≈øt by the Fire, and therein the Churches of Alhallows Bread≈øtreet, St. Mildred Bread≈øtreet, St. John Evangelist, and St. Margaret Mo≈øes; al≈øo Cordwainers, Salters and Gerrards Hall. This Ward hath an Alderman,
his Deputy, and 11 Common Council Men, 10 Con≈øtables, 8 Scavengers, Wardmote Inque≈øt 13 and a Beadle.

23. Queen Hythe VVard, comprehends Tainity lane, Bread≈øtreet hill, Fyfoot lane, Disbourn lane, Little Trinity lane, Old Fi≈øh≈øtreet, Lambeth hill, Pye lane, Town≈øend lane, Queen Hythe, Salt VVharf, Stew lane, Broof VVharf, Broken wharf, Trig lane, and Bull wharf. The whole Ward was con≈øumed in 1666, with the≈øe Churches, Trinity Church, St. Nicholas Cole Abby, St. Nicholas Olaves, St. Maudlins Old Fi≈øh≈øtreet, Saint Mary Mounthaw, St. Mary Somer≈øet, St. Michael Quean Hythe, and St. Peters Pauls wharf. It hath an Alderman, his Deputy,, and 6 Common Council Men, 9 Con≈øtables, 8. Scavengers, Wardmote Inque≈øt 13, and a Beadle. In it is Painter Stainers Hall.

24. Ca≈øtle Baynard Ward, contains part of Creed lane, the La≈øt part of Avemary lane, part of Pater no≈øter Row, the Ea≈øt ≈øide of Warwick lane, Peters hill lane, Pauls Wharf, Addle hill, Carter lane, Dolittle lane, Sermon lane, St. Pauls Chain, and part of the South Church-yard, St. Peters Pauls Wharf, and Baynards Ca≈øtle. It was wholly burnt down by the Fire, and therein Baynards Ca≈øtle, St. Bennets Church near Pauls Wharf, St. Andrew Wardrobe, St. Mary Magdalen, and St. Gregories by St. Pauls. It hath an Alderman, his Deputy, and 6 Common Council Men, 10 Con≈øtables, 7 Scavengers, VVardmote Inque≈øt 14, and a Beadle.

25. Farringdon Ward without is very large, and contains Gilt≈øpur ≈øtreet, Pye Corner, Cock lane, Holbourn Conduit, St. Bartholomews Ho≈øpital, Duck lane, Saint Bartholomews Clo≈øe, part of Long lane, part of Chicklane, Smithfield, Cow lane, Snow hill, to the Bi≈øhop of Elies Hou≈øe, Furnivals Inn, Staples Inn, Bernards Inn, Fetter-lane, Thavies Inn, Shoe lane, the Churches of St. Sepulchres, and St. Andrews Holborn, the Old Baity where the Se≈ø≈øions is kept for London and Middle≈øex,
Fleet Ditch, Holborn Bridge, the Streets on each ≈øide the Fleet Pri≈øon, Fleet lane, St. Dun≈øtaus Church in the we≈øt, Cliffords Inn, the ≈øouth end of Chancery lane, Sergeants Inn, even to the Rolls Liberty, Jackanapes lane, part of Sheer lane, the two Temples, White Fryers, Water lane, Salisbury Court, St. Brides Church, Bridewel lane, and Bridewel. There is now a new Street out of Chancery lane, to Little Lincolns-Inn. Some part of this VVard was burnt, and al≈øo Newgate. It hath an Alderman, Deputy and 16 Common Council Men, 14 Con≈øtables, 15 Scavengers, VVardmote Inque≈øt 44 and 3 Beadles.

26. Bridge Ward without, contains long Southwark, St. Georges Church, St. Olaves Church Barnaby ≈øtreet, Kent ≈øtreet, Blackman ≈øtreet, St. Mary Overies, formerly a Priory of Canon Regulars, St. Thomas Church and Ho≈øpital for the Sick and Lame, and the Lock a Lazer Hou≈øe in Kent ≈øtreet; in which were five Pri≈øons, the Clink, the Compter, the Mar≈øhal≈øea, the Kings Bench, the White Lyon, al≈øo Winche≈øter hou≈øe, Battle bridge, the Bridge hou≈øe, and Bermond≈øey Abby. Every VVard hath a peculiar Alderman, as an Over≈øeer or Guardian, who hath greater Power than any ordinary Ju≈øtice of Peace.

div.head: CHAP. VIII. The Inns of Court and Chancery, Colleges, Schools, and Ho≈øpitals in and about the City of London.
div.p:
THE famous City of London may not unfitly be ≈øtiled an Univer≈øity, for therein are taught all Liberal Arts and Sciences, for not only Divinity, Civil Law, and Phy≈øick (which are u≈øual in Univer≈øities) are read hear, but al≈øo the Municipal or Common
Law of the Nation is here taught, and Degrees taken therein, which can be ≈øaid of no other City; moreover all ≈øorts of Sciences, as Geography, Hydrography, the Arts of Navigation and Fortification, Anatomy, Chyrurgery, Chymi≈øtry, Calligraphy, Brachygraphy or Short-hand; the Arts of Riding, Fencing, Dancing, Art Military, Fireworks, Limning, Painting, Enamelling, Sculpture, Architecture, Heraldry, all ≈øorts of Mu≈øick, Arithmetick, Geometry, A≈øtronomy, Grammar, Rhetorick, Poetry, and any other Science that may contribute to the accompli≈øhment of an Ingenuous Noble Man, or Gentleman.

The Colleges of Municipal or Common Law, for Profe≈ø≈øors and Students are Fourteen, and are ≈øtill called Inns, the old Engli≈øh word for the Hou≈øes of Noble Men or Bi≈øhops. There are 2 Inns of Sergeants, 4 Inns of Court. and 8 Inns of Chancery; the Inns of Chancery were probably ≈øo named becau≈øe there dwelt ≈øuch Clerks as did chiefly ≈øtudy the forming of Writs; their Names are Thavies Inn, begun in the Reign of Edward III. Furnivals Inn, Bernards Inn, New Inn, Clements Inn, Cliffords Inn, anciently the Hou≈øe of the Lord Clifford, Staple Inn; belonging to the Merchants of the Staple, and Lyons-Inn, anciently a common Inn with the ≈øign of the Lyon. The≈øe were preparatory Colleges for younger. Students, many being entred here before admitted into the Inns of Court; now they are generally taken by Attorneys, Sollicitors, and Clerks, who have Chambers apart, and their Diet in an Hall together, where they are obliged to appear in long Robes, and black round knit Caps; the≈øe Colleges belong all to ≈øome Inns of Court, who ≈øend yearly ≈øome of their Barri≈øters to read to the≈øe. In each of the≈øe Inns of Chancery may be about three≈øcore Per≈øons.

The Inns of Court were ≈øo named (as ≈øome think) becau≈øe the Students therein are to ≈øerve the Courts of Judicature; of the≈øe there are 4. Fir≈øt the
„Äà‚óä„Äâ
Temples, heretofore the dwelling of the Knights Templars, and purcha≈øed by ≈øome Profe≈ø≈øors of the Common Law, above 300 years ago; they are called the Inner, & middle Temple in elation to E≈ø≈øex hou≈øe, which was a part of the Knights Templars, Lodgings & call'd utter or outer Temple, becau≈øe it is ≈øeated without Temple-Bar; the 2 other Inns of Court are Lincolns-Inn, and Greys-Inn, belonging to the Noble Family of the Greys; In the Reign of K. Henry VI. there were in each of the≈øe above 200 Students.

The≈øe Societies are no Corporations, nor have any Iudicial Power over their Members, only certain Orders among them≈øelves, which have by con≈øent the force of Laws; for lighter Offences they are only excommoned, or put out of Commons, not to eat with the re≈øt, & for greater they lo≈øe their Chambers. There are no Lands or Revenues belong to the≈øe Societies, nor have they any thing for defraying the Charges of the Hou≈øe, but what is paid at Admittance, and quit Rents for their Chambers; the whole Company in each Society may be divided into 4 parts Benchers, ∆≤tter Barri≈øters, Inner Barri≈øters and Students. In the 4 Inns of Court there now are reckoned 800 Students. There are 2 more Colleges called Sergeants Inn where the Common Law Student, when he hath arrived to the highe≈øt Degree, hath his Lodging and Diet, and are as Doctors in the Civil Law; out of the≈øe are cho≈øen all the Judges of the Kings Bench and Common-Pleas. There is likewi≈øe the College of Civilians called Doctors-Commons near St. Pauls, for the Profe≈ø≈øors of the Civil Law, where commonly the Judges of the Arches, Admiralty and Prerogative Court re≈øide, who≈øe Office is not far off; They judgeth of E≈øtates fallen by Will, or by Inte≈øtates, and are under the Juri≈ødiction of the Arch-bi≈øhop of Canterbury. There is al≈øo the College of Phy≈øicians, curiou≈øly rebuilt in Warwick lane; and likewi≈øe a College of Heralds
who are Me≈ø≈øengers of War, and Peace, and skilful in De≈øcents, Pedigrees, and Coats of Arms.

Gre≈øham College in Bi≈øhop≈øgate-≈øtreet is another, built by Sir Tho. Gre≈øham, and a Revenue left to the Lord Mayor and Aldermen, for maintaining four Per≈øons to read within this College, Divinity, Geometry, A≈øtronomy, and Mu≈øick, with an allowance to each (be≈øides Lodging) of 50 l. a year; and other Rents are left to the Mercers Company to find three able Men more, to read Civil Law, Phy≈øick, and Rhetorick, with the ≈øame allowance; the≈øe ≈øeveral Lectures ≈øhould be read in Term time, every day in the Week except Sundays, beginning at nine in the Morning, and at two Afternoon, to give notice whereof, the Bell in the Steeple of the Royal-Exchange is to ring at tho≈øe times; they are to read Forenoon in Latin, and Afternoon in Engli≈øh. The Mu≈øick Lecture to be read only in Engli≈øh.

There is al≈øo Sion College founded by Dr. White near Cripplegate, for the u≈øe of the Clergy of London, and of the Liberties thereof, and ≈øome Alms-Hou≈øes for 24 poor People; to perform all which he gave 3000 l. and for the maintenance of the≈øe poor People 120 l. a year for ever, and 40 l. a year for a Sermon in Latin at the beginning of every Quarter, and a plentiful Dinner for all the Clergy that ≈øhall then meet there. In this College is a fine Library, built by John Sym≈øon, well furni≈øhed with Books for Divines. This College felt the rage of the Fire, but is ≈øince rebuilt, A little without the Walls ≈øtands another College or Collegiate Hou≈øe, called the Charter-hou≈øe, formerly a Convent of Carthu≈øian Monks, called al≈øo Suttons Ho≈øpital. It con≈øi≈øts of a Ma≈øter or Governour, a Chaplain, with a Ma≈øter and U≈øher to in≈øtruct 44 Scholars, be≈øides 80 decayed Gentlemen, Soldiers, or Merchants, who have all a plentiful maintenance of Diet, Lodging, Cloaths, Phy≈øick, &c. and live all together in a Collegiate manner; and the 44 Scholars have
all Nece≈ø≈øaries whil≈øt they are here taught, and when fit for the Univer≈øity, there is allowed to each, out of the Revenues of this College 20 l. yearly for 3 years after they come to the Univer≈øity; and to others ≈øit for Trades, a con≈øiderable ≈øum to bind them Apprentices. There are all ≈øorts of Officers fit for ≈øuch a Society, as Min≈øter, Phy≈øician, Apothecary, Steward, Cook, Butler, &c. who have all competent Salaries. This va≈øt Revenue and Princely Foundation was the ≈øole Gift of an ordinary Gentleman, Mr. Thomas Sutton born in Lincoln≈øhire, and is of ≈øuch, account that by the Kings Letters Patents under the great Seal, divers Per≈øons of the highe≈øt Dignity and Quality in Church and State, are always the Over≈øeers, and Regulators of this Society, as the Arch bi≈øhop of Canterbury, the L. Keeper or Chancellor, L. Trea≈øurer, and 13 more.

There are likewi≈øe divers publick Schools endowed, as St. Pauls, a Free School founded by Dr. Collet Dean of St. Pauls for 153 Children to be taught gratis; for which there was appointed a Ma≈øter, a Subma≈øter or U≈øher, and a Chaplain, with large ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
pends paid by the Mercers Company. This famous School was al≈øo burnt down, but is now reedified in a more magnificent and commodious Manner. In 1553. after the crecting of Chri≈øts Ho≈øpital out of the Ruins of the Gray Fryers, a great number of poor Children were taken in, and a School appointed at the charge of the City There are in London divers other endowed or Free Schools, as Merchant Taylors, Mercers, &c.

There are likewi≈øe ≈øeveral famous Ho≈øpitals in this City, as Chri≈øts Ho≈øpital, given by King Edward VI. from whence Children are put forth Apprentices every year, ≈øome of them being in≈øtructed in Arithmetick and Navigation, are placed with Commanders of Ships out of the Mathematical School, founded by K. Charles H. Then there is St. Bartholomews Ho≈øpital
for maimed Soldiers, Seamen and other di≈øea≈øed Per≈øons. St. Thomas's Ho≈øpital in Southwark, for ≈øick and wounded Per≈øons. Al≈øo Pridewell Ho≈øpital for Vagrants and Indigent Per≈øons. The Ho≈øpital o ‚Ä¢
Bethlem for curing Lunaticks and mad Men, hath been lately removed, becau≈øe of the inconveniency of the Place; and a ≈øtately and magnificent Ho≈øpital built for them in Morefields, which co≈øt above 17000 Pound.

div.head: CHAP. IX. The Strand, We≈øtmin≈øter and Part Adjacent.
div.p: IT would too much enlarge this ≈ømall Volume to give an exact Account of the City of We≈øtmin≈øter and other Parts; we ≈øhall therefore only remark ≈øome Particulars; We≈øtmini≈øter was formerly called Dorney or Thorney, and was an I≈øland incompa≈ø≈øed by the Thames, overgrown with Fryers and Thorns, but now graced with ≈øltately Hou≈øes and Pallaces, both publick and private. The chief are the two Palaces of White hall, but the former was lately burnt down by a ≈øudden Fire, and St. James's to which is adjoined a delightful Park, in which is a Mall, ≈øaid to be the be≈øt in Europe, it is now the Pallace of our Gracious Queen Anne.

Then there is We≈øtmin≈øter-hall, where the Courts of Ju≈øtice are kept, as the High Court of Parliament, con≈øi≈øting of the King, the Lords Spiritual and Temporal, and the Commons. The Court of Kings Bench, wherein the King ≈øometimes ≈øate in Per≈øon, in which are handled all the Pleas of the Crown, all things that concern lo≈øs of Life or Member, for them the K. or Qu. is concerned, becau≈øe the Life, and Limbs of the Subject belong only to them, ≈øo that the Pleas are here between the King and the Subject. As all Trea≈øons, Felonies, Breach of Peace, Oppre≈ø≈øion, Mi≈øgovernment, &c. In this Court ≈øit four Judges.
Then there is the Court of Common-Pleas, ≈øo called (≈øay ≈øome) becau≈øe there are debated the u≈øual Pleas between one Subject and another; in this Court there are likewi≈øe four Judges. Next is the Court of Exchequer, ≈øo called (≈øome think) from a Checquer wrought Carpet covering the great Table in that Court; wherein are tryed all Cau≈øes concerning the Kings Revenue. There is another called the Court of the Dutchy of Lanca≈øter, which takes Cognizance of all Cau≈øes that concern the Reve
‚Ä¢ ues of that Dutchy. Al≈øo the high Court of Chan
‚Ä¢ ery, which is placed next the King's Bench, as mitigating the Rigor thereof; this Court is the Womb ‚Ä¢ f all our Fundamental Laws; it is called Chancery as ‚Ä¢ ome imagine, becau≈øe the Judge of this Court ≈øate ‚Ä¢ nciently inter Cancellos, or within Lattices, as the Ea≈øt end of our Churches being ≈øeparated per Cancel
‚Ä¢ os from the Body of the Church, as peculiarly belonging to the Prie≈øt, were thence called Chancels; this Court grants Writs according to Equity or Con≈øci
‚Ä¢ nce. Out of which i≈ø≈øue Summons for Parliaments, ‚Ä¢ dicts, Proclamations, Letters Patents, Treaties, ‚Ä¢ eagues with Forreign Princes, &c. There is likewi≈øe ‚Ä¢ he Court of Admiralty, wherein all matters concern
‚Ä¢ ng the Sea are determined by the Civil Law, becau≈øe ‚Ä¢ he Sea is without the Limits of the Common Law, ‚Ä¢ ow kept at Wallingford-Hou≈øe.

The next thing con≈øiderable is the Collegiate Church called We≈øtmin≈øter-Abby, or St. Peters. It was ‚Ä¢ ai≈øed out of the ruins of a Temple formerly dedicated to Apollo; wherein there is King Henry VII's Chappel, a magnificent and curious Edifice; beautified with the ≈øtately Tombs of the Kings and Queens of England, and many other Per≈øons of Honour and Renown are buried in this Church; and here the Kings of England are commonly crowned.

Then there is Somer≈øet-hou≈øe, a large and ≈øtately ‚Ä¢ tructure belonging to the King, Northumberland
hou≈øe York-hou≈øe now turned into Streets and Buildings, the new Exchange ≈øtored with variety of Shops and Goods; the Statue of K. Charles I. lately erected at Charing cro≈øs, Salisbury-hou≈øe now a fine Street, the Savoy, Arundel-hou≈øe, Bedford-hou≈øe, and divers other Places worth ob≈øerving. The Limits of We≈øtmin≈øter end at Temple-Bar and there the bounds of London begin. We≈øtminfter is ≈øo mightily enlarged by the building of St. James's Fields and the adjaceat Places into ≈øtately large Streets, that it is thought to be as big again as formerly.

To conclude, London is the Epitome of England, the Seat of the Britti≈øh Empire, the Chamber of the King, the chiefe≈øt Emporium or Town of Trade in the World, and to de≈øcribe all things in it worthy to be known, would make a Volume. The City of London with the Suburbs and parts adjacent is from Lime-hou≈øe to the end of Tothill ≈øtreet in We≈øtmin≈øter, Ea≈øt and We≈øt above 7500 Geometrical Paces, or 7 Engli≈øh Miles and an half, and from the further end of Blackman-≈øtreet in Southwark to the end of Shoreditch North and South, 2500 Paces or two Miles and an half.

div.head: Hi≈øtorical Remarks OF LONDON and WESTMINSTER. PART II.
div.p: ENgland, in the time of the Saxons, was divided into an Heptarchy, or ≈øeven Kingdoms, in the year of Chri≈øt 527. One of the≈øe Kingdoms contained E≈ø≈øex and Middle≈øex, and continued about 281 years, during the Reign of 14 Kings. The third of whom was Sebert, who built the Cathedral of St. Paul, which had formerly been the Temple of Diana. The ninth King was Sebba, who after thirty years peaceable Reign relinqui≈øhed the Crown, and took upon him a Religions Habit in the Mona≈øtery of St. Paul, where dying, his Body was intombed in a Coffi ‚Ä¢ of Gray Marble, and ≈øtood in the North Wall of the Chancel of the Church, till the Fire in 1666.

About 872. the Danes invaded this Kingdom, and got into London, making great ≈øpoil; upon which King Elfred, who then reigned, compounded with them, allowing them a great quantity of Land to ≈øecure
the re≈øt from Plunder and Ruine; for we find the≈øe words in the end of the Laws publi≈øhed by this King, Let the Bounds of our Dominion ≈øtretch from the River Thames, and from thence to the Vale of Lea, even unto the head of the ≈øame Water, and ≈øo forth ≈øtraight unto Bedford, and finally going along by the River of Ou≈øe, let them end at Watling-≈øtreet. But the Danes ufurped daily upon other places, ≈øo that King Elfred was many times forced to hide him≈øelf in the Fens and Mar≈øhes, and with his ≈ømall Company to live by Fi≈øhing, Fowling, and Hunting Wild Bea≈øts for Food; and being one time entertained alone in a Country man's hou≈øe, di≈øgui≈øed in very mean attire, as he was ≈øitting by the Fire, a Cake was baking on the Hearth before him, but the King being intent in trimming his Bow and Arrows, the Country woman coming in, and ≈øeeing the Cake burn, ≈øhe furiou≈øly took the Bow from him, and checking him as her Slave, ≈øaid, Thou Fellow, do≈øt thou ≈øee the Bread burn before thy Face, and wilt thou not turn it, and yet maye≈øt be glad to eat it before it be half baked? Little ≈øu≈øpecting him to be the man that u≈øed to be treated with more dainty Food.

This King, more minding the Benefit of his Subjects than the Maje≈øty of State di≈øgui≈øed him≈øelf in the habit of a common Fidler, and went in Per≈øon to the Danes Camp, who lay wallowing in Wantonue≈øs and Security; and being a ≈økilful Mu≈øician, and a Poet he addded his Voice thereto; ≈øinging Songs of the Valour of the Danes, whereby he had admittance to the Company and Banquets of their chief Commanders and Princes; and ob≈øerving their carele≈øne≈øs, and under≈øtanding their De≈øigns, he returns to his poor di≈øcon≈øolate Soldiers, and tells them how ea≈øie it was to ≈øurprize their Enemies, and thereby recover their ruined Country: who immediately fell upon the Danes in their Camp, and made a very great ≈ølaughter; and pur≈øuing their Victory, they
beat them in all Places; and at la≈øt followed them to London, from whence, all the Danes fled. The Inhabitants were very glad to ≈øee the Face of their King, and he re≈øtored the City to its former Liberty and Splendor again, the Danes making their e≈øcape by ≈øhipping into France.

In 982 the Danes again invade England, and de≈øtroy all Places near the Shore. Etheldred was then King, who≈øe elder Brother (called the Martyr) was treacherou≈øly murdered by his Mother-in-Law; for the King being a hunting in the I≈øle of Purbeck, went alone out of kindne≈øs to „Äà‚óä„Äâ his Mother-in-Law and Brother, who dwelt hard by, where this cruel Woman, out of ambition to bring her Son to the Crown, cau≈øed one to run him into the back with a Knife, as he was drinking a Gla≈øs of Wine on Hor≈øeback at his departing, who feeling him≈øelf hurt, ≈øet ≈øpurs to his Hor≈øe, thinking to get to his Company, but the Wound being mortal, and he fainting through lo≈øs of Blood fell from his Hor≈øe; and one Foot being entangled in the Stirrup, he was dragged up and down through the Woods, and afterward found dead, and was buried at the Min≈øter in Shaftsbury. Etheldred was then crowned King by Dun≈øtan Arch Bi≈øhop of Canterbury, who at his Coronation, denounced the wrath of God again≈øt him in the≈øe Words; Becau≈øe, ≈øaith he, thou ha≈øt a≈øpired to the Crown by the death of thy Brother, whom thy Mother hath murdered, therefore hear the Word of the Lord; The Sword ≈øhall not depart from thy Hou≈øe, but ≈øhall furiou≈øly rage all the days of thy Life, killing all thy Seed, till ≈øuch time as thy Kingdom ≈øhall be given to a People, who≈øe Cu≈øtoms and Language the Nation thou now governe≈øt, know not. Neither ≈øhall thy ≈øin, the ≈øin of thy Mother, nor the ≈øins of tho≈øe men who were Partakers of her Councils, and In≈øtruments of her wicked De≈øigns, be expiated and appea≈øed, but by long and mo≈øt ≈øevere Vengeance. Which Prediction was ≈øeconded by Prodigies; for it is ≈øaid that a Cloud
of Blood and Fire appeared after his Coronation, and mi≈øerable Calamities fell upon him and his Hou≈øe. This King was neither forward nor fortunate in any of his undertakings, ≈øo that he was called, The ∆≤uready; he ≈øpent his Youth in debauchery, his middle Age in carele≈øne≈øs, and neglect of his Government, maintaining Di≈ø≈øentions among≈øt his own Subjects, and his latter end in re≈øi≈øting the blood thir≈øty Danes, who made continual De≈øtruction of his People and Country, who had been quiet for 22 years before, ≈øo all the≈øe calamities were imputed to the Mi≈øgovernment of this unhappy Prince.

The Danes perceiving the Hearts of the Subjects to be drawn from their Sovereign, landed in Ker ‚Ä¢
with ≈øeven Ships, ≈øpoiling the Country for eleven years together, till at la≈øt the King, by advice of his Lords, paid them ten thou≈øand Pounds, to depart the Realm. This ≈øerved for the pre≈øent, but they returned year after year, and ≈øtill obliged the King to give them more Money, till at la≈øt it came to forty thou≈øand Pound a year, which emptied the Land of all the Coin, and the Engli≈øh were forced to plough, and ≈øow while the Danes ≈øate idle, and eat the fruit of their Labours, abu≈øing al≈øo their Wives and Daughters, whereupon they were called Lord Danes, (now Lurdains, ≈øignifying a Lazy Lubber.)

In this di≈øtre≈ø≈øed State, the King thought of this expedient to be rid of them: He ≈øent out Commi≈ø≈øions into every City in his Dominions that at an appointed time they ≈øhould Ma≈ø≈øacre all the Danes that were among≈øt them. The Day was Novem. 13, 1002 his Command was accordingly performed, and that with ≈øuch Rigour, that in Oxford the fearful Danes for refuge, took into the Church of St. Fride≈øwide, as a Sanctuary of venerable Antiquity; but they in their fury, regarding neither Place nor Per≈øon, ≈øet the Church on fire, wherein many Danes were burnt, with divers rich Ornaments, and the Library utterly defaced.

At which time, it is ≈øaid, King Etheldred him≈øelf was in Oxford, and had ≈øummoned a Parliament both of Engli≈øh and Danes to meet there, and afterwards repaired the Ruins the fire had made. In this Ma≈øfacre the Lady Gunhild Si≈øter to the King of Denmark, and a continual Friend to the Engli≈øh, with her Hu≈øband and Son were ≈ølain. Upon the News of this Ma≈ø≈øacre King Swain with a great Navy of Danes, lands in ≈øeveral parts in England, and carries all before him: and other Danes with 94 ≈øhips, ≈øailed up the River of Thames, and be≈øieged London, but the Citizens made ≈øuch valiant Re≈øi≈øtance, that they forced them to retire: however they fell ≈øeverely upon E≈ø≈øex, Kent, Su≈ø≈øex, and Hamp≈øhire. The≈øe Calamities were ≈øeconded with others as fearful; for about this time the City was de≈øtroyed by Fire, who≈øe beauty then chiefly extended from Ludgate We≈øtward; for that within the Walls, where the heart of the City now is, was then neither beautiful nor orderly built. To add to the≈øe Mi≈øeries a dreadful Sickne≈øs raged in London, and mo≈øt parts of England, hitherto anknown in this Kingdom, being a burning Fever, and the bloody Flux; there was al≈øo great ≈øcarcity, by rea≈øon of the Murrain, and Death of all ≈øorts of Cattel. All the≈øe Judgments were imputed to the King, and his Abettors, Dun≈øtan prophecying further woes to the Land after his death, though the King made great lamentation for the Murther of his Brother K. Edward, for which his Mother beat him ≈øo violently with a wax Taper, which ≈øtood before her, that he could never after well endure the ≈øight of a Taper.

In 1013 K. Swain came again from Denmark, landing a great number of Men in the River Humber, and conquered all before him till he came to London, and pre≈øently be≈øieged King Etheldred within it, Swain doubted not of carrying the City, but the Citizens con≈øidering they had their King with them, and that London was the Eye of the Land, grew very couragious,
beating the Danes from the Walls, and then ≈øallying out ≈ølew them on heaps, ≈øo that King Swain him≈øelf was in great danger, had he not de≈øperately ran through the mid≈øt of his Enemies Swords, and by flight e≈øcaped, marching day and night in great fear, till he had got to Bath; where Ethelmere Earl of Devon≈øhire, and his people ≈øubmitted to him; but this la≈øt overthrow, and want of Victuals, cau≈øed him after he had received a ≈øum of Money, to ha≈øten into Denmark, but returning with greater Strength, he met with the Engli≈øh again, and utterly defeated them, by rea≈øon of the treachery of ≈øome Engli≈øh who revolted to the Danes. So that the whole Kingdom, yea Loudon it ≈øelf, was forced to comply with the calamity of the Times, wherewith Etheldred, being utterly dejected, he ≈øent his VVife Emma, and his two Sons to his Brother Richard Duke of Normandy; and went him≈øelf in one of his Ships to the I≈øle of Wight, and afterwards to Normandy to his Brother, leaving the Danes ≈øole Lords and Ma≈øters of the Realm.

A while after King Swain coming to St. Edmundbury in Suffolk, threatned to burn down the Church, unle≈øs they would give him a ≈øum of Money (having done the like in ≈øeveral other Places) which the Iuhabitants refu≈øing to pay, he went to di≈øturb the Bones of St. Edmund, ≈øo called; which while he was doing, he ≈øuddenly cried out (≈øaith the Hi≈øtorian) that, He was ≈øtruck by St. Edmund with a Sword, being then in the mid≈øt of his Nobles, and no man ≈øeeing from who≈øe hand it came; and ≈øo with great Horror he died three days after, and the Danes advanced Ganutus his Son to the Throne.

Soon after King Etheldred died al≈øo, and his third Son called Edmund Iron≈øide (of his enduring Labour) ≈øucceeded: A great part of the Engli≈øh both feared and favoured Canutus, e≈øpecially the Clergy, who at Southampton ≈øwore fealty to him. But the Londoners
≈øtood firm to Prince Edmund, and elected him King. In revenge whereof Canutus, who had be≈øieged the City before the death of King Etheldred, cau≈øed his Ships to be towed up the Thames to the Ea≈øt ≈øide of the Bridge, and from the River with a deep Trench encompa≈ø≈øed the City, ≈øhutting up all the Pa≈ø≈øages in or out of it. But the coming of their new King Edmund to their a≈ø≈øi≈øtance did much encourage them, and di≈øheartned the Danes, ≈øo that they brake up the Seige, King Edmnnd having ≈øent a Challenge to Canutus to fight him in ≈øingle Combat; which he neither accepted, nor ≈øtaid at London, but ≈øailed down the Thames to the I≈øle of Sh ‚Ä¢ ppey, where he wintred with his Navy. and in the Spring a≈ø≈øailed the We≈øt of England, where the Danes were routed. After this, at a place called Shero≈øtan in Worce≈øter≈øhire, another Battle was fought, where the Danes were like again to have been di≈øcomfited; which Edrick an Engli≈øh Man perceiving, he cut off the Head of a Soldier, who≈øe name was O≈ømearus, who was like King Edmund both in Hair and Countenance, and ≈øhaking his bloody Sword with the ga≈øping Head, cried out to the Engli≈øh Army, Fly wrethes, fly, and get away, for your King is ≈ølain, behold here is his Head, therefore ≈øeek now to ≈øave your own Lives. Edmund having notice of this treacherous Stratagem, ha≈øtned to ≈øhew him≈øelf, who≈øe ≈øight ≈øo encouraged his Men, that they had got a total Victory, if night had not prevented them The Soldiers bent their Bows again≈øt Dake Edrick, and had ≈øhot him to death, had he not excu≈øed the Fact, as being mi≈øtaken in the Countenance of the Man, and de≈øirous to ≈øave the blood of the Engli≈øh: upon which fal≈øe Pretence he was taken into favour again.

Three days after both Armies prepared again for Battle, yet ≈øtood ≈øtill without ≈økirmi≈øhing, only refre≈øhing their tired Bodies, and burying tho≈øe that were ≈ølain in the two days before. The night following

And thus was the Saxon Monarchy come to its la≈øt period, and the tottering Crown was ≈øoon after torn from Edmunds head: For Duke Edrick, a Traitor in grain, being much in favour with both Kings, yet to oblige Canutus, contrived the death of renowned Edmund, who going into a place of ca≈øement, was ≈øuddenly thru≈øt from under the Vault into the body with a ≈øharp Spear; which being done, the Villain Edrick cut off his Sovereigns head, and pre≈øented it to Canutus with this flattering ≈øalutation, All hail thou now ≈øole Monarch of England, for here behold the head of thy Copartner, which for thy ≈øake I have adventured to cut off.

And ≈øo much concerning the Jews. To return now to the ≈øeries of the Story, King William
Rufus was taxed with great Prodigality, becau≈øe when his Chamberlain brought him a new pair of Ho≈øe, he asked what they co≈øt, and was told three ≈øhillings: Away ba≈øe Fellow, quoth he, are the≈øe be≈øeeming a King? And though the Monks that writ in tho≈øe times, charge this King with covetou≈øne≈øs, yet by the following in≈øtance it doth not appear. But however there aro≈øe a great difference between him and An≈øelm Archbi≈øhop of Canterbury, becau≈øe he required the Bi≈øhop to give him a Thou≈øand Marks for preferring him to that See, which An≈øelm refu≈øed to give, as judging it no le≈øs Simony to give after the preferment than before; but yet afterward offering five hundred pound, the King refu≈øed to accept it, as being worth (he ≈øaid) five times as much. Whereupon An≈øelm told

In the ninth Year of his Reign, a blazing Star appeared with two Bu≈øhes or Tails, and other Stars ≈øeemed to ≈øhoot darts at each other. The la≈øt of his Reign, the Sea breaking over its Banks, de≈øtroyed

div.p: The Lords having thus got the Government into their hands, obliege the King to free them from all Obedience and Allegiance when≈øoever he infringed their Charter. Yet ≈øoon after the King ≈øends to R ‚Ä¢ me to be freed from his Oath; which he obtained. Whereupon the Lords put them≈øelves into arms, and Moniford Earl of Leice≈øter their General, takes many Ca≈øtles. The King likewi≈øe rai≈øes Forces. The Barons march toward London, under a Banner richly and beautifully flouri≈øhed with the Kings Arms. And as they pa≈ø≈øed by the Hou≈øes or Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions of tho≈øe that favoured the Popes Bulls (whereby the King him≈øelf, and all others who had formerly ≈øworn to ob≈øerve and maintain tho≈øe new Ordinances and Laws, and to ≈øupport the Authority of the twenty four Peers, were fully ab≈øolved from their Oaths) they robbed and wa≈øted them, as Enemies to the King and kingdom.

They then approached the City of London, and by their Letters de≈øired the Lord Mayor and Citizens to ≈øend them word whether they re≈øolved to ≈øupport the Authority of the Peers or not; prote≈øting before God, them≈øelves intended nothing el≈øe; and that if any thing were defective in tho≈øe Laws, they ≈øhould be reformed.

The Lord Mayor ≈øends the≈øe Letters with all ≈øpeed to the King, who de≈øired likewi≈øe to know, whether they would ≈øupport the Laws of the twenty four Peers or not: they ≈øtoutly an≈øwered, that they would, ≈øince by the Kings command they had all ≈øworn ≈øo to do. The King was extreamly enraged at this an≈øwer, but he could get no other; and the ≈øame an≈øwer they ≈øent to the Lords, who thereupon proceeded in their march, and were with much joy and kindne≈øs received into London, and ≈øoon after routed the Prince, who came again≈øt them with a con≈øiderable Army.

But ≈øome of the meaner ≈øort of the City, intending under the pretence of the≈øe di≈øturbances, to do mi≈øchief, elected two ambitious Fellows, whom they called the two Con≈øtables of London; and agreed, that at the tolling of a great Bell in St. Pauls Church, as many as would join with them, ≈øhould be ready to act whatever the two Con≈øtables commanded them; and though all endeavours were u≈øed to prevent them, yet their de≈øire of plunder ≈øo furiou≈øly tran≈øported them, that upon the tolling that Bell, a great number met together; and marching about eight miles We≈øtward from London, they ruined and de≈øtroyed the Hou≈øe and Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions of the Kings Brother Richard King of the Romans, carrying away all his Goods with them. Which in≈øolent outrage much furthered the ≈øucceeding Wars, for whereas before Richard being of a mild and virtuous di≈øpo≈øition had u≈øed all his endeavours to make peace upon all occa≈øions, he now became a profe≈ø≈øed Enemy both to the Barons, and the City of London.

After this the Lords ≈øent a Letter to the King, and prote≈øted with all humility and ≈øubmi≈ø≈øion that they intended nothing but the performance of their Oaths, by defending tho≈øe Laws and Ordinances which had been e≈øtabli≈øhed in Parliament for the benefit of the King and the Realm. But the King, his Brother Richard, and Edward the young Prince, thinking nothing more di≈ødainful than that Subjects ≈øhould rule and command their Sovereign, re≈øolved to revenge it, and bid utter defiance to the Lords; and both Armies met near a Town called Lewis in Su≈ø≈øex, where a cruel Battel was fought, and the King, his Brother, and the Prince, were all taken pri≈øoners, with many other great Commanders, and twenty thou≈øand men ≈ølain. Yet a while after, upon ≈øome Conditions,
they were all three ≈øet at Liberty, and the former Laws and Ordinances were confirmed in Parliament, and the King took an Oath for confirming the power of the twelve Peers.

After which the Earls of Leice≈øter and Gloce≈øter, the two Generals of the Lords Party, fell into a great difference; which Prince Edward taking advantage of, rai≈øeth an Army, and per≈øuading the Earl of Gloce≈øter to join with him, they fell upon the Earl of Leice≈øters Army, and utterly routed them, him≈øelf, his elde≈øt Son, and many others being ≈ølain. Which overthrow utterly defeated the Barons, and revived the Melancholy King: who calling a Parliament, all the former Decrees were made void, together with the power of the twelve Peers, and the King regained his former Liberty and Authority.

When this Parliament was ended, the King (perhaps by the in≈øtigation of his Brother Richard, who was ≈øo horridly abu≈øed without cau≈øe, by the ba≈øer ≈øort of the Inhabitants of the City) re≈øolved utterly to de≈øtroy and con≈øume the City of London by Fire, becau≈øe he ≈øaid the Magi≈øtrates and Inhabitants had always hated him, and taken part with the Lords again≈øt him. Whereupon tho≈øe of the Nobility, who were mo≈øt in favour with the King, humbly be≈øought him, By no means to do ≈øuch an execrable deed, which would not onely weaken his own Kingdom and Government, but would likewi≈øe make him infamous throughout the World to all Generations.

They were very earne≈øt in their ≈øuit, and their Rea≈øons were unan≈øwerable: yet the King prore≈øted, That he was re≈øolved to do it, and his determination ≈øhould be unchangeable, and his Ju≈øtice upon ≈øuch Rebellious Villains, ≈øhould be a Pre≈øident to deter all perver≈øe and ob≈øtinate Rebels and Traitors in time to come. This ≈øevere Re≈øolution made the Citizens
tremble, at the indignation of their angry King; ≈øo that perceiving his rage and fury not to be mitigated, they cau≈øed an in≈øtrument to be drawn in writing, which was confirmed with their Common Seal, wherein they confe≈ø≈øed their Rebellion, and humbly craved pardon for the ≈øame; and without any exception or re≈øervation, they wholly ≈øubmitted their Lands, Goods, and Lives, together with the whole City, to the Kings Grace and Mercy.

This In≈øtrument they ≈øent to Wind≈øor to the King, by ≈øome of the chiefe≈øt of the Citizens, who were ordered to pre≈øent it on their knees; but ≈øo furious was the Kings wrath again≈øt them, and ≈øo implacable was his anger, that he reputed none to be his Friends, who interpo≈øed as Mediators on their behalf: neither would he admit any of them into his pre≈øence, but commanded them immediately to be thrown into pri≈øon, and five of the principal of them he gave to the Prince, together with all their Lands and Goods; and all the re≈øt he be≈øtowed among his Attendants, who made them Slaves, and ≈øuffered them to enjoy the lea≈øt part of their own.

But when the King had thus a little revenged him≈øelf, and time had cooled his mighty pa≈ø≈øion, he began to hearken to the importunate interce≈ø≈øion of Prince Edward his Son, and ≈øoon after received the City and all its Inhabitants into favour again, and laying onely a Fine upon them of a thou≈øand Marks, he re≈øtored to them all their Charters, Liberties, and Cu≈øtoms, which for their tran≈øgre≈ø≈øions he had ≈øeized into his hands.

And now though the≈øe Inte≈øtine Troubles and Civil Wars, which like an outragious Fire di≈øper≈øed into the mid≈øt of a well compacted City, had end angered the whole State of the kingdom, were thus appea≈øed; and though the Earl of Gloce≈øter
by his revolt from the Barons, and joining with the Prince, had greatly furthered this good work, and had cau≈øed the King to enjoy a happy peace; yet was this Earl ≈øo little tru≈øted, that he found neither favour nor reward; but was much ≈ølighted, and had but cold entertainment at Court, which he highly re≈øented, and meditated revenge.

In this fury he came headlong into the City of London, and complaining of his ill u≈øage, the common people flockt in Troops about him, and daringly committed many notorious outrages within the City, forgetting the great Calamity they had lately ≈øuffered, and what favours they had received. From thence they went to the Kings Palace at We≈øtmin≈øter, which they mo≈øt barbarou≈øly rifled, ≈øpoiled, and ran≈øacked. This might have produced another Civil War, but the Tumult was in a little time di≈øper≈øed, and the Prince again interpo≈øed him≈øelf an earne≈øt Mediator between the King and all the Offenders, and procured a large and free pardon for the Earl of Gloce≈øter, whereby all things were again appea≈øed and quieted.
After which the Earl of Gloce≈øter and Prince Edward went into the Holy Land, where he continued till after the death of his Father.

It is ob≈øerved of this King Henry the third, that he was never con≈øtant in his love nor his hate; for he never had ≈øo great a Favourite but he ca≈øt him off with di≈øgrace, nor ≈øo great an Enemy whom he received not into favour. An example of both which Qualities was ≈øeen in his carriage to Hubert de Burgh, who was for a time the greate≈øt Favourite, yet ca≈øt out afterward in mi≈øerable di≈øgrace; and then no man held in greater hatred, yet received afterward into Grace again. Henry IV. his Uncle, ≈øucceeded K. Rich. again≈øt whom ≈øeveral Rebellions were rai≈øed; e≈øpecially one Henry Piercy called Hot≈øpur, and others, who were overthrown, King Henry him≈øelf killing thirty ≈øix with his own hands, the Earl of Worce≈øter among the re≈øt, was taken and beheaded, with many others, who≈øe Heads were ≈øet on London Bridge. In his time a Parliament was called at We≈øtmin≈øter, in which the Commons pre≈øented a Petition to the King and the Hou≈øe of Peers, de≈øiring that the King might have the Temporal Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions of the Bi≈øhops and Clergy; affirming that they would maintain 150 Earls, 1500 Knights, 6200 E≈øquires, and 100 Ho≈øpitals for maimed Souldiers. They de≈øired likewi≈øe that Clerks Convict ≈øhould not be delivered into the Bi≈øhops Pri≈øon, and that the Statute in the ≈øecond year of his Reign again≈øt Lollards, or the Followers of John Wickliff might be repealed. But the King denied their Petition, and in per≈øon commanded them from thenceforth not to trouble their brains about any ≈øuch bu≈øine≈øs, ≈øince he was re≈øolved to leave the Church in as good ≈øtate as he found it.

In the third year of this King a Blazing Star appeared fir≈øt at the Ea≈øt, and then ≈øent out fiery ≈øtreams toward the North, fore≈øhewing perhaps the effu≈øion of bloud that followed after in tho≈øe parts. In the ≈øame year the Devil appeared (≈øaith our Author) in the likene≈øs of a Gray Frier, who entering the Church, put the people in great fear, and the ≈øame hour the top of the Steeple was broken down, and half the Chancel ≈øcattered abroad by a Tempe≈øt of Whirlwind and Thunder. In his eighth year Richard Whittington Lord Mayor of London erected Whittington Colledge, with
Lodgings and Weekly Allowance for ≈øeveral poor People. He al≈øo built Newga ‚Ä¢ e, half of St. Bartholomews Ho≈øpital in Smithfield, and a bountiful Library in Chri≈øtchurch, and likewi≈øe the Ea≈øt end of Guild-hall, and a Chappel adjoyning to it, with a Library of Stone for keeping the Records of the City. The Grocers in London purcha≈øed their Hall in Coney hoop Lane for 320 Marks. In his twelfth year Guild-hall was begun to be rebuilt, and of a little Cottage, made a famous Building, as now it is. John Gover the famous Poet, new built a great part of S. Mary Overies Church, where he lies buried. In a Parliament holden the ninth year of his Reign, the King moved to have allowed him every year, wherein no Parliament met, a Tenth of the Clergy, and a Fifteenth of the Laity; to which demand the Bi≈øhops con≈øented, but the Commons would not. In his ≈øeventh year a Parliament began at We≈øtmin≈øter, which la≈øted almo≈øt a whole year, wherein a Sub≈øidy was granted, which was ≈øo ≈øevere, that even Prie≈øts and Friars who lived of Alms, were forced every one to pay a Noble.

In the forty ≈øixth year of his Age, having peace at home and abroad, and being too active to be idle, King Henry re≈øolved to go to the Holy Land, and great provi≈øion was made for his Journey to Jeru≈øalem; but he needed no ≈øuch preparations: for being at Prayers at S. Edwards Shrine in We≈øtmin≈øter Abbey, he was ≈øuddenly raken with an Apoplexy, and thereupon removed to the Abbot of We≈øtmin≈øters hou≈øe, when recovering him≈øelf, he asked where he was; and being told that it was the Abbots hou≈øe, in a Chamber called Jeru≈øalem, Well then (≈øaid he) the Lord have mercy upon me, for this is the Jeru≈øalem, where an A≈øtrologer told me I ≈øhould die. And here he died indeed March 20. 1413. aged 46 years; of which he reigned 13.

It is worth remembring that all ‚Ä¢ he time of his Sickne≈øs he would have his Crown ≈øet upon his Bol≈øter by him, and one of his Fits being ≈øo ≈øtrong upon him, that all men thought him to be d ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ectly dead, the Prince his Son coming in, took away the Crown; when the King ≈øuddenly recovering his ≈øen≈øes, mi≈ø≈øed it, and asking for it, was told the Prince had taken it; whereupon the Prince being called, came back with the Crown, and kneeling down ≈øaid, Sir, to all our Judgments, and to all our Griefs, you ≈øeemed directly dead, and therefore I took the Crown as being my Right; but ≈øeeing to all our comforts you live, I here deliver it much more joyfully than I took it, and I pray God you may long live to wear it your ≈øelf. Well, (≈øaid the King ‚Ä¢ ighing) what Right I had to it God knoweth; but (≈øaith the Prince) if you die, my Sword ≈øhall maintain it to be my Right, again≈øt all oppo≈øers. Well, (≈øaith the King) I refer all to God; but I charge thee on my ble≈ø≈øing, that thou admini≈øter the Laws ju≈øtly, and equally, avoid Flatterers, defer not to do Ju≈øtice, neither be ≈øparing of Mercy. And then turning about ≈øaid, God ble≈øs thee, and have mercy upon thee: and with the≈øe words gave up the Gho≈øt. In this Kings Reign there died of the Pe≈øtilence in London, above thirty thou≈øand in a ≈øhort time, and a Fro≈øt la≈øted fifteen Weeks.

Henry the fifth ≈øucceeded his Father, and proved a very wi≈øe and valiant King, though the People much doubted of it, becau≈øe when he was Prince he followed ≈øuch di≈øorderly cour≈øes. For getting into company with ≈øome lewd Fellows, it is ≈øaid, he lay in wait for the Receivers of his Fathers Rents, and in the per≈øon of a Thief, ≈øet upon them, and Robbed them. Another time when one of his Companions was arraigned for Felony before the Lord Chief Ju≈øtice in We≈øtmin≈øter Hall, he went to the Kings Bench Bar, and
offered to take the Pri≈øoner away by force, but being with≈øtood by the Lord Chief Ju≈øtice, he ≈øtepped to him, and ≈øtruck him over the Face; whereat the Judge nothing di≈øturbed, ro≈øe up and told him, that he did not this affront to him, but to the King his Father, in who≈øe place he ≈øate; and therefore to make him ≈øen≈øible of his fault, he committed him Pri≈øoner to the Fleet.

It was wonderful how calm the Prince was in his own cau≈øe, who had been ≈øo violent in his Companions: for he pariently obeyed the Judges Sentence and ≈øuffered him≈øelf quietly to be led to Pri≈øon. This pa≈ø≈øage was very plea≈øing to the King his Father, to think he had a Judge of ≈øuch courage, and a Son of ≈øuch ≈øubmi≈ø≈øion. But yet for the≈øe and ≈øome other Frolicks, the King di≈øplaced him from being Pre≈øident of the Council, and placed therein his third Son John. This made the Prince ≈øo ≈øen≈øible of his Fathers di≈øplea≈øure, that he endeavoured to recover his good opinion, by as ≈øtrange a way as he lo≈øt it: for attiring him≈øelf in a Garment of blue Sattin, wrought all with Oylet holes of black Silk, the Needle hanging thereto, and about his Arm a thing like a Dogs Collar, ≈øtudded with SS of Gold, he came to the Court at We≈øtmin≈øter, to whom the King, though not well in health, cau≈øed him≈øelf to be brought in a Chair into his Privy Chamber, where in the pre≈øence of three or four onely of his Privy Council, he demanded of the Prince the cau≈øe of his unwonted Habit and coming; who an≈øwered, That being not onely his Subject, but his Son, and a Son always ≈øo tenderly beloved by him, he were worthy of a thou≈øand deaths, if he ≈øhould but intend or imagine the lea≈øt offence to his Maje≈øty, and had therefore prepared him≈øelf to be made a Sacrifice: and thereupon reached his Digger, and holding it by the point he ≈øaid; Sir, I de≈øire not to
live longer then that I may be thought to be what I am, and ≈øhall ever be, Your faithful and obedient Va≈ø≈øal.

With this or the like an≈øwer, the King was ≈øo moved, that he fell upon his Sons neck, and with many tears imbracing him, confe≈ø≈øed, That his ears had been too open to receive Reports again≈øt him, and promi≈øing faithfully, that from thenceforth no reports ≈øhould cau≈øe any di≈øaffection toward him. But as ≈øoon as this young King was Crowned at We≈øtmin≈øter he like king Saul ≈øeemed to have a new heart given him, and became another man than he was before. For calling his old Companions and brethren in evil before him, he ≈øtrictly charged them not to come within Ten miles of the Court till they had given proof of their Reformation, And to prevent their proceding in ill cour≈øes, he gave every one of them a ≈øufficient allowance.

Immediately after a Parliament was called at We≈øtmin≈øter, where a Sub≈øidy was granted without asking, and the Commons began to harp upon the old ≈øtring of taking away the Lands of the Clergy, which the Bi≈øhops, fearing the Kings inclination, endeavoured to divert, by ≈øhewing him the great Right he had to the Crown of France: which they made ≈øo plainly appear, that he alters his Arms, and quarters the Flower de Luces like the King of France; But to do it fairly, he ≈øends Amba≈ø≈øadors to Charles the ≈øixth King of France, Requiring him in a Peacable manner to ≈øurrender the Crown of France. The Amba≈ø≈øadors had five hundred Hor≈øe to attend them, and were at fir≈øt honourably received and Treated by the Court of France; but when their Me≈ø≈øage was known their Entertainment was ≈øoon altered and the Dauphin (who managed the Affairs of State during the Kings ≈øickne≈øs) about this time ≈øent a
Tun of Tennis Balls to K. Henry in deri≈øion of his Youth, as fitter to play with them than to manage Arms. Which King Henry took in ≈øuch ≈øcorn, that he promi≈øed with an Oath, It ≈øhould not be long before he would to≈øs ≈øuch iron Balls among them, that the be≈øt Arms of France ≈øhould not be able to hold a Racket to return them.

And accordingly he went with an Army into France, and utterly routed the French Army at Agincourt, though they were 6 times as many as the Engli≈øh, killing about nine thou≈øand of them, and taking fifteen hundred pri≈øoners; and on the Engli≈øh part not above ≈øix hundred were ≈ølain in all.

In the beginning of his Reign, the followers of Wickliff greatly encrea≈øed, of whom Sir John Old-Ca≈øtle was chief, who by marriage came to be Lord Cobham, and in great favour with the King. But being accu≈øed in a Synod of London for maintaining Wickliffs Doctrine, the King ≈øent for him, and per≈øuaded him to ≈øubmit to the cen≈øure of the Church; who told the King he onely owed ≈øubjection to his Maje≈øty, and for others, he would ≈øtand for the Truth again≈øt them with his life. Upon which he was cited to appear in the Bi≈øhops Court, which he refu≈øing was condemned by a Synod for an Heretick; in which Synod the Arch-Bi≈øhop of Canterbury cau≈øed it to be ordained, That the Holy Scriptures ought not to be tran≈ølated into the Engli≈øh Tongue. But mark the Judgment of God that fell upon his own Tongue, who≈øe roots and blade ≈øhortly after (as it is recorded) grew ≈øo big in his mouth and throat, that he could neither ≈øpeak nor ≈øwallow down meat, but in horrour lay langui≈øhing, till at la≈øt ≈øtarved by Famine, ≈øo died.

After this Sir John Oldca≈øtle was taken, and he, Sir Roger Acton, and twenty eight more, were executed
at S. Giles in the Fields, and in Smithfield, for Here≈øie: and all the Pri≈øons in and about London, were filled with his Followers.

In the third year of this Kings Reign, on Candlemas day, ≈øeven Dolphins came up the River of Thames, whereof four were taken. This King had ≈øuch command in France, that their own Chronicles te≈øtifie in the Court of Chancery in Paris, all things were ≈øealed with the Seal of King Henry of England. In the ≈øecond year of his Reign, Moregate near Coleman≈øtreet was fir≈øt made by Thomas Fawkener Mayor of London, who cau≈øed the Water of this City to be turned into the Thames in Walbrook, by making Grates in divers places.

King Henry the fifth died the thirty fifth year of his age, and the ninth of his Reign, leaving his Son Henry to enjoy his Crown, who was but eight months old when his Father died, yet by the Duke of Bedford, Regent of France, is proclaimed King of England and France at Paris, and at nine years old was crowned King there, receiving the Oaths and Fealty of all the French Nobility.

This King was very weak in Judgment, and was ruled onely by his Queen, which occa≈øioned him very great trouble: for they u≈øed his Authority for the de≈øtruction of the Duke of Gloce≈øter, and ≈øeveral other per≈øons, who were much beloved of the People. About which time the Duke of York began to whi≈øper his Right to the Crown, as de≈øcended from Philippa, Daughter and Heir to Lionel Duke of Clarence, Elder Brother to John of Gaunt, and Great Grandfather to the pre≈øent King Henry the ≈øixth, and it was privately di≈øcour≈øed, That King Henry was of a weak capacity, and ea≈øily abu≈øed, and the Queen, who was near to the French Queen, was of a malignant ≈øpirit, and bloudily ambitious, the Privy Council is wi≈øe enough,
yet not hone≈øt enough, regarding more their own pravate profit than the publick good, and that through their neglect, all France was lo≈øt, and that God would not ble≈øs the u≈øurped Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of King Henry. With the≈øe ≈øugge≈øtions the Kenti≈øh men ≈øeemed to be taken; which being ob≈øerved by an In≈øtrument of the Duke of York one Mortimer, he takes opportunity to tell the People, That if they will be ruled by him, he will ≈øhew them the way to make a thorough Reformation, and prevent the Taxes that are upon every ≈ølight occa≈øion laid upon them.

The≈øe promi≈øes of Reformation and Freedom, ≈øo wrought with the People, that they drew to a Head, and make Mortimer, otherwi≈øe called Jack Cade, their Leader, who ≈øtiled him≈øelf Captain Mendall: with whom they came to Black-heath, and lay thereabout a Moneth, ≈øending for whom, and what he plea≈øed. He then pre≈øents the complaint of the Commons to the Parliament, who ≈øent them to the Privy Council; but they explode them as frivolous, and charge the Authors to be pre≈øumptuous Rebels: and thereupon the King rai≈øeth an Army, and brings them to Greenwich; but the Lords could get no Followers to fight again≈øt them, who fought onely for Reformation of Abu≈øes, and for puni≈øhment of ≈øuch Traitors as they ≈øaid the Lord Say was. The Lord Say is hereupon committed to the Tower, and the King and Queen retire to London, whom Cade follows, and comes to Southwark, where he Quarters his men; and next morning marcheth to London Bridge, where he cau≈øed his Followers to cut the Rope of the Draw-bridge, no re≈øi≈øtance being made again≈øt him, and ≈øo in good order marched up to London-Stone, upon which he ≈øtrook his Sword, ≈øaying, Now is Mortimer Lord of London. He then ≈øent for the Lord Say out of the Tower, and cut off his head at the Standard in Cheap≈øide,
and al≈øo the head of Sir James Cromer High-Sheriff of Kent; but upon the Kings General Pardon, his Followers leave him, and he is ≈øoon after ≈ølain, and with the execution of eight more, though five hundred were found guilty, this In≈øurrection is ≈øuppre≈ø≈øed.

It was a cu≈øtom that upon St. Bartholomews day the Lord Mayor and Sheriffs of London, ≈øhould go to the Wre≈øtling-place near More-fields, where at this time the Prior of St. Johns likewi≈øe was to ≈øee the ≈øport; and a Servant of his being a≈øhamed to be foiled before his Ma≈øter, de≈øired to Wre≈øtle again, contrary to cu≈øtom, which the Lord Mayor denied: whereupon the Prior fetched Bowmen from Clerkenwel again≈øt the Mayor, and ≈øome ≈ølaughter was made; the Mayors Cap was ≈øhot through with an Arrow, yet he would have the ≈øport go on, but no Wre≈øtlers came: whereupon he ≈øaid, He would ≈øtay a while to make Trial of the Citizens re≈øpect to him; and pre≈øently after a great party of them came with Banners di≈øplaid, and fetched him home in triumph. Soon after another Quarrel happened in Holborn between the Gentlemen of the Inns of Chancery, and ≈øome Citizens, in appea≈øing whereof, the Queens Attorney and three more were ≈ølain. The year after the Apprentices of London, upon a very ≈ølight occa≈øion fall upon the Foreign Merchants, rifling and robbing their hou≈øes, but the Lord Mayor by his di≈øcretion appea≈øed the Tumult, puni≈øhing ≈øome of the Offenders with Death, and others by Fine, and all things are quieted and appea≈øed.
