div.p:
As ≈øoon as this Parliament was di≈ø≈øolved, the Duke ≈øends for the Queen and ≈øome others, to come out of Scotland. But they had rai≈øed an Army there, and the Duke of York met them with another; and at Wakefield Green the Duke is flain, with the lo≈øs of three thou≈øand of his men, and leing dead, had his head crowned with a Paper Crown, together with many other Circum≈øtances
of di≈øgrace. However his Son Edward Earl of March pro≈øecutes the Quarrel, and puts the Queens Forces to flight, which ≈øhe endeavoured to recruit; but ≈øome of her Northern Army having robbed the People as they came along the Country, ≈øaying, It was their Bargain to have all the Spoil in every place. The Londoners would not ≈øuffer any Provi≈øion to be ≈øent to them, the Commons ri≈øing about Cripplegate, and ≈øtopping the Carts which the Lord Mayor was ≈øending to the Army.

In the mean time the Earls of March and Warwick having got a con≈øiderable Army, march to London, and were joyfully received there. And ≈øoon after the Earl of Warwick drawing all his Forces into St. Johns Field by Clerkenwel, and having ca≈øt them in a Ring, he read to them the Agreement of the la≈øt Parliament, and then demanded, Whether they would have King Henry to reign ≈øtill? Who all cryed out, No, No. Then he asked them, Whether they would have the Earl of March, Elde≈øt Son of the Duke of York, (by that Parliament proclaimed King) to reign over them. Who with great ≈øhouting an≈øwered, Yes, Yes. Then ≈øeveral Captains and others of the City, went to the Earl of March at Baynards Ca≈øtle, to acquaint him what had pa≈ø≈øed; who at fir≈øt ≈øeemed to excu≈øe him≈øelf, as unable to execute ≈øo great a charge: but encouraged by the Archbi≈øhop of York, the Bi≈øhops of London and Exeter, and the Earl of Warwick, he at laft con≈øented to take it upon him; and ≈øoon after he was generally proclaimed King. And here Writers end the Reign of King Henry the ≈øixth, though there were ≈øeveral changes. For ≈øometimes he was a King, and ≈øometimes none, yet he was never well ≈øetled, though he lived twelve years after.

King Henry was then in the North, and rai≈øe
an Army to oppo≈øe Edward, but is defeated by the Lord Falconbridge. Upon which Henry and his Queen go to Scotland, and rai≈øe more Forces, but are again beaten. And now King Edward ≈øits three days together in the Kings Bench in We≈øtmin≈øter Hall to hear Cau≈øes and regulate Di≈øorders. And the Earl of Warwick is ≈øent into France to treat of a Marriage with that Kings daughter ‚Ä¢ but in the mean while the King marries the Lady Elizabeth Gray. At which Warwick grows di≈øcontented, and joins again≈øt King Edward, and ≈øurprizing him, takes him Pri≈øoner, but he ≈øoon made his e≈øcape. King Henry was taken in di≈øgui≈øe and ≈øent to the Tower of London ≈øome years before. And now Warwick going to France, brought a great Army over, and proclaimed Edward an U≈øurper; who thereupon endeavoured to rai≈øe an Army but could not, and therefore fled out of England into the Duke of Burgundies Country, and King Henry is taken out of Pri≈øon, where he had been nine years, and again proclaimed King.

But King Edward, by the a≈ø≈øi≈øtance of the Duke of Burgundy, lands an Army in Yorkshire, and marches towards London, where he was joyfully received. And in the year 1471, and the 11 year of his Reign, K. Edward made his entry into the City, and had King Henry delivered into his hands. The Earl of Warwick having notice thereof, marcheth with his Army toward St. Albans, and King Edward follows him, carrying King Henry along with him; where the Earl of Warwick and many others are ≈ølain, and Henries Parry utterly routed.

And now was the time for King Henry to be delivered out of all his Troubles; for the bloudy Duke of Gloce≈øter entering the Tower of London, where he ≈øound King Henry nothing at all troubled
for all his Cro≈ø≈øes, ≈øtruck him into the heart with his Dagger, and there ≈ølew him. And now within half a years ≈øpace, we find one Parliament proclaimed Edward an U≈øurper, and Henry a lawful King; and another proclaiming Edward a lawful King, and Henry an U≈øurper; that we may know there is nothing certain in humane Affairs, but uncertainty.

In the fifth year of King Henry the ≈øixth, it rained almo≈øt continually from Ea≈øter to Michaelmas: In his ≈øeventh year the Duke of Norfolk was like to have been drowned pa≈ø≈øing through London Bridge, his Barge being ≈øet upon the Piles ≈øo overwhelmed, that thirty per≈øons were drowned, and the Duke with others that e≈øcaped, were fain to be drawn up with Ropes. In his ≈øeventeenth year was ≈øo great a Dearth of Corn, that people were glad to make Bread of Fearn roots. Next year all the Lions in the Tower died. In the thirty third year of his Reign, there was a great Blazing Star, and there happened a ≈øtrange ≈øight, a mon≈øtrous Cock came out of the Sea, and in the pre≈øence of a multitude of people, made a hideous crowing three times, beckening toward the North, South, and We≈øt. There were al≈øo many prodigious Births, and in ≈øome places it rained bloud.

About this time the Draw-bridge on London Bridge was made, and Leaden Hall was built to be a Storehou≈øe of Grain and Fewel for the poor of the City. In the fir≈øt year of this Kings Reign a Parliament was held at London, where the Queen-Mother, with the young King in her lap, came and ≈øate in the Hou≈øe of Lords. In this Kings Reign Printing was fir≈øt brought into England by William Caxton of London Mercer, who fir≈øt practi≈øed the ≈øame in the Abby of We≈øtmin≈øtor 1471. This King Henry lo≈øt his Kingdom
when he had reigned thirty eight years ≈øix months and odd days. The day after he was murdered he was brought to St. Pauls Church in an open Coffin bare-faced, where he bled; and from thence carried to Black Fryars, where he al≈øo bled, and la≈øtly was buried at Wind≈øor.

In the fir≈øt year of King Edward the fourth Walter Walker Grocer, living in Cheap≈øide, was beheaded for ≈øpeaking ≈øome words again≈øt King Edward. In his fourth year there was a great Pe≈øtilence, and the Thames was frozen over. In his 14 year John Gro≈øe was burnt on Tower-hill for Religion. The ≈øame year King Edward in his Progre≈øs hunting in Sir Thomas Burdels Park, ≈ølew many Deer, and among the re≈øt a white Buck, which Sir Thomas hearing of, wi≈øhed the Bucks head, horns and all in his belly who moved the King to kill him. Upon which words he was condemned to die, and being drawn from the Tower of London to Tyburn, was there beheaded. Next year George D. of Clarence K. Ed. Brother, was drowned in the Tower in a But of Malm≈øey. In his twenty ≈øecond year ≈øome Thieves for Robbery in St. Martins le Grand, were drawn to Tower-hill and there hanged and burnt, and others were pre≈ø≈øed to death.
In this Kings time Richard Raw≈øon, one of the Sheriffs of London, cau≈øed a Hou≈øe to be built at St. Mary Spittle for the Lord Mayor and Aldermen to hear Sermons in the Ea≈øter Holy-days.

King Edward the fourth being dead, his elde≈øt Son Edward, not above eleven years old, was proclaimed King, but never crowned; for the Duke of Gloce≈øter hearing of his Brothers death, comes to London, and having gotten the King and his Brother the Duke of York into his hands, ≈øends them to the Tower, and murders the Lord Hatings who was true to Edward, and then endeavours to prove the two children of Edward Illegitimate,
whereby he at la≈øt attained the Crown by the name of Richard the third, and afterwards per≈øuades Sir James Tyril to murder the two young Princes in the Tower, who getting two other Villains as bad as him≈øelf, they come to the childrens chamber in the night, and ≈øuddenly wrapping them up in their cloths, and keeping down by force the Feather-bed and Pillows hard upon their mouths, ≈øo ≈øtifled them that their breath being gone, they ≈øurrendred up their innocent ≈øouls; and when the Murtherers perceived fir≈øt by their ≈øtrugling with the pains of death, and then by their long lying ≈øtill, that they were throughly dead, they laid their bodies out, and then called Sir James Tyril to ≈øee them, who pre≈øently cau≈øed their bodies to be buried under the Stairs. But the≈øe Murderers came all to mi≈øerable ends; and King Richard him≈øelf, after this abominable Fact, never had a quiet mind, but was troubled with fearful dreams, and would ≈øometimes ≈øtart out of his bed and run about the chamber in a great fright, as if all the Furies in Hell were about him, as he did the night before the Battle at Bo≈øworth Field, where he was ≈ølain by King Henry the ≈øeventh, who ≈øucceeded to the Crown.

King Richard took away from Jane Shore one of King Edwards Concubines, all her Goods, to the value of above 3000 Marks; and afterward cau≈øed her to do Pennance before the Cro≈øs for her Incontinency, with a Taper in her hand: when, though undre≈ø≈øed, yet ≈øhe appeared ≈øo fair, and lovely, and likewi≈øe ≈øo mode≈øt, that many who hated her cour≈øe of life, yet pitied her cour≈øe u≈øage, ≈øince ≈øhe u≈øed all the favour ≈øhe had with King Edward to the good of many, but never to the hurt of any. And truly ≈øhe had cau≈øe to complain again≈øt Richard for being ≈øo ≈øevere for her offending again≈øt the ≈øeventh Commandment

And the Lady Jane Gray Daughter of the Duke of Suffolk, was proclaimed Queen by the Lord Mayor and Aldermen of London, as being made Heir to the Crown by the la≈øt Will of King Edward; upon which the Lady Mary flies to Farmingham Ca≈øtle in Suffolk, and there, upon her ≈øolemn promi≈øe and engagement not to alter the Religion e≈øtabli≈øhed, nor to bring in Popery, the Gentlemen of that Country and Norfolk joined with her, and ≈øoon after ≈øhe obtained the Crown.
